column1: There are many good things to say about Mr. McWhorter's book. Manty other reviewers have done that.  I want to add a warning.  Mr. McWhorter's book is about the theory of language dynamics.  It is not about any particular language

column3: people
column4: place
column5: or time.  Mr. McWhorter explains the processes that cause languages to change over time.  He does a remarkably good job of this.  However
column6: he makes references to actual languages and actual statements only as they serve to illustrate changes over time.  If you are looking for some understanding of some particular language at some particular time
column7: you will sadly agree with me that this book constantly changes the topic.  If there is a sustained discussion of one language for more than ten pages
column8: then I cannot find it.  I must admit that I could not finish the book
column9: after several tries.  The subtitle should be removed from the book.  This book is not a history of languages.  It is an excellent exposition for the general reader of the dynamic forces behind language change.  However
column10: it contains nothing about any particular language

column1: "The Case for Israel" is written by the Harvard law professor Alan Dershowitz. Politically
column2: he could be described as a Cold War liberal. He supports gay rights
column3: affirmative action and OJ Simpson
column4: while opposing Cuba and Communism. And he supports Israel. Ironically
column5: his support for Israel is as uncritical as the attitude of the CPUSA towards the Soviet Union. Dershowitz even defends house demolitions
column6: and have proposed that entire Palestinian villages be destroyed in retaliation for suicide bombings. Despite protestations to the contrary
column7: he also supports torture. Yet
column8: Dershowitz is a member of Amnesty International!   "The Case for Israel" is a piece of badly edited and completely fanaticized pro-Israeli propaganda. It was obviously written in great haste
column9: since it contains a number of factual errors and misspellings. For instance
column10: the author seems to think that the Philippines are a Muslim nation
column11: and calls the notorious Spartacist League "Spartacus League". In an earlier edition
column12: he even claimed that the phrase "Turnspeak" comes from George Orwell. (Its Newspeak
column13: of course.) While sloppy editing like this is amusing
column14: the main theses of the book certainly are not. Here
column15: I will concentrate on just two of them.   First
column16: the question of collective punishment. Dershowitz argues that all
column17: or most
column18: Palestinians are guilty
column19: since they sympathize with terrorist groups or actions. Thus
column20: even punishment of civilians is justified. There is a "continuum of civilianity"
column21: says the author
column22: since its not always easy to distinguish civilians from combatants among the Palestinians. They are all in on it
column23: after all.   Of course
column24: this bizzare line of argument works both ways. Most American Jews aid and abet Israel. Would that justify a bomb in a Brooklyn shopping mold? Most Israelis support the on-going attack on Lebanon. Does that justify bombing Haifa? And what about kibbutzniks at the Syrian border or settlers at the West Bank? They are heavily armed
column25: and some of them are illegal
column26: making the distinction between civilians and combatants on the Jewish side hard to draw. Indeed
column27: Osama bin-Laden justified 9/11 in exactly the same way. The American people elected the politicians responsible for attacking Iraq and supporting Israel. Therefore
column28: they must take collective responsibility for the death of Arab civilians. (See "Messages to the World" by Osama bin-Laden
column29: available here at Amazon.com.)   Alan Dershowitz attempts to circumvent this by claiming that the Jews who are killed by Palestinian suicide bombings are "perfectly innocent" and are killed "regardless of their political views". But most Israelis dont vote for parties demanding immidiate withdrawal from the Occupied Territories
column30: and today most support the attack on Lebanon. By Dershowitzian logic
column31: they are therefore not "perfectly innocent". But the opposite is true as well: Dershowitz demagogically points out that some Israelis killed by suicide bombers were teenagers. Yet
column32: he supports the massive ethnic cleansing of Germans by the Soviet Army during the last phase of World War Two
column33: seeing this as suitable collective punishment. Of course
column34: these actions affected teenagers as well
column35: including teenage girls gang raped by Soviet soldiers... By implication
column36: Dershowitz even seems to support the nuking of Hiroshima and Nagasaki
column37: where many teenagers and kids died as well! (For the record: I support the Allies and my grandfather was a Communist partisan during the war. But that doesnt mean I have to accept Allied atrocities.)   The author of "The Case for Israel" also claims that there is a difference between intentionally killing civilians (like Hamas) and unintentionally killing them while bombing military targets (like the IDF). He also points out that Israel gives advance warning before it bombs civilian areas. Are there no bounds to the cynicism of this man? Perhaps Israel doesnt "want" to kill civilians (its bad PR
column38: after all) but their two invasions of Lebanon clearly prove that they couldnt care less if civilians do get killed. They are
column39: after all
column40: all guilty
column41: right? As for giving advance warning
column42: the IRA gave advance warning before its attacks against civilian targets in Britain. Logically
column43: Dershowitz should claim that the IRA and the British were morally equivalent
column44: but of course he doesnt. Besides
column45: there may be many reasons why civilians cant leave a targeted area even if given advance warning. Witness the hurricane Katrina in the US. Besides
column46: why SHOULD they leave? Would American Jews "just leave" New York if given advance warning about another al-Qaeda attack? I guess so
column47: but they would surely demand swift counter-action by Ms. Rice. And Im not talking UN resolutions.   So why do Alan Dershowitz have one standard for the Jews and a quite different one for the Arabs? This bring me to my second point. The reason
column48: of course
column49: is that he believes Palestine to be rightfully Jewish. And not just Palestine
column50: but apparently Transjordan as well!   On what grounds? That Jews have an automatic right to Palestine
column51: no matter what
column52: is an idea that can only be "justified" religiously. But the author is a secularist. With the risk of drawing some fire
column53: I dont belive there are any secular grounds for automatically granting the Jews Palestine
column54: save one: the "right" or might of conquest. Before the Zionist colonization
column55: Palestine was predominantly Arab
column56: and had been Arab for around 1200 years. No amount of sophistry can change this fact
column57: and Dershowitz tries some! That Jews had an independent kingdom in Palestine over 2000 years ago is irrelevant. By that logic
column58: New York City should be given over to the Manahata Indians. Ironically
column59: that would force its Jewish community to re-settle in Israel
column60: something they havent been very keen on doing for the past 60 years. Presumably
column61: Egypt should be given over to some descendant of Cleopatra
column62: provided such could be found.   The case for Transjordan being Jewish is non-existent on secular grounds
column63: pace Dershowitz
column64: and flimsy even on religious grounds. Some Biblical passages suggest that everything from the Stream of Egypt to the Euphrates is rightfully Jewish. That would include both Transjordan and half of Iraq! Other Biblical passages suggest that "only" the northwestern part of Transjordan should be Jewish. But most limit the Promised Land to Palestine proper
column65: leaving out the areas east of Jordan. The rabbinical commentary "Tevuos Haaretz" exclude both the Negev and Transjordan from Eretz Israel
column66: but include Lebanon. "Kaftor VaFerach" also include the coast of Syria
column68: no Transjordan. The relevant maps can be found in the Stone edition of the Jewish Bible
column69: available from this site.   So what is the real case for Israel? Frankly
column70: the only case that could be made for it
column73: and simply wont go away. In a perfect world
column75: with the Jews forming their own state some place else
column76: or Jews and Arabs would love each other
column77: and hence create a bi-national state. But the Jews created their own state in Palestine
column78: and they dont like Arabs. Welcome to the dog-eat-dog imperfect world. For pragmatic reasons of Realpolitik
column79: compromises are called for. What the compromise must be is obvious: a two-state solution
column80: with Israel withdrawing from the West Bank and Gaza strip
column81: where a Palestinian state should be set up. The Palestinian refugees
column84: except perhaps to the Palestinian state. I agree with Prof. Alan Dershowitz on one point only: It was indeed a mistake for Arafat not to continue the negotiations at Camp David in 2000. However

column86: since Israel would surely have demanded all kinds of "security guarantees" from such a state. Arafat isnt the only culprit here...   When I was more pro-Israeli

column88: I changed my mind. Mr. Dershowitz

column1: The amount of praise given to this work does not surprise me given that there is a widespread
column2: yet subtle
column3: socialist movement in America as well as in Europe.  Despite this
column4: the book is a failed attempt at reconciling the ideal with reality.  Rawls commits one of the many age-old flaws of collectivism
column5: attempting to force morality on immoral beings. Rawls' entire work is fundamentally flawed in that the hypothetical situation from which the entire theory relies
column6: selectively allows certain knowledge
column7: assumptions
column8: etc. while conveniently eliminating others.  For instance
column9: empirical evidence that shows capitalism outperforms other economic systems cannot be known in the original position.  This is profound when one considers that we live in a hostile world that requires nations to invest in security of which economic power is imperative.  Thus
column10: capitalism may be a necessary injustice in order to safeguard liberal democracy.  If we compare the human condition prior to capitalism
column11: one can see that perhaps a collectivist system that may contribute to capitalism's downfall is immoral
column12: if it leads us back in this direction.  Consequentalism perhaps?  Despite this
column13: the people in the original position cannot have this knowledge.  Therefore
column14: information that is direly relevant to the construction of a social system in a hostile world cannot be used in determining its structure.  Somehow though
column15: the people do understand the important of the right to vote
column16: equality
column17: etc. This is absurd and impractical.  Rationale beings need to analyze as much information as is available and pertinent to any decisions they make.  Rawls continuously attempts to explain his "tweaks" as rationale but it is obvious that they are all implemented in order to discount human nature and proceed in theoretical terms.  On a side note
column18: Rawls' first principle calls for the right to vote
column19: what would his state do if citizens began to vote for a more capitalistic system that defied his "justice"?  Iron fist?  Nevertheless
column20: it is quite obvious what Rawls is attempting here.  In a hypothetical situation where we all have to fear being born without intelligence
column21: strength
column22: status etc. we will take the safe route and ensure ourselves the highest index of goods.  This may be true
column23: or it may not (human nature seems to embrace risk taking) however this situation is irrelevant because of its exclusion of relevant information.  Hobbes for instance accepted human nature and the potential for a wide array of circumstances in his hypothetical Natural Condition.  While Rawls may have some strong arguments in declaring that his two principles are the epitome absolute justice
column24: this does not mean they are practical in a hostile world.  Essentially
column25: what Rawls is saying is that none of us deserved to be born intelligent
column26: responsible
column27: hard working
column28: but that we were simply lucky in the natural lottery.  Because of this arbitrary distribution
column29: he believes that we all must compensate for those unfortunate souls that were born unintelligent
column30: lazy
column31: and perhaps even immoral!  I'd admonish Rawls not to attempt applying his insane reasoning to the criminal justice system (Poor
column32: unfortunate murderer).  If Rawls believes that the laziest
column33: dumbest
column34: and most immoral person still deserves a living wage despite not working
column35: he has contradicted himself in that this justifies slavery
column36: forcing individuals to work for other individuals without compensation.  This simply cannot be justice as "fairness".  Nevertheless
column37: I'd recommend it to all free market advocates simply to strengthen their positions.  As a warning however
column38: be prepared for a work that lacks brevity
column39: organization
column40: coherence
column41: and most importantly
column42: reality

column1: What it this? Disney's original animated film `The Jungle Book' was made in 1967
column2: and after almost 40 years they released a sequel `The Jungle Book 2.' What is the point of doing this anyway?  To be fair
column3: the sequel is not a horrible film. It has more colors (more light colors in the jungle) and comes with the original's exhilarating `Bare Necessities.' Who can dislike this song? And the introductory part using stick puppets is cleverly done
column4: letting us into the world of the wild child Mowgli and his friends.  But after that
column5: about 10 minutes or so
column6: the film suddenly starts to look not-so-ambitious attempt to re-tell the story of the original
column7: which should have been ended 40 years ago. In this sequel Mowgli
column8: who is fed up with the rules of the village
column9: goes back to the jungle where his friend big bear Baloo is living and dancing to that charming song alone. Now Baloo is happy to meet the boy again for he is lonely and needs a partner to do the musical number.  But we are not so happy. That is partly because their reunion virtually ignores the original film's conclusion
column10: and partly because we know the same story has just begun again. The difference between the 1967 version and this one is that Shanti also steps into the jungle with a little boy Ranjan
column11: but this slight difference means little to us because both of them are quite unmemorable.   After all
column12: the problem is not the fact that the story of `The Jungle Book 2' in fact retreads that of the original because few people would still remember the details of the film made 40 years ago. The real drawback is that in `JB2' nothing interesting happens except the last 10 minutes where the bad tiger tries to kill Mowgli. The film provides musical scenes (which are decent themselves)
column13: but they only stretch the thin story. Even though I love the song Bare Necessities
column14: I don't want to listen to it three times in a short film that only runs 72 minutes.  To me (I am living in Japan) the most shocking thing about the film is that like the so-so film `Return to Neverland' `The Jungle Book 2' was originally made for video
column15: and then was chosen for theatrical release in USA and UK. That they can do such a thing is as unaccountable as the company's choice of the material for the sequel

column1: Before I started reading "Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
column2: the book had a lot going for it: stellar reviews on the cover, an intriguing title and its status as one of five or six books found in the meager philosophy section at Walden Books in Pocatello.  Unfortunately, despite these advantages, the book failed to deliver anything but ambiguity and disappointment. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't terrible, it just wasn't very good.  I'm not sure whether the book is a memoir, a novel or a philosophical treatise. In Zen" Robert Pirsig tells the story of a motorcycle trip he went on with his son
column3: Chris in the 1970s. But the story
column4: I guess
column5: is not really about the bike trip itself but the thoughts the author has about quality and technology.  The only interesting passage of the whole book can be found on page  17:      "The Buddha
column6: the Godhead
column7: resides quite as comfortably in the circuits of a computer or the gears of a cycle transmission as he does at the top of a mountain or in the petals of a flower."  That passage is good. The rest of the book is depressing and confusing. Throughout the entire motorcycle trip
column8: the author ignores his son and becomes lost in his own head thinking deep thoughts about the definition of "quality."   I'm not sure if this book was intended as a novel
column9: but if it was
column10: it failed to produce character growth. It's standing as a work of philosophy is not much better. The author's ideas could have been explained in a 20 page essay and been much clearer.   Whatever the book was supposed to be
column11: it didn't impressed me.

column1: From what was a landmark study by ethnobiologist Wade Davis into the folk preparations in the creation of zombies and the belief system associated with Haitian voodoo came a Eurocentric mess of a movie with the same title that was originally released in 1988.  It was reported at the time that Davis only agreed to sell the rights of the book if Peter Weir was hired as the movie director and Mel Gibson would play the leading role (based on Davis). Neither person was ever involved in the movie project.   The DVD cover tells the story as presented by director Wes Craven; the movie strips the book of its exploration into the real history and customs of the religious practices unique to Haitian society and pounds away at the the evilness of voodoo and the destruction it can cause to the human psyche.  In the movie
column2: the scientist is in search of a secret voodoo powder that places people in a simulated death. The setting is in a time of political revolution and the movie does touch upon authentic details of Haitian society. But the action degenerates into the overt racism of the horror genre that gets repeated over and over again; the darker the skin
column3: the more evil the sin.   To save time and money
column4: purchase the book and appreciate the solid research and writing by Davis & disregard the DVD.

I reached the point of not caring anyway and just kept reading to get to the end.  The whole thing reads like a Mission Impossible TV episode but nowhere near as good or exciting.  The scenes in the UK were very sloppy; there are no such things as pound notes and the beefeaters actually guard the Tower of London not Buckingham Palace.  I can only hope that it is Craig Dirgo that is the problem and that when the next Oregon Files book comes out written by Jack DuBrul (who I am a great fan of in his own right) that things will improve

 I found stale recounting of very well-known facts about 20th century technologies and their economics, with no insights.  Since it covers the gamut from plastics to jet engines to microprocessors, and it's only 200  pages in a fairly large typeface, I wasn't expecting historical depth.  But  I was expecting at least one fresh idea.  I bought it on the strength of a  much earlier book by Nathan Rosenberg (about technology in the economy of  the 19th century).  I was disappointed.  I get the feeling the book is  intended as a brief survey for people who just came down in the last shower  -- college freshmen born in the 1980s.  I'll bet they find it kinda stodgy 
 WARNING, SPOILER:  Clarissa is hounded by an evil young man whos see her, at first, as nothing more than a challenge. then he is obsessed in possessing her even if it means sullying her honor and breaking her spirit.  Toward the end of the movie, after many twists and turns, when it is clear that she wants nothing to do with him, and rapes her while others hold her down, something I didn't expect at all.  She feels so violated, that she wills herself to die. I hated the story so much that I regret viewing it. Had I known about the rape scene I would not have wasted my time watching this.  Silly me in believing that virture will always triumph--certainly not in this story. If you love Jane Austen and all that her heroines stand for, then don't waste your time on this story 
 I read the whole book. I am a long time AK resident, born and raised.  I've been to 'the bus', I talked with a person who discovered Chris' lifeless body in his sleeping bag many years ago. That conversation lead me to read this book. I found the author attempting to make Chris some sort of 'hero' for what he attempted. He was not.  He committed suicide using his firearm.  He knew that he would starve to death.  I don't understand why he didn't walk out on the high ground. It wouldn't of been easy, but it can be done.  I've done it myself in other drainages, Healy creek for example.  I've walked in the hills for 25 miles back to the road when the creek was at flood stage.  It can be done and if Chris had half a brain he would of known that. In his weakened condition was not thinking clearly or he was not using the brains he was born with.  I just don't understand it, a life wasted.  I am sure that Chris's parents had a big hand in the writing of this book.  I'm guessing that they wouldn't let Jon write the truth on how Chris died.  I guess I don't blame them, but the book has lost lots of credibility with me because it is not factual 
 This is a very good book for an academic setting or for a new RN.  It was not however helpful to me, a nurse with more than two decades of experience.  This is my first review for Amazon.  I write this so that some reader can avoid the pain I suffered.  The book was the worst mystery I have ever read.  Wild plot twists have been mentioned by others, nonsensical plot twists are a better description. I found none of the book to be believable and must admit the the only reason I finished to the book was to see if the final half was worse than the first half.  This book was factually wrong in so many ways. Here are a few; 1) The prices listed were off. 2)College professors held office hours late on Friday afternoons. 3) Someone was paid with $1000 dollar bills.    I will give away one plot twist.  Someone has been stealing rare books for months.  Someone is given a contract to kill a girl two weeks before the first attempt is made to kill the girl who happens to be reading the rare book.  The brillant detectives assume the book thefts are to a smart way to cover up the murder.  I would have found the book less offensive if the plot twist was that young aliens were playing with their parents' time machine and that the aliens had given the murder contract in order to prevent their parents' from discovering the youthful indecretion

column1: There are just too many errors

column4: in this book to justify purchasing it.In this review we will concentrate on Rima's(R)handling of the work of J M Keynes.On p.84
column5: R's claim that the Physiocratic concept of hoarding is "surprisingly suggestive" of J M Keynes's idea has no supporting evidence to back it up.On p.133
column6: R claims that Malthus had developed a principle of effective demand
column7: a la Keynes.What Malthus expressed was an uneasy feeling and/or intuition that Ricardo's deductive
column8: analytical system of market self adjustment to a global optimum was overlooking(or assuming away)the possibility of insufficient aggregate spending.Nowhere does Malthus ever systematically present a theoretical counter to Ricardo.What Malthus does is express some reservations in an exchange of postal letters with Ricardo.In chapter 20 of R's book
column9: she attempts to deal with Keynes's theory of effective demand and Keynes's discussion of involuntary unemployment which follows directly from his theory.Keynes worked out the mathematical details in his chapter 20
column10: titled "The Employment Function".R should have simply reprinted that chapter in her book
column11: replacing her chapter 20 with Keynes's chapter 20.R's Figure 20.1

column6: it becomes clearer and clearer that some of these things are either made up or a rip-off from other NDE accounts.  The author seems sincere and it is a heartfelt account.  I could actually feel myself in her shoes in each page of the book
column7: and empathize with her.  The book is heart-wrenching at times and I actually sobbed.  Not so much in sorrow

column9: and it provides an invaluable message...  That the most important thing in life is to enjoy life and to love each other.  Now what I just wrote would make the book worth 5 stars.  However
column10: this is where the scale tips backwards.  The book is biased.  She goes on to say that while she was in "heaven" in her NDE
column11: she realized that the creator of the Universe and all else is Jesus Christ himself.  Of course the description of Jesus is the typical white man with a beard with a light glowing from within his beard.  That's all fine and good.  BUT
column12: Mrs. Eadie forgets to say that the creator of the Universe presented itself to HER as Jesus Christ.  This is not a Universal Truth
column13: it is the author's truth.   Eadie makes a good point that while in "heaven
column14: she learned that it is foolish to criticize other people's religious beliefs, or lack of...  Then she ruins this promising statement by indicating that Christianity is at the top rung and that all other religions don't hold the same love and promises as the gospel.  To a Christian or Mormon, this would make sense, but the TRUTH is that all religions or lack of them are EQUAL.  Christianity is no better than Buddhism, Hinduism, Judaism, Wicca, Paganism, Tao, or any others.  To think that one is better, more true, or superior to another (even if the bible says so), is just plain ignorance.  The bias on the importance of men is another downfall for the book, going back to women being weaker in nature than men and that it was Eve's impatience" or whatever in the "garden of eden" (a biblical fable no more true than the myth of Pandora's Box) that brought death into the world.   Men and women are EQUAL

column1: As someone interested in the Russian Revolution
column2: I found this book at a school library and read it. I was not favorably impressed. Lenin is pushed down to the level of megalomaniac idiot. You don't have to like the guy to try to really explain his motivations or to seek real answers to the questions that bamboozle people. In addition to the pyscho-babble mentioned by other reviewers
column3: I had a problem with Robert Service picking on someone who is to dead to sue him for slander. Robert Service accuses Lenin of shooting down his own Soviet troops (an absolute idiocy in the middle of a civil war).It may be fashionable to produce "exposes" of Soviet leaders
column4: but that doesn't make it a good trend. Modern biographers of the Russian revolutionaries need to remember that Joe McCarthy and his Committee are no longer here to black-list them. In Robert Service's biography
column5: I was upset to find the author judging Lenin through 21st century glasses. By this I mean: 1. Cutting out the context of the Russian economy's ruin during the Civil War. 2. The abject failures of the "democrats"  3. Forgetting what the alternatives would have been had the opposition won (I don't mean the Whites- even the peasants hated them) I wonder what Mr. Service would do if he were in Lenin's shoes...  While I'm wondering
column6: I think I'll go pick up W. Bruce Lincoln's books on how the revolution happened and what happened during and after the civil war

column1: Sontag represents a certain type of "intellectual" who is - thankfully - becoming increasingly rare in the world of google and broadband. As exemplified by Descartes (I think
column2: therefore I am)
column3: this is the school of people who think that truth can be discovered solely through rumination - without doing any research
column4: without experimentation
column5: without any investigation of the world outside of your skull. It is pure subjectivity - gloriously self-referential and egotistic
column6: completely self-contained and titannically self-satisfied. What Sontag's writings are about are Sontag - not the world as it is (and which can easily be fact checked) but the world as seen through the coke bottle lens of Sontag's ego and self. Sontag would hate the comparison but she is the leftist equivalent of the medieval christian mystic - the world outside of her own mind doesn't matter and facts have no weight. This is what enabled her - in one of the most egregious public acts of heartlessness in the last one hundred years - to praise the 9/11 terrorists for bravery while the World Trade Center was still smoldering and bodies were still being dragged from the debris. This was like praising the Nazi concentration camp managers for efficiency and thoroughness. Having distanced herself from humanity and decency with her warped and unbalanced intellect
column7: the stunned response to her statements probably bewildered her completely. No matter as her crazed statements had plenty of precedents in her previous writings. She took the very cheap
column8: easy
column9: and elitist high road of condemning every wrong in the world - without ever offering any solutions and always
column10: always
column11: condemning the USA for actually trying to do something about these problems rather than just word process away safely in her study surrounded by the works of Verlaine
column12: Rimbaud
column13: and Genet.  In Photography
column14: Sontag is at the Acme of her (witch) craft. She thinks (and enough critics seemed to have agreed with her) that a well written sentence implies veracity as if the good sentence was a litmus test for truth; as if grammar and a good thesaurus conferred reliability

column1: This is the first review i've written and I just wanted to let people know that this in essence is a  good book....but only if your looking for drugs/medications as a priority to dealing with your hormonal problems. I ordered this book along with another book called "hormonal balance" and there's no comparing between the two. The other book talks indepth about exactly what your hormones do...and how they control your body. This book gives a short explanation followed by prescriptions that your doctor might advise...it has alternative treatments...but they are not very detailed...and focus more on "get more sleep....exercise....etc". All in all it's not a bad book...but there are definetly better one's out there

column3: authors Beard
column4: Kennedy

column9: Malek cuts down the number of tests from 6 to 3. Nearly every one of the regurgitated questions is a reprint from nearly 15 years ago
column10: thus ensuring that this text does not reflect any of the major changes in test content during that time. What Malek does try is to emulate the far more successful paradign put out by the Princeton Review's CRACKING THE GRE LITERATURE by codifying the vast array of western literature: genres
column11: timelines
column12: book and author lists
column13: literary terms
column14: schools of literary criticism
column15: etc. The problem is that Malek did not do half as thorough a job as the Princeton Review did. Malek does little more than to use an overly broad brush to skim a distressingly long list of required readings without giving any hint as how to best do that. True
column16: neither did the Princeton Review
column17: but at least the latter presented a methodology that was reasonable. This is not to say that Malek's updated text is useless. Anything
column18: no matter how scant

column1: I read this book years ago when it was first published.  Mr. Sick allowed himself to be taken in by a collection of Iranian liars as well as some phonies claiming to have experience in intelligence.  Some of the people Sick listened to were shown in the Iran-Contra hearings to be con artists who also took in Ollie North and Bill Casey.  These con artists are experts at saying what the listener wants to hear.  One guy claimed to have been in Special Forces and was an eyewitness to one of VP-candidate Bush's flights to meet with Iranians.  It turns out that he was not in Special Forces at all and he had been dishonorably discharged from the US Army.  In addition
column2: he could not have been an eyewitness to the event he claims to have seen because he was in jail at the time.  The phony intelligence specialists have also been proven to be liars with no experience in intelligence or anything resembling national security work.  By the time I finished this book
column3: I actually felt sorry for Sick because he had allowed himself to be taken in by these jokers.  He clearly wanted to believe that what he was being told was true.  This book does not prove anything except that even an experienced researcher can be fooled if he really wants to believe.  Subsequent investigations by a Democratically dominated Congress proved that there was no October surprise

This is one of those books where all the best parts can be found on the book jacket!  I was intrigued by the book jacket description of the Swap Shop Show:  "If you've got something you're itching to sell
column2: something  you mighta never woulda bought no way
column3: then give us a call
column4:
but this  idea isn't expanded upon in the text.  Instead, this seems to be another in  a series of recent books where the authors seem to believe a series of  quirky characters alone a great novel make.  Not so.  Readers want  characters they can get to know, characters who grow and change throughout  the book, not a series of semi-related vignettes about cardboard cutouts of  people.  I particularly found McCorkle unable to handle the parallel story  lines well.  Perhaps the plot ties together in the end (I just couldn't get  that far, I really tried!), but the impression I got was of jerking back  and forth between stories that may have stood better on their own.  For  examples of successful books employing the parallel-lives technique, see  Tom Wolfe's *A Man in Full* or Michelle Huneven's *Round Rock.*  I've  gathered in reading reviews that McCorkle is being hailed as a great new  Southern author; I found no Southern flavor at all in this book.  These  silly characters could have lived anywhere.  I guess I'll stick to Rita Mae  Brown when I want a taste of the South 
 The problem with all Indian cultural analysts living outside India including those writing on cinema is that while they fulfill a mandatory understanding of the cultural theories in vogue at the undergraduate level  in the US, Europe and Australia, they display a singular lack of  sensitivity while dealing with the material at hand. Their survival,  therefore, depends almost entirely on their reader's lack of knowledge of  the field of study which will include amongst other things the native  language, the local history as well as the local lores. On all these counts  Ms Chakravarty's book is sadly lacking in a defined sincerity of purpose.  There are pieces of information which cannot bear testimony - the  relationship of Ali Akbar Khan with the Navketan Productions, for one.  There are descriptions - such as the music composer SD Burman being  described as a baul singer - which are downright ridiculous. And, of  course, her command of the Hindi language is unquestionably poor! Surely  the West and the East deserve a better introduction to the Indian cinema  than this book 
       Never before has such a poorly written book received such acclaim. Maya Angelou wrote this story not with candor and grace but with a bias rarely allowed to sit on shelves let alone the top of a best-seller list. She was not humorous but had a heinousness of character and action that places her beyond the limits of human pity. This inspiring author" did not demonstrate poignancy and depth but the crude rudiments of writing skill below that found in the essays of a primary school student.               Maya Angelou has portrayed herself as a victim of fate and yet at best her actions can only be described as foolhardy. In an attempt to prove to herself that she isn't a lesbian (a term she apparently doesn't understand) she initiates a deed without thinking of the consequences. She repeatedly gratifies her ego by exalting her academic accomplishments
column5: yet doesn't grasp the fallacies of her own actions until it is far too late.             Several fans have seen her as an example to women. I must disagree with this ardently. Every teenage girl using her as a role model and demonstrating such lack of forethought puts herself at risk for sexual assualt
column6: neglect
column7: STDs
column8: and teen pregnancy.             My only hope for this book is a quick and discreet cremation. May her name never be mentioned in the same breath as Margaret Atwood or any other great modern writer of either gender
column9: and ANY nationality

column1: I was truly impressed by the utter emptiness of this new novel.  But I have no one else to blame but myself
column2: since I knew nothing about it before shelling out over $24.  I should have been more on guard
column3: but I wasn't.  What I found when I opened the cover and turned the pages was something like a tribute to the cliche
column4: a celebration of lame
column5: flabby banality
column6: a festivel of mediocrity
column7: nicely tarted up as a "brainy cultural commentary" (an actual review quote).  The only brainy thing about this book was the slick con job pulled off by the Knopf marketing department.  They deserve five stars.    The "characters" in this brainy cultural commentary all seem to have stopped growing around the age of 12.  The dialogue is agonizingly weak and it is not resurrected by the use of punctuation oddities or tinkering with the margins.  She ain't no e.e. cummings.  I kept wondering if I had left the television on as I was reading this brainy cultural commentary.  But it was not on
column8: that was the tinny sound of the two dimensional nonentities who populate this book yakking at each other.  This is surely on my top ten list of truly bad novels
column9: up there with The Historian by Whatshername Kostova.  Do yourself a favor and move away from this section of the bookstore with "intelligence and velocity" (another quote from inside the dust jacket.

column1: This is the eleventh or twelvth Pratchett book I've read
column2: and it is by far the worst.  That's somewhat misleading
column3: though
column4: because it's the only bad Pratchett book I've read at all.    I'm not australian
column5: but I did catch on to many of the australian references.  The problem was that most of them weren't funny.  Pratchett's humor has always lain with the insight and subtlety with which he makes his cultural references and satire tie into the situation at hand.  However
column6: in The Last Continent
column7: there is no "situation at hand".  The story rambles on and on
column8: seemingly without point.  People and things come and go without notice or reason
column9: often simply to fit the motif of australian references.  The story of the wizards and the story of Rincewind don't converge until the very last pages of the book
column10: and the convergence is not even explained (how rincewind knows to find the cave and then to draw in it).  The reason for Rincewind's problem is not explained at any stage (why the librarian changes shape
column11: why the wizards' presence in the past is causing the present to shift at random
column12: why it doesn't rain
column13: etc).  The humor that does exist in the book is shallow in nearly every case.  Often it's just inane bickering between the wizards
column14: which elicits cheap laughs
column15: but doesn't grab one's attention.  The humor isn't structured at all
column16: which is Pratchett's normal approach.  In his other books
column17: the humor develops around some reference.  Here they are mostly just one liners.  In The Last Continent
column18: the only time this kind of humor develops is on the topic the wizards' sexual repression
column19: which is entirely unrelated to the story's problem.  I strongly recommend other Pratchett books such as Jingo
column20: Small Gods
column21: or Reaper Man for a much more sophisticated example of fantasy satire

column1: I was eagerly awaiting this release for a few reasons
column2: the main one being that I was anxious to get Edith Massey's "Big Girls Don't Cry" on cd.  Imagine my horror when I queued that track up and realized that that track was mastered from vinyl that's very scratched and not even balanced properly between the channels.  It's either fake stereo or mono with the channel balance off.  Did John Waters (or whoever put the sources together for him) not have a copy of the Rhino "World's Worst Records" album?  If they couldn't find a master tape for this song
column3: at least taking it from the Rhino compilation would have resulted in a reasonable mix.  Some other tracks sound similarly bad for no reason.  Ray Charles' "The Right Time" has been issued on countless cds from master tape but on this cd it's taken from a VERY scratchy 45 rpm record.  Why?  I'm not actually sure that ANY of the songs on this cd were taken from tape
column4: though the scratches are at a minimum on several of the songs.  It seems that someone just sat down with their record collection and transferred a bunch of records to a computer to burn a cd compilation.  I can do that level of quality at home.  Quite honestly I intend to "fix" this compilation for myself by replacing a "needle drop" that I had already done of Edith Massey's track for the one here
column5: replacing the Ray Charles track with a copy ripped from another cd
column6: and perhaps replacing some other tracks (I haven't analyzed the disc enough yet) then then reburning my own compilation.  Then this disc will go back to a used cd store.  I am a HUGE John Waters fan and even waited in line to buy his Christmas compilation cd and get his autograph.  That cd was well done.  This cd is junk.  Shame on John Waters for allowing his name and face to be connected to such a low quality product.  (Yes
column7: I know that his early films featured unlicensed music snippets taken from scratchy records
column8: but that was over 30 years ago when he was poor.

column1: but Ridley devotes too much space regurgitating tired
column2: old
column3: discredited dogmas on both sides of the nature-versus-nurture debate. I think his views are self-evident to many non-specialists
column4: like myself
column5: outside the sociobiolgical fishbowl.     As a physical scientist
column6: I am often disturbed by the (in my opinion) misplaced empiricisms of behavioural/social scientists. For exapmle
column7: in one part of the book
column8: Ridley describes a "remarkable" experiment that found children with a certain high-active gene (MAOA) are "virtually immune" to the detrimental effects of mistreatment by their care-givers
column9: and did not "get into trouble much"
column10: as compared to those with low-active versions of the gene. The implication is that this could become a tool of social policy. The thought of engineers building Jumbo Jets according to principles of gravitation
column11: mechanics
column12: and fluid dynamics that "ought to work a lot of the time" would be a disaster in the making - much like
column13: in my opinion
column14: social policy built along the thinking he outlines. Personally
column15: I would be much more interested in low and high-ative MAOA children who flaunt the conventional conclusions of the study (of which I assume there are some
column16: based on the language). Perhaps it is the exceptions that hold the key.     I'm not saying that physics/math/engineering is superior to the social/behavioural sciences. I think that it is important to know where the fuzzy edges of reductionist-empiricisms lie
column17: and where to draw boundaries around them. I just think that physical scientists
column18: by the nature of their fields
column19: tend to have better tools for drawing and testing these boundaries. Without these boundaries
column20: there seems to be a temptation to take conclusions too far
column21: and be lead astray as a result.

column1: I have been a big Rumpole fan every since the PBS series
column2: and I thought I'd give one of Mortimer's other books a try. If he could strike gold with Horace Rumpole
column3: why not with Lucy Purefoy? Unfortunately
column4: no such luck.  	Lucinda Purefoy is a bishop's daughter recently graduated from college. She takes an advertising job
column5: but something is missing
column6: so she decides to volunteer for an organization called SCRAP
column7: Social Carers
column8: Reformers and Praeceptors
column9: who help former prisoners readjust to society. That's how she meets Terry Keegan who's just done four years for breaking and entering. They fall in love.  	The conflict begins when Terry tries to explain to Lucy why he got into burglary in the first place. "It's not for the money
column10: he says, It's  the excitement." She wants to get closer to Terry so she decides to try it for herself. She begins by shoplifting. When Terry finds out about it
column11: the roles are reversed. Now he's the one trying to get her to go straight.   	When Terry looks down his nose at her trivial efforts
column12: she decides to increase the stakes. There lies the problem with the book. It's just not believable; it reads more like Bridget Jones's Diary than a crime caper. I would imagine Mortimer was trying to lampoon do-gooders here
column13: but Lucy is such a dim bulb that the reader is constantly telling himself
column14: "She can't be serious!"  	The minor characters are worse. Lucy's father the bishop is more liberal than Teddy Kennedy. When he finds out Lucy is sleeping with Terry
column15: he's all for it. Also
column16: when the leader of SCRAP resigns
column17: they solicit Terry's criminal overseer
column18: Chippy McGrath
column19: to take his place. Mr. Markby
column20: Terry's parole officer
column21: is just as clueless. These people just don't measure up to the Rumpole characters. Somebody should have had the courage to tell this to Mr. Mortimer

column1: Dr. Lehman will step on your independent toes and leave them broken and bruised!  I purchased this book just after becoming a first-time mom a few months back. column2: quite frankly
column3: states that I am letting someone else raise my children because I am a working mother.  The entire chapter was full of his own opinions stated as fact and his reminiscing of his own childhood and how one day his mother told him to fix himself a sandwich and he said something to the effect of
column4: "Oh
column5: but it tastes so much better when you make it for me."  At which time she then proceeds to fix him his sandwich.  That's one more man in this world that can't fix his own sandwich!  I
column6: for one

column8: her independence and her sense of self.  To work outside the home
column9: inside the home

My own money which I made - that allowed me to purchase Dr. Lehman's book in the first place

column1: I'm an American

column4: it does have some helpful information that you don't get from the usual Japan guides (such as the difference between uchi and soto)
column5: which is why I gave it 2 stars instead of 1 star.  My complaint is that the author (P. Sean Bramble) doesn't seem to like Japan very much.  The book is extremely negative about the Japanese.  Yes
column6: every culture has some downsides and Japan is no exception
column7: but I found most of the book to be focused on the negative with very little written on the positive.  I didn't realize it until I was 75% through the book and thought
column8: "Why am I going to this awful place again?"  Then it hit me
column9: what a downer this book has been!  I flipped back through what I had read and was surprised to see how much the author focused solely on negative aspects of Japan.  So the problem is that I don't think he presents a realistic view of Japan and the Japanese culture - by overemphasizing the negative
column10: he doesn't present a balanced view.  For example
column11: after you read the health care section (which says doctors suck and pharmacists are a joke and the dentists are awful)
column12: you would think Japan would be the worst place in the world for health care.  That's simply not true - Japanese health care is excellent despite its flaws. Perhaps he was trying to injecting a little reality into the normally too-sunny descriptions of Japanese culture
column13: but he goes too far the other way and in the process loses his ability to describe Japan accurately.  I also question his ability to appreciate the nuances and beauty of Japanese culture -- this quote tells it all:  "When people ask me to explain the real reason I've stayed here all these years
column14: I shrug
column15: scratch my head
column16: and say 'Beer.'

column1: I've really enjoyed the other things that I've read by Franzen (The Corrections; How to Be Alone
column2: a book of essays)
column3: but I found "The Twenty Seventh City" to be nearly unreadable. The only reason that I persevered to the end was that I was stuck on a 6-hour cross-country flight with nothing else to read. As it was
column4: I wound up skimming the last 100 pages.   Two of the biggest problems with this book are an overabundance of minor characters and a very choppy narrative
column5: in which the average scence is about 1 to 2 pages. It's just jump after jump after jump for 500 pages
column6: with no sustained development of anything. I also found the basic premise (a police colonel and cousin of Indira Ghandi from India comes to the US to take over the police force of St. Louis
column7: where she uses a band of Indian terrorists to manipulate the city's business and political elite and control the real estate market) so implausible that it was just a constant stumbling block all though the book. None of the characters struck me as remotely believable or interesting. I suppose it was intended as some sort of farce
column8: but I don't think I encountered a single thing that I thought was humorous. Then there is the dialect... rather than developing distinctive characters
column9: the author writes in truly awful dialect (eg
column10: a character who says things like "Habout time" or "Hanyway"; and of course
column11: a police officer with a lisp).   Altogether
column12: this may be most excruciating piece of fiction writing I've read in the last 5 years.

column1: In the last few years rock music biographies have come of age and many are well researched
column2: full of insight and show a real and objective understanding of the artist in question. Victor Bockris' study of one of the most important icons of the 1960's unfortunately falls far short of what I've come to expect.  The book reads like a lazy retread of thirty years of news clippings and has very little insight into what actually made the Stones become the greatest rock'n'roll band in the world. He's good at knitting together a constant series of quotes and old interviews into a below average narrative but seems to be unable to actually have any real understanding of the people behind the words.  With less than a quarter of the book dedicated to the years when the Stones actually had some validity and almost half of it dedicated to the incredibly tedious 'heroin' years Bockris misses the whole point of why a book about Keith Richards should be written. One unproductive junkie is just like any other and I don't need nearly two hundred repetitive pages to get the message. As another reviewer has rightly pointed out
column3: the author seems to have an unnatural admiration of Keith's heroin addiction and completely fails to comment on the fact that it neatly coincides with the band's rapid creative decline.   I can only hope that the next four hundred page book on one of popular music's most influential guitar players will have three hundred of them covering the period of 1964 to 1971 with the remainder dealing with the following thirty six years when the Rolling Sones simply ceased to have any relevance

What you want to know is how to sell real products and services now.  And most of those authors never sold much in their lives except their books."  The above quote is from the first page of Joe Girard's book "How to Sell Anything to Anybody".  The impression you get is that Joe is a straight shooter and he's going to tell you about real strategies that will really help you sell
column6: not some touchy-feely self-help garbage
column7: and he comes through.  However
column8: the same cannot be said of "How to Sell Yourself".  Now remember the quip about looking in the mirror
column9: he doesn't explicitly ridicule the practice
column10: but it's implied
column11: and it's almost like a joke between you and Joe where he's saying "Yes that's all fine and good for them
column12: but we know better".  So
column13: imagine my surprise when he advocates in his "How to Sell Yourself Book" that you "Put up a little card where you can see it every day
column14: a card that says I am Number One.  Look in the mirror every morning and tell yourself I am my own best salesperson" (pg. 26).  Say it ain't so Joe.  Tell me you didn't just say that.  Tell me you didn't just suggest such a pathetic and ridiculous thing.  Needless to say
column15: I stopped reading the book right there.  If that's the sort of advice you are looking for then maybe this is the book for you
column16: but I was looking for something that wasn't psycho-babble self-help garbage.  Why did I buy the book then?  Because I read Joe's "How to Sell Anything to Anybody" and was sold on his straight shooting

column18: I was disappointed.  It comes across as ungenuine.  The impression is that someone offered Joe a truckload of cash to write another book

column21: I'd definitely recommend Joe's "How to Sell Anything Book" but I can't recommend this book.

column2: especially books at sea.  So I was really looking forward to this book.  I have never read a book more disappointing.  The writing is almost impossible to follow. I believe only once does the author go above board and then only for a brief spell during a storm.  This book is not worth reading.

column1: This book takes the position that increasing technological infrastructure and investing in higher information technology does not increase productivity. The argument is complete hokum from beginning to end; however
column2: it is very convincing due to the large amount of evidence presented and the prestige of the pseudoscientist promulgating it.   Most of the evidence presented exemplifies the post hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy
column3: which should be obvious to any logician or scientist reading it. However
column4: several more subtle fallacies are also present. The subtlety comes in by virtue of the author failing to define `productivity.'  First
column5: the author measures productivity using GDP. This is analogous to using the physics definition of work when you ask a man who's spent all day trying to tip over a mountain
column6: "Why are you so tired? The mountain hasn't moved
column7: therefore you haven't done any work!" GDP is a measure of output in terms of dollars. It does not measure work done
column8: just how much was sold.   Second
column9: the author uses return on assets to analyze investments in new equipment. Now
column10: I'm no expert in finance
column11: but since assets is in the denominator
column12: using ROA in the way this author does (the ROA of the firm
column13: not the investment decision) would systematically understate the positive effects of these investments. Net Present Value or Internal Rate of Return would both be much better measures.  Third
column14: and this is related to the second point
column15: the author compares firms to what they were in the past (before investing in technology) or to other
column16: dissimilar firms. The relevant comparison is between a firm's current profitability and what the current profitability would have been if not for the investment. The common form of this reasoning is: XYZ Corp. made a huge technological investment in 1986
column17: and experienced no rise in productivity (as measured by ROA). This ignores the possibility that the whole industry became more competitive
column18: and failing to invest in the technology could have led to bankruptcy.   In a related issue
column19: he completely ignores rising standards. His argument is equivalent to
column20: Finding Nemo did not make significantly more money than The Lion King. Therefore
column21: enhanced technology did not increase productivity. This is incorrect because productivity is a measure of work done over time
column22: not money made. If animators tried to make a film with the graphics quality of Finding Nemo by hand
column23: it would have taken several orders of magnitude longer
column24: if it was even possible! The fact is
column25: the animators
column26: like so many workers in society
column27: get far more done today than they used to
column28: they just don't get paid anymore to do it
column29: which is actually an argument for the value of technology.  I gave up on it shortly thereafter

column1: To begin with humans
column2: as a species
column3: are not very variable genetically. Of this small genetic variation
column4: only a small proportion is correlated with the geographical distribution of human social groups. This geographically conditioned genetic variation
column5: small though it is
column6: can nevertheless help in the reconstruction of human history as long as it is used to supplement large amounts of reliable information from the social sciences: social and cultural anthropology
column7: history
column8: archeology
column9: and linguistics.   One thing that geographically conditioned genetic variation cannot help with is in explaining the evolution of cultural and social institutions within human groups. Social scientists discovered this a century ago when they observed that genetically very similar groups can show enormous cultural and social differences while groups that are relatively different genetically can be socially and culturally alike. Unfortunately
column10: the authors of this book are not aware of this. As geneticists who know little social science they look for genetic explanations where these do not exist.  The author's ignorance of social science also leads them to miss an important story. Although
column11: the genetic differences between human groups are relatively insignificant in themselves
column12: humans have
column13: at times
column14: attached a great deal of importance to them. One product of this socially and culturally conditioned exaggeration of the importance of genetic differences has been racism. Unfortunately
column15: the author's ignorance of social science seems to have rendered them unconscious of their own racial prejudices.   Readers interested in human diversity can find a number of good books on this subject. This is not one of them

I gave this  2 stars with the thought that someone who is so out of the loop and a danger to their child may read this book-at least could adopt some common sense.  But it isn't helping my family.

column1: The Scientific Method applied to this book:  1) Form a hypothesis:  Great managers do something differently than mediocre managers. 2) Conduct an experiment:  Interview 80

 Is it really my failure
column12: or theirs?"  Carol Kennicott asks herself this question nearly 250 pages into "Main Street
column13: regarding her impossible relations with the residents of  the town of Gopher Prairie, Minnesota. By this time, I was asking a similar question: Is it really my failure
column14: or Sinclair Lewis's?"  "Main Street" seemed a good idea as it sat on my shelf. Touted as a satirical look at middle-class America
column15: it was Lewis's first successful novel
column16: ushering in a new era upon its publication in 1920
column17: and breaking critical ground for the Golden Age of American Literature
column18: of Hemingway
column19: Fitzgerald
column20: and Faulkner. Lewis was the first American to win the Nobel Prize for Literature. How could I go wrong picking it up?  The book tells the interminable story of Mrs. Kennicott
column21: who marries a country doctor while imagining herself an improving influence on his as-yet-unseen town of Gopher Prairie. Imagine her surprise when she is greeted not as a liberator but grist for the gossip mill
column22: with her Big City ideas and lack of churchiness.  Carol's alternating turns of resistance and acceptance are about the sum total of this plotless book. Lewis's descriptive powers are much in evidence
column23: and you find yourself trapped in G.P. as much as Carol

column25: when you get past the period slang and the barbed commentary

column1: This book is not LaVey's best. The best thing about it is the humour that LaVey manages to weave into his writing -- at times it can get a bit childish
column2: but at it's best
column3: the irreverance can be quite amusing.  Unfortunately
column4: it doesn't really reddem the book
column5: as it seems quite obvious  that he has nothing to say here. LaVey seems much bitterer and full of  himself in a rather narcissistic way than he was earlier in his life and  this lack of perspective makes him seem sort of absurd. In this collection  of essays
column6: LaVey is indulging himself -- but it is largely the indulgence  of a two year old throwing a temper tantrum rather than the indulgence of  the artist
column7: which was the ideal that he had in mind when he wrote the  Satanic Bible. There are essays about playing dumb jokes on people
column8: on how  much he hates everyone
column9: and so on. But there are some gems here. His  aphorisms are worse than useless
column10: but ideas of the "Law of the  Trapezoid" are interesting
column11: as are his sharing of his musical tastes  with everyone (and rather good taste it is!). He shares his interest of the  odd and unusual
column12: inlcuding several little-known but interesting people and  the rip-roaring humour of "Hatha Toilet Seat meditation". Still
column13: these little snippets are not quite enough to redeem this volume and the  foreward by Kenneth Anger certainly adds nothing to the book (he mentions  that lamentable fact that the popular media had chosen to ignore LaVey --  but does not mention that LaVey has plagiarised so much of his  "work" that he has got basically what he deserved). The sheet  music for the "Battle Hymn of the Republic" is included
column14: as well  as various original musings which really aren't worth anyone's time except  for the most enthusiastic LaVey worshipper. If your library has it
column15: it  might be worth a read
column16: but it's not worth the price. If you want laVey at  the height of his powers
column17: check out the Satanic Bible; this is just the  rantings of a bitter old man

column1: The Panasonic is very compact
column2: very stylish SEXY as my wife called it
column3: but the photos are very disappointing: they are way to noisy! Even if set on the lowest ASA setting at 80ASA it is just barely acceptable and they do get progressively worse anything above 100ASA.  The colours are good
column4: and it does take very good videos
column5: but still photos are just plain bad when compared to other cameras in Photoshop CS2. Of course it is easy to understand why: the native resolution of the images. If one investigates such things
column6: will notice that the Panasonic is only 72 dpi
column7: same as Sony's
column8: Canon improves this to 180
column9: and Nikon is at 300 dpi. It is not just about megapixels folks
column10: but how those megapixels are recorded and at what resolution. Obviously a camera with 72 dpi will have more noise than one at 180 or 300 dpi.   So before you buy any digital camera or thinking about upgrading to a newer model
column11: do yourself a favour. Try 4 or 5 cameras in the same megapixel range at a good camera store by taking photos of the same subject in the same light condition. Set the camera for the lowest ASA and the highest picture quality in JPG format
column12: take the photos
column13: pop the SD card  into the computer
column14: compare the images in Photoshop. Enlarge to full pixel size (100%)
column15: and and look at the meta data at the same time and you will see for yourself. That is what I did
column16: since I was not very happy with the images my Panasonic produced! I had this camera for 11 months and 20 days exactly
column17: and today I traded it in on a Nikon P5000 after evaluating over a dozen models including the Leica D-lux3 10MP camera
column18: and driving the sales persons crazy with all the testing and spending 4 hours at the store
column19: but it was very educational for them too

column1: Aslam's core story is fascinating - a culture clash that leads to the deaths of three people
column2: and the collapse of a family. However
column3: I found the book difficult to read for two reasons. The first was the visceral hatred thrown up on nearly every page towards Islam and the beliefs and attitudes held by first-generation Pakistani immigrants. Some of these beliefs are indefensible (such as honour killings and the fatal exorcism that appears in a subplot) but Aslam's seeming hatred of this culture - one he grew up in; he's the son of a Pakistani political exile - and Islam poisons any argument he was trying to make and makes this book a piece of anti-Islam and anti-Pakistani propaganda. The second difficulty with this book comes from Aslam's incredibly pretentious prose style (such as describing segments of an orange on a plate as "dolphins leaping over ocean waves"). Linked in with this is his failed stab at introducing magical realism (men with glowing hands and blood
column4: peacocks and parakeets
column5: fireflies becoming ghosts
column6: men with golden hair)
column7: into the mix. The story that Aslam is trying to tell is the only reason why I have given this book two stars. If that hadn't been interesting
column8: it would have just managed one. The difficulties Pakistani immigrants are facing in the UK
column9: and elsewhere in the world
column10: is a matter that deserves investigating and exploring in literature. But there are much better novels that explore these problems - Brick Lane by Monica Ali and Hanif Kureishi's excellent Buddha of Suburbia

column7: this book is a long way from being readable or being helpful in a course in micro

column1: I have nothing but respect for someone who learns enough art and enough physics to write a proper book on the topic.  Unfortunately
column2: this author has not done so.  Put simply
column3: this text contain information that is downright misleading.  Physics can be quite difficult
column4: especially if one is trying to understand the esoteric worlds of relativity and modern (quantum) physics.  That said
column5: there is no excuse for misleading a reader
column6: when an educated layman's understanding of physics would reveal correct and useful information.  Dr Shlain states several things that would mislead a lay reader.  For example
column7: his understanding of the way lights add is just plain wrong.  This might not harm a painter
column8: but would harm a digital artist or someone building light sculptures.  Were said painter to think that their flawed understanding was supported by relativity
column9: they would resist learning how lights differ from pigments
column10: making it very hard to move to interior design or other light-based domains.  This complete failure to get the physics even close to correct makes me worry about the art history.  Again
column11: he does not have to be an expert
column12: but proper due diligence would suggest sending the drafts to a working art historian and a working physicist to get their feedback before inficting it on the general public.  Again
column13: I am not claiming that one needs graduate level work to write such a book.  I do claim that one should have at least an educated layman's exposure to the feilds before taking pen in hand

column1: Vincent Mosco's book is a fair introduction to political economy
column2: yet the author fails to state that he comes from a very particular approach of political economy
column3: namely the Marxist (some would call it neo-Marxist). As regards Mosco's boundary work towards cultural studies
column4: I agree that the divide between political economy and cultural studies can be seen as `labour analysis' versus `cultural analysis'
column5: and further in terms of structural versus interactionist methodologies. However
column6: I wish to reject Mosco's description of political economy as the theoretical `middle way'. Political economy does not stand out as the reconciling discipline between cultural studies and other disciplines (notably policy studies) for a number of reasons. On the most fundamental level
column7: political economy continues to suffer from the tendency to induct all analysis to class alone
column8: despite political economists' claim that their discipline no longer is aquainted with economism and reductionism. This is in my opinion the greatest weakness of Mosco's text. Also
column9: there is little new to the book
column10: although the author claims to be doing rethinking and renewal

column6: so they looked all pretty and still alive
column7: but still

column9: but still thought it was rather a waste of my time.

column1: I found this book to be hard to read.  Take the chapter headings: who is the toddler
column2: the challenges of being a toddler
column3: the question of temperament...  Can you tell exactly are these about?  I can't.  Compare this with Your Two Year Old by Gesell Institute - chapters are: general characteristics of the age
column4: the child with other children
column5: techniques
column6: accomplishments and abilities... The chapter headings indicate to me a much clearer organization.  If I want to know what is an age appropriate skill
column7: I go to the accomplishments section
column8: if I want to know how to manage a behavioral concern
column9: I go to techniques.  The Lieberman book also uses bold face to describe some allegedly actual scenes
column10: and it describes several in a row in unnecessary detail without directly commenting on any of them.  When it does offer advice
column11: it is often in the form of oblique truisms
column12: instead of simple suggestions.  It just seems like a waste of words. You can infer from the truisms what she thinks is a good way to handle certain situations
column13: but she doesn't make it easy to find.  The Gesell book is more likely to give very concise explanations of possible behaviors
column14: reasons for the behaviors
column15: and good ways to manage them.    I found the Gesell book much more interesting reading because it is clearly written
column16: and also much more useful as a reference because it is well organized.

column1: I should have read the back cover more closely before buying Mirabai Starr's translation of the Interior Castle.  To her credit
column2: she admits to her butchery of the text.  As cited by other reviewers
column3: she provides a list of the words that she changed; Lord to Beloved
column4: devil to "spirit of evil
column5: sin with missing the mark
column6: etc.  However, all her semantics serve to do is to force the reverse translation by the reader, and it grew quickly tiresome to mentally exchange Lord" for every instance of "Beloved."  Not to mention the sneaking suspicion that Ms. Starr had monkeyed with the text to a greater extent than she admits.  But
column7: again
column8: you have to admire Ms Starr's honesty in her statement that "[Teresa] would have approved of my boldness
column9: if not the results."  This amounts to an admission by Ms Starr that her modifications substantially change the meaning of Teresa's text.  Despite all the linguistic hijinks
column10: Starr's translation of the Interior Castle is not "Free of Dogma" as is its claim.  The concept of the soul is dogma.  The redemptive suffering of Christ is dogma.  Teresa's  patterns of prayer and life are rooted in dogma.  To attempt to pen a "dogma-free Interior Castle" is like attempting to write a "math-free Calculus".  What the attempt to "free Teresa from the cage of Christianity" reveals is a complete denial of Teresa's life and devotion.  Whatever pressures Teresa may have felt at the hands of the inquisitors and the Church heirarchy
column11: Teresa was voluntarily a Carmelite and she deeply believed in all sorts of inconvenient things.  Teresa cannot be separated from Christianity - nor can she be separated from Catholicism.  In the end
column12: far from being dogma-free and modernized
column13: Starr's interpretation of Teresa's Interior Castle is simply castrated
column14: lobotomized
column15: sterile
column16: and confused

column5: Molly is sure that it's a case of murder -- even if the police have decided that George-Stanley death was an accident. Determined to make her case

column9: Molly Appleby

column1: I was actually glad to read all of the low reviews because I felt like a traitor when I didn't like this book.  I wanted to like it

column3: I didn't like Royd (Royd - are you kidding?  Perhaps the author should invest in a baby name book - there are much better choices for names out there.).  I wasn't interested in the direction the book went.    I thought the action scenes were ridiculous compared to the every day scenes.  If Sophie could pull off the every day scenes like she did the action scenes we wouldn't have had such a boring book.  She was da bomb during breaking and entering and getting away but she was pathetic at any other time.  Royd was so very unlikeable I couldn't believe they ended up in bed together.  Ick.  Adding Jane into the book was very contrived.  Plain old artist Jane and her cop stepfather Joe saved the boy from a ruthless trained killer?  It seemed like a ploy to connect Eve Duncan with this book.  Not at all believable.  The one sentence that I found interesting was when Michael thought that Jane resembled or looked like someone familiar.  It seemed to be a lead in to the next book.  The first IJ book I ever read was Ugly Duckling.  Hopefully IJ re-reads that one before starting the next one.  Give us a strong heroine who overcomes her trauma and kicks [...].

column1: As to the best of my knowledge
column2: there were two major intellectual responses to the seemingly endless and insuperable crisis which the capitalist system had got itself into after the Great Slump of 1929: Keynes`s "General Theory of Money
column3: Interest and Employment" of 1936 and Schumpeter`s "Capitalism" which was first published in 1942. Like Marx before them
column4: both Keynes and Schumpeter reject the "classic economists'" contention that what they called the market system wll always automatically swing back to an ideal equilibrium - expecially one that implied full employment - provided only the state kept its hands off as much as possible.   However
column5: that is just about where their concurrence ends. While Marx sees the only solution outside the system
column6: in its bloody overthrow and its succession by a "dictatorship of the proletariat" introducing the next evolutionary step in human history
column7: called socialism
column8: Keynes considered the market system as basically viable. All that was needed
column9: according to him
column10: was governmental involvement by which the lacking demand in times of a slump would be lifted to more agreeable levels. Schumpeter
column11: in contrast
column12: agrees with Marx in that capitalism's days are counted and that it is about to be replaced by socialism
column13: even though he doesn't share Marx`s more aggressive notions: according to him
column14: the present day capitalists need not be dealt with by the guillotine alone
column15: they may indeed have a useful function as entrepreneurs employed by his envisaged omnipotent and omniscient super agency that will ideally plan everybody's well-being in his imagined socialist system.  What to think of the book today? First
column16: it is hard to fathom how Schumpeter could have turned such an absolutely blind eye on the totalitarian tendencies necessarily inherent in a state that not only controlled the political field but also was quasi the monopolist employer and as such responsible for the economic side of peoples's lives as well
column17: in particular when one considers the time when it came out: 1942! Second
column18: it is a fine example of how wrong you can get things even if (or: because?) you know so much as Schumpeter did - maybe that is the best argument of all against the establishment of such a super agency planning everybody's life to the extent envisaged by Schumpeter. Finally
column19: even if such an agency did not err - is it not a basic right - and half of the fun of life - to make mistakes - for oneself that is
column20: not forcing them on others
