column1: If the demented 13-year-old offspring of the unholy union between David Lynch and William S. Burroughs were given pen and paper and told to write a trippy story splattered (and I don't choose that word lightly) with blood
column2: gore
column3: zombies and sex
column4: Baby Jesus Butt Plug is what you'd get.  Unfortunately the outcome will still suffer from the story telling of a hormone laden 13-year-old boy.  To illustrate
column5: imagine a depraved pre-pube making up a wild sex-fi story on the fly
column6: while his wide-eyed buddies eat up his every absurd word.  It's stream-of-consciousness story telling with all manner of shock and awe thrown in for effect.  On the other hand
column7: the beginning and end of the story contain flashes of satirical brilliance
column8: biting humor and quirky sci-fi-esque fun to offset the crude writing and story line.  One passage that I found particularly clever and amusing is when the narrator talks of getting a free Baby Jesus Butt Plug from a couple who just want to make sure the BJBP goes to a good home.  He says
column9: "And when they said `a good home' all they really meant was they didn't want to give them to anyone who would stick them in their butts".  I wish Mellick had pursued the socio-religious angle of owning a BJBP that began to take form in the first third of the book.  Or he could have explored the conundrum of losing oneself physically and mentally in a sea of one's own clones.  Either way would have made for a much more powerful and coherent statement.  As it stands
column10: the story begins to provoke and stimulate but quickly deteriorates into a menage-a-bizarre story of teen male angst
column11: desire and fear.  I've read other Mellick works and know that in a lengthier format he can make you blush
column12: throw-up and ponder in the matter of one short paragraph.  So I am comfortable in saying that this is not his best.  However
column13: if you want a unique insight into the stuff of which adolescent boys wet dreams are made
column14: then Baby Jesus Butt Plug will take you there.

column1: The concept of "Rumspringa
column2: in which some of the world's most conservative people run wilder than most of us ever do, is fascinating.  Then why is _Devil's Playground_ so boring?  The beginning is amazing, when we get our first glimpse at the debauchery of an Amish youth party.    The rest of the film, unfortunately, is pure tedium, as the filmmakers focus on a few kids who stray rather far into drugs and other vices, but who just aren't very interesting.    One in particular, a crystal meth dealer and user, gets endless attention, and we just see him ramble about nothing much for minute after minute.  The fact that he was formerly Amish does not make his pathetic life much more interesting than that of the next white trash loser.  Another Amish drop-out is a girl who appears to have serious emotional problems and who decides to go to college.  That is all I learned about her in the movie, and it could have been conveyed in about 30 to 60 seconds.  Instead, the director goes back to the girl again and again to pad out the film's running time, even though she has nothing additional to tell us.  Meanwhile, we are not given much context for any of this.  Do most Amish kids stray this far before coming back?  Do some not stray at all?  Do the adults really just sit idly by for all of it?  After seeing this movie, I have no idea--I just know about a few kids who fell pretty far from the tree, and who aren't very interesting in themselves.  It seems many of the Amish shown here do not reflect typical Amish/Mennonite ethnic traits, which goes unexplained.  It is also clear that some of the Amish people we see, including the adults who allowed themselves to be interviewed on camera, are from substantially different Amish sects.  So does this stuff go on among all the Amish, or just in some weird group of Amish, or what?  The film never explains.    Other things irritate, such as use of the same soundtrack music over and over.  Why the filmmaker thought the electronic music of Aphex Twin was the best choice to represent the unplugged" world of the Amish
column3: I don't know.    The footage in this film could have been used to make an interesting 15-minute news magazine segment.  It does not work as a (barely) feature length documentary

column1: Sometimes a title says it all
column2: and Madam Secretary is essentially the sum and substance of Albright's claim to fame. She was the first woman Secretary of State and probably one of the worst Secretaries of any department in any era. Admittedly she worked for a morally bankrupt man who governed based upon what the polling data showed
column3: but this book reveals that the ship of State was rudderless and without a compass.  If the titles "Clueless" and "Sleepwalking through History" weren't already taken
column4: they would have been much more apt descriptions of Albright's tenure in such serious posts as Secretary of State or Ambassador to the UN. The initial chapters were interesting in her personal history as her family moved from Czechoslovakia and to the USA
column5: but it was all downhill after that.  I kept turning hundreds of pages looking for some substance or recognition of her true impact on world events but couldn't find any. Her refusal to be "baited" at the UN and defending the USA by rabid haters of the USA and instead making jokes about how it made her feel "young again" was telling. She glosses over the North Korean violation of the "framework" negotiated between the new Clinton Administration in 1993 and 1994 by the peanut farmer and never acknowledges that this "framework" was violated by the North Koreans from day one
column6: but somehow blames the Bush Administration for calling an end to this charade by revealing the fact that the North Koreans never lived up to their commitments. The bombings by al Qaeda of the US Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania the year that Osama declared war on Western Civilization? No connection that she had anything to do with it or the impact of the US tepid response. What about Clinton hiding behind her skirt and sending her out to defend him when he lied to her and the nation about Monica? It was all Ken Starr's fault. Arafat lying through his teeth about Palestinian terrorism and using the White House as his platform? Not a problem. Rwanda and the greatest genocide in modern history since Pol Pot as hundreds of thousands of Tutsi's were hacked to death? Boys will be boys
column7: and besides
column8: the UN didn't want to get involved. Any thought about how Saddam built billions of dollars of palaces under the Oil for Food program that she supported? An audit program? What and upset the French who were collecting the billions involved in the program thru Paris banks?. Mon Dieu!!  This book is much more spin than substance
column9: but I actually think that she doesn't recognize the difference. If you want to know why we were so highly thought of by the enemies of freedom
column10: you can read all about it here. We were very
column11: very nice when we should have been very
column12: very determined. If you want to know just how the world became such a dangerous place on her watch
column13: you might be better off saving the dollar I paid for this book and asking some wino on a park bench. Most have them have a better understanding of the real world. The Freudian analysis of this book's title is that she may have been the biggest Madam in Foggy Bottom while she was in charge of the house located there called the State Department. The problem is that she is probably unaware of the fact that it may not necessarily be a compliment.

I had a few friends whom stated they wished to read this book when I was done and I told every single one of them that it isn't worth their time. I'll tell you the same. There are plenty of books out on this subject that give you a real sense of what happned and the evil people whom were responsible.  I was really hoping this book was going to live up to expectations but sadly it did not

column1: The trouble with Alistair Horne's "Seven Ages of Paris" is the set of expectations it raises and then fails to deliver upon. Naturally
column2: when picking up a history of a given city
column3: I expect to get a narrative that concentrates on the subject. But too much of this book is taken up by generalized history of the French nation
column4: with only incidental discussion of the impact of wider events on the capital. Admittedly
column5: France has become such a centralized nation in recent centuries that it is tempting to take country and city as intimately intertwined. Yet I'm not sure this was always true.  The book is also oddly stingy with illustrations and maps. The growth of Paris would seem to present all sorts of opportunities for vivid illustration (check out the Musee Carnavalet in the Marais for several hundred candidates for inclusion)
column6: but all we get here is a few sparse city maps and a few pages of glossy pictures

column1: We have had the LeapPad Plus Writing for a couple of years now.  When it works it is great my kids love it.  The Durabily is awful!  We are now on our 5th or 6th pen for it.  This must be a problem for most of them since the last time I called the company they autimatically stated on one of the phone options that you can get up to 2 free pens for it (with the cost of $5 s/h for each pen -another $10 bucks down the drain when it actually only costs them probably a $1 to ship by mail.)  The pen is so sensitive sometimes it seems to work ok then others like on the bones of the body- you can touch on the bone and it will give you the wrong answer.  The books are a lot of fun and educational but we paid $80 for this when it first came out and we own probably 7 book ($15 average per book)and if the Leap Pad isn't working the books are a waste).  The last time I used this with my son and it started off working fine then all of a sudden the pen wouldn't recognize anything.  I called the Co. and they told me they would give me 1/2 off a new Leap Pad plus Writing book.  I thought that was kind of stupid considering I already have one that obviously isn't working and wouldn't spend money on getting a new one that will have the same problems.  They suggest when having problems with the pen to clean the prongs with alcohol - this has never worked for me.   It might be okay to buy if the pen wasn't attached to the book because it seems every little tug you need a new pen.  I am debating on getting the new Leapster L-max
column2: but am worried that it will also have problems.  Very disappointed in the LeapPad Plus Writing

column1: Admission to America's elite colleges is an increasingly trying affair. An academically strong
column2: middle class high school senior with no particular claim on a space
column3: "un-hooked" as it is known
column4: is faced with increasingly long odds of acceptance. The "un-hooked" applicant is squeezed by a dynamic made from increasing applications as more high school seniors go on to college and the colleges' own efforts to expand the applicant pool through increasing financial aid as well as recruiting international students even as they hold the number of places in freshman classes unchanged.  In this environment it is hardly a challenge to find a really sharp kid who was not accepted and also to find some "hooked" applicant who seemed rather less than qualified who was accepted. Venting on this situation provides a good release.   Golden vents well
column5: but is unfortunately short on substance. Lacking quantitative data
column6: the scope and scale of the matter escape Golden.   More importantly
column7: Golden does not attempt to address what seems to be the most pressing question: What do we expect of these elite institutions? Do we require that they be social engineers? If yes
column8: to what degree? Failing  an attempt to answer this question "The Price of Admission" is reduced to a voice only of frustration and angst.  For a more thought provoking read
column9: see Harry Lewis's "Excellence Without a Soul". Lewis is not specifically concerened with admissions
column10: as GOlden is
column11: but Lewis is very much interested in the question of what an education at one of these elite institutions should be.

column1: They spend the first half of this movie saying how great the Ultimate Warrior was.  The journey is awesome!  Then all of the sudden
column2: the paid WWE guys just began to bad-mouth the Warrior. Maybe he did have questionable judgment - but why are they trying to make us feel bad about someone we loved? column3: and I really can't distinguish one's ability from the other. They just all gang up on him and make outragious allegations. Vince says quickly that the reason why the Ultimate disappeared for 3 years was because he failed a drug test. As soon as he says this
column4: they fade to black then come back with a new issue. What drug use? Which drugs? Presumably they're talking about steroids. But what about that high and mighty Hulk Hogan with his admitted drug use. Let's not talk about that - let's just keep ganging up on the Warrior. They completely ridicule him changing his name to the Warrior. And they also just try to badmouth him so much. Who cares that none of the wrestlers liked him? I don't! He excited the heck out of me way more than any of the dorks who say bad things about him -including Hulk. And oh yeah - they don't even let the Warrior defend himself.  Why did I have to find out from IMDB.com that he was asked to appear but declined? Why don't they address this?  This "docu" is more slanted than "Fahrenheitt 911" Every wrestling and Ultimate Warrior fan will start out loving this docu then hating it. It just leaves you with a bitter taste in your mouth

column1: I don't understand why there is still a debate over whether or not DID/MPD exists.  It does.  And the experts/professionals have concluded so since they included in the DSM and since insurance companies fork over the money to treat it.  Since I have been diagnosed with it I was curious to hear what people have to say about why they think it doesn't exist.  That's why I was considering this book
column2: but after reading the reviews I decided against it.  Here's why:  If you're going write a book debunking a legitimate diagnosis that is included in the current DSM
column3: you should at least back it up with more than emotional backlash.  With the current findings from research (and from those who treat dissociative disorders) it is believed that DID/MPD CANNOT be realistically faked today.  Those who are trained in treating it can not only recognize when it is faked
column4: but prove when it exists by doing some kind of special MRI (I'm not a dr. so I don't know what it's called).  Anyway
column5: the condition exists.  I wouldn't recommend reading any book debunking it unless they can back it up with more convincing evidence than what is shown for it's existance (which you won't find btw)

column7: parentheses

column12: maybe to another sub-sub-story and back to the sub-story

column1: This 600+ page endeavor in tedium has quite a few clever and witty observations about the current state of media
column2: technology
column3: etc.
column4: but is undone by the author's endless tone of self-congratulation and his complete inability to MOVE THE STORY ALONG. For a story intending to portray life in the modern fast lane

column1: Everyone else seems to adore this book so I guess I have lost my sense of humor because I just don't like this particular version-- at least not for the 3 and under set.    My first objection stems from the use of bug spray by the 'old lady' to get rid of the fly.  She is shown sitting on a couch surrounded by cans of depleted insecticide while spraying more in her mouth.  Rather than find this funny
column2: it scared me to think that some child might get a notion to copy this activity.    Then second is my objection to boiling a cat and chasing a dog with the same intent.  Now most children wouldn't do this so that's not a problem but I still don't like the idea of introducing this weird concept to my little boy.  (My son asked me if we needed to keep our cat inside and safe from the neighbors - hmmm.)  The funny part of all of this is that I don't mind when the old lady just pops the animals down her throat.  Go figure.  In any case
column3: Nadine Westcott is a good story teller and her artwork is clever
column4: but I still have to give this book two stars because of the above reservations.          [A `Thought You Should Know' review

column1: The oral history approach by Ambrose & Co offers certainly has its attraction. And if this book would have consisted of personal accounts of D-Day veterans only
column2: I think it would have made a valuable
column3: insightful
column4: and memorable account of this landmark battle.   Unfortunately
column5: the author did not leave it at that but felt the need to present his own
column6: highly biased and overly patriottic views on the various aspects of the battle. The message that is spelled out again and again
column7: in capitals
column8: is that only the American troops and their commanders showed excellence in planning and carrying out the battle. Their allies
column9: in particular the British
column10: receive considerably less credit or even scorn. For example
column11: the book ridicules the supposed British craze for "gadgets"
column12: such as their mini-submarines and special tanks
column13: which they nonetheless used very effectively on D-day.   But what really annoys me is the personal "battle" that Ambrose seems to be fighting with the long-beaten German foe: all the decisions they took on D-day were wrong in his opinion
column14: they responded way too late or not at all
column15: they failed to foresee the invasion
column16: their command structure was inadequate
column17: their navy did not intercept the fleet "which nobody could understand"
column18: etc. etc. The truth is that by june 1944 the Germans simply did not have the resources to fight an agressive and intelligent counter-battle on the Western front anymore. I find it disappointing
column19: a little cheap and certainly inappropriate for a scholarly historian to keep on criticizing the past performance of an enemy with the comforts of hindsight and imaginary resources. (Even more so as the included number of German combattants' accounts in this book is less than a handful.)   By the end of this book
column20: I was thoroughly fed up with the hollow rhetorics and "easy" truths like "The Wehrmacht's many mistakes [on D-day] were exceeded by those of the Luftwaffe
column21: which was quite simply just not there" (ch 32). Perhaps this style is what it takes to write a bestseller
column22: but "D Day: June 6
column23: 1944" fails as a military history book.

column2: for example

column7: full of compassion.  Unfortunately his wonderful intentions are sorely misguided.

column3: superficial
column4: fawning
column5: etc.
column6: etc.  This book is about the 2002 U.S. Open Golf Championship at the Bethpage Black Golf Course
column7: a New York State Park course on Long Island.  The subtitle
column8: "Inside the Ropes at Bethpage Black
column9: is used here as a figure of speech, meaning behind the scenes."  ("Inside the ropes" is normally used in the context of a professional golf tournament to refer to the actual playing area itself -- spectators are separated from the golfers
column10: caddies
column11: officials
column12: and other chosen few by thin ropes that tell the spectators how close they can get to the action.)  Feinstein's purpose is to give the reader a look at the unfolding of a golf tournament from its conception to its completion.  We see U.S Golf Association (the organization that conducts the tournament) leaders in action and learn something about the logistics of putting on a golf tournament (e.g.
column14: 850 people willing to volunteer their time so that the professional golfers and U.S.G.A. can have a huge payday)
column15: about random qualifiers and random competitors
column16: and about the resurrection of the Black golf course.  Yet the book does not fulfill its promise.  My guess is that Feinstein's indebted to too many golf people for both his past and anticipated future lifestyle to offer the kind of critical insights and analysis I had hoped for

column1: This book is perpetuating false facts about Reiki and its history. Hayashi did not charge $10
column2: 000 for master level training as this book claims. And certainly Usui did not charge anywhere near $10
column3: 000 as the book is  suggesting. This book also states that Usui was a Christian monk
column4: when in  fact he was Buddhist. Another false fact presented in this book is that  Hayashi was Usui's successor
column5: when we know through research it was Ushida.  The society that Usui founded in 1922 still exists today in Japan and is  called Usui Shiki Reiki Ryoho. Ushida was the second president of this  organization after Usui made his transition. I recommend the book Reiki  Fire for those interested in the true and verifiable history of Reiki or  contact the Usui Shiki Reiki Ryoho society in Japan. These are only a FEW  examples of the incorrect information this book is presenting about Reiki  and its history

column1: I will never buy a brand new product release from Linksys again. Their Q.C. stinks. I am on the third WRT54GX4 router and it is the first that was not defective. I got it set up and tried my new WPC54GX4 network card(SRX400) and got a weak signal
column2: but I had my second laptop with a WPC54GX card(SRX200) on the desk getting 100% signal strength. I switched cards in the two computers
column3: and the old SRX200 card was better in either computer(both XP Pro). After hours with semi-English speaking techs
column4: they came to the same conclusion I came to in five minutes...a bad antenna in the new WPC54GX4. So once again Amazon will replace a defective Linksys product for me. I had been a Linksys fan in the past
column5: but not any more. Here's a link to a picture of the first router I got and its defect.  http://vowe.net/archives/006639.htm

column1: "Wise Blood" could more aptly be called "Stupid Minds."  Both titles are tendentious
column2: but the latter is more accurate.  Ms. O'Connor depicts a pair of Southern troglodytes in the grip of religious mania.  We are meant to regard their fanaticism as a form of primal wisdom; in fact
column3: it is merely ludicrous or pathetic.  Those who deem this judgment parochial should ask themselves whether Ms. O'Connor
column4: an Orthodox Roman Catholic
column5: was any less so.   Faulkner plumbed the humanity within or beneath the grotesque.  Ms. O'Connor is more interested in the God-driven grotesqueness that warps humanity; she sees it as higher knowledge.  Her prose in this early effort is merely workmanlike
column6: and time has made what was strange or shocking in her vision seem familiar.  If blood wisdom were truly wisdom
column7: an Islamic terrorist would be wise

I also found myself thinking aloud "i don't want to read this anymore" many times throughout the meanderings in this book.  I'm not exaggerating
column9: nothing happens in the 600 pages I've read.    Not to mention the number of plot holes I've encountered.  It's baffling. I really regret reading this series.  For example
column10: Molly encounters old men who recognize her as the bastard's woman
column11: yet Regal can still not find her!  Okay!     It started off decent with the first book.  It was a good intro and I was excited to start the 2nd book.  After 500 pages in that book with nothing happening

column13: she insists on switching the subject with the negative ala "Can not you.." or "Should not you.."  Then she switches back to regular American dialogue.  She isnt' consistent with it either.  It's awkward at best.  Each and every single female character has to be sassy and always try to take charge.  God forbid she portrays a female that's not 'equal' to men or appears weak!  Her villains are laughable.    We know nothing of more of the red ships or Regal
column14: or the forged ones by 500 pages into the third book than we did 50 pages into book one.  It's astounding how she can concentrate so much on Fitz
column15: who never really grows anyway
column16: and leave all the other characters to a single dimensional fate.  Regal is the embodiment of evil and that's good enough for you!  I really want to stop reading this book even now at 600 pages into it because I know the ending is going to be terrible
column17: yet I am compelled to finish it because I've invested so much time into it...  Read this book at your own risk

column1: Whether or not you like this collection of essays will depend on your definition of travel writing. D.Cooper's "Canadian Gothic"
column2: J.McPhee's "A Fleet of One" and B.Donahue's "Under the Sheltering Sky" are all excellent. However many of the pieces chosen are little more than self-indulgent fluff. Was 2004 such a mediocre year for travel writing? M.Byers "Monuments to Our Better Nature" and R.Chevat's incoherent "Screenwriters Vacation" and M.Gorra's "Innocents Abroad?" are hardly memorable.  As another review has pointed out the selections seem to come from a rather limited field: The New Yorker
column3: National Geographic
column4: Travel&Leisure. There are thousands of publication venues
column5: yet Pico Iyer decided to treat us  to an anthology that is  top heavy with selections from the  main stream "Big Media" press. The publisher of this series
column6: Houghton-Mifflin hasn't strayed far from the ground that it feels most comfortable with-established main stream authors. Even the piece by Tim Cahill does not represent his best writing. Most of the selections in this book seem like warmed-up left-overs.  As another reviewer has  mentioned
column7: only 4 of the 24 selected authors are women writers. This just boggles the mind... were there no women writers of merit in 2004?  My main concern is that few of these selections are really "travel stories". Some are set in foreign locales
column8: but deal with subjects like teaching English in Tanzania
column9: riding the bus in NYC
column10: famine in Ethiopia
column11: and  political repression in Burma. There is also an irritating post-9/11 angst in several of the essays. While this maybe a  reflection of the mood of  American writers in 2004  coming to grips with their new found feeling of insecurity in their comfortable middle-class lives
column12: it does not reflect the daily  pre-occupations of the other 5 billion souls on the planet. There is a self-centered navel gazing in this collection of essays that reflects some of the worst
column13: not the  best of recent travel writing.  Nowhere in this collection will you find the brilliant writing of  W. Thesinger
column14: Freya Stark
column15: Norman Lewis
column16: Eric Hansen
column17: or Jan Morris. You will find a lot of boring and recondite references to Henry James  however.  This collection of essays is to travel writing what Starbucks is to a bistro . If you can't tell the difference from the real thing
column18: you might enjoy it. Maybe.   I would give this book a big miss
column19: and send a message to Houghton-Mifflin . Donald Rumsfeld famously referred to the "old Europe". This collection of essays isn't even "old-style travel writing". It is a mis-directed bore
column20: brought to you from the same corporate folks that convinced you that chicken McNuggets is  really food. This isn't travel literature. It isn't even literature. Most of the collection is dross.

column18: if you're lucky

column1: Nothing much new or of substance here.  I sent it back and ate the postage
If you are looking for an unabashed cheerleader on the American Way
column2: this book is for you. If you are already convinced that America is the pinnacle of Western Civilization
column3: nothing in this book will change your mind. If you voted for George W Bush - you'll probably enjoy this book. On the other hand
column4: if you believe America has made some mistakes and are looking for arguments to convince you that what you thought were mistakes were actually smart decisions - look elsewhere.   Revel is a lover of capitalism
column5: liberalism
column6: obviously an admirer of the USA and probably of George W Bush as well. He makes his disdain for many European positions
column7: as well as those of the American left
column8: quite clear. This is a book written for people who agree with American foreign policy. Revel is well informed on many American foreign policy positions as well as European arguments against those positions. On the rare occasions when he is not insulting Europeans who disagree with him
column9: he provides intelligent and thoughtful views on foreign affairs.   The author spends most of the book distorting European views and insulting those who hold them. A fine example is his description of the US Missile Defense system. He claims that there are 2 arguments against it. One
column10: that it doesn't work and the second that it will work too well and make useless the arsenals of the other nuclear powers. These are obviously contradictory arguments and he claims to be baffled that anyone could believe them both. Oddly enough
column11: I've never heard from anyone who believed them both. I do recall the letter signed by 50 Nobel prize winning scientists claiming that the project is a waste of money. I also recall hearing from those worried about angering Russia and China.   Mr Revel's penchant for ridiculing those who disagree with him is occasionally amusing but never convincing. It's a shame. I think he's right on a number of points. If he would just turn his copious knowledge of foreign policy and his broad vocabulary toward convincing people instead of insulting them - he might actually have an impact on someone who doesn't agree with him already.

column1: Before I start

column12: charlatans and wankers to be found in the Social Sciences departments of any given University. Anyone who's been to university and didn't know that deserves a clip around the ear and to be sent to the back of the class. Now either Sokal didn't know that ( - ~clip~ -)
column13: or he's spent half his book shooting fish in a barrel. That might seem like good sport
column14: but before long it becomes obvious it's a cheap thrill.  Having said that
column15: I sincerely doubt that the titillation of seeing dumb French Feminists taken apart is what made this book such a splash: I think it's because of Sokal's purported intent: to undermine the notion of cognitive relativism
column16: especially as it associated with modern philosophy of science
column17: in particular the work of Thomas Kuhn and Paul Feyerabend. This is the battle: Sokal aligns with those who say scientists are the exclusive purveyors of a shining light called truth; the Barbarians at the gate are these simpering postmodernists who want to tear the temple down.  While the poseurs cited in this book are certainly (for the most part) phoneys or idiots
column18: I think Thomas Kuhn was neither
column19: and while Paul Feyerabend overplayed the court jester hand
column20: he had some important things to say too.  So
column21: to the first point: Proving that one writer (or a hundred
column22: or a thousand) who purports to adhere to relativism is a charlatan doesn't establish anything about *the idea* of relativism. All you have established is that you have a found yourself a charlatan. Give yourself a star.   But while you're pinning it on
column23: remember that postmodernists do not have a monopoly on illogical
column24: bamboozling
column25: balderdash:  Example: Sir Roger Penrose (Emeritus Rouse Ball professor of mathematics at Oxford University
column26: no less) and his dreadful
column27: lumpen-headed
column28: and deliberately bamboozling anti-AI tract "The Emperor's New Mind". The very point of the (no doubt correct but nonetheless entirely irrelevant) science deluged on the reader in that book is to obscure the fact that the real emperor was Roger Penrose and his arguments on AI really blow the kumara.   Example: Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker's Linguistic Nativism
column29: which has held sway for a good thirty years in many linguistics departments
column30: and is anything but post-modern: nativism holds that humans have an innate understanding of grammar hard wired into their biology. From my paltry readings in linguistics and the philosophy of language
column31: my impression is that Pinker's and Chomsky's arguments are seriously flawed. (See: Sampson: "The Language Instinct Debate" for a thorough linguistic critique of nativism; see Rorty: "Contingency Irony
column32: and Solidarity" for a philosophical perspective on the contingency of language). Make note of this example
column33: as it becomes relevant later on.  Secondly
column34: Sokal and Bricmont (quite deliberately) refuse to engage on certain topics
column35: in particular on cultural or aesthetic relativism
column36: which they say (without providing a reason) "raise very different issues". Take that star away
column37: for this statement betrays a fundamental misunderstanding about relativism. Actually

column39: aesthetic and cognitive relativisms raise different manifestations of *exactly* the same issue: Cognitive relativism
column40: in that it relates to "epistemic" truth (as opposed to "moral" truth or "aesthetic" truth - both of which seem intuitively more questionable ideas) is simply a cut closer to the quick: indeed
column41: the aesthetic and moral brands of relativism rely for their plausibility on cognitive relativism anyway (i.e. if the truths we understand about the physical universe are contingent on our language
column42: then it follows that ideals of right and wrong and beauty must be similarly contingent on our language).  Thirdly
column43: Sokal provides the following account of cognitive relativism:   "While scientists ... try to obtain an objective view ... of the world

column45: in principle

column52: known as a straw-man argument: You set it up to knock it over. Here goes:   P1: Relativists say science is a waste of time P2: Science helps us reliably predict and react coherently to phenomena occurring in the world  P3: Things which help to predict and react to such phenomena have genuine utility  C1: Therefore

column60: and description of the world in terms of
column61: the current "paradigm". Relativism simply says the best you can do is to know that
column62: for now

column70: for example Pinker ..."  Hold the phone. The implication is that the Sapir-Whorf thesis (as to the contingency of language) has been discredited

column78: except that it relegates the scientist from "truth knower" or "person through whom you may have exclusive access to the truth" (sounds a bit like a grand high pooh-bah or - dare I say it - high priest
column79: doesn't it?) to "person whose theory works the best for now" and who may be in competition for that status with other people in the community whether or not they're scientists.   If science *does* work better than feng shui or healing crystals (and I

column1: Bottom Line: Fans of A Series of Unfortunate Events will most likely be disappointed by this book.  "The End" does for series what the movie did for the franchise; and that's not good.  Before I get into the negatives
column2: first let me state the positives.  While not as good as in earlier books
column3: the writing in "The End" is clever and still has the trademark Snicket whit and wordplay
column4: although the jokes seem forced and repetitive - but I guess it all depends on how you look at it.  Also
column5: the final revelation in Chapter 14 (yes
column6: there is an additional chapter at the end of the book) gives careful readers a lot to ponder.  As with all the other books in the series
column7: this is a fun and fast read and
column8: even though there are major problems
column9: I must admit that I still had a good time reading this book.  That's about it for the positives.  Now for the downside.  First off
column10: you will not find resolution to many of the series' mysteries in "The End": No information on the contents or location of the sugar bowl
column11: nothing more about the purpose of VFD or its schism
column12: nothing about the fates of the villains and volunteers from the fire at the Hotel Denouement (or the hidden library)
column13: not a word about the "man with a beard but no hair" and the "woman with hair but no beard
column14: not a peep about the possible survival of one of the Baudelaire parents, etc, etc, etc.  The problem isn't that The End" doesn't explicitly resolve these issues for us (did anyone actually expect that it would?)
column15: it's that the layers and layers of intrigue that have been building up for years are largely ignored.  The true unfortunate event would be if the series were to end like this
column16: with nothing more to bring closure to these outstanding mysteries.  This volume does add an extensive cast of new characters
column17: however they are all as flat as a pancake (read the book
column18: then try telling one of your associates or enemies anything about the characters Marlow
column19: Larsen
column20: or almost any of the other islanders for that matter - bet you can't).  This time around even the series' mainstay
column21: Count Olaf
column22: seem utterly lifeless and even out of character.    The plot of this book is rather dull
column23: which is perplexing considering that this is the longest book in the series. What you will find within the pages of this book are 12 chapters of fairly slow paced and repetitive "story
column24: followed by a long Chapter 13 that is so utterly ridiculous that the writers of Scooby-Doo would feel guilty ending their story (let alone a beloved series) in such a way.  It is as if the author got to the end of the book and noticed he hadn't moved the ongoing story forward, so decided to have certain characters monologue about the fates of others.  For example, we have all been wondering what happened to the Quagmires and expecting some type of glorious reunion, but I'm quite sure that nobody wanted to hear Kit Snicket say yeah
column25: they captured some birds and then crashed into the ocean
column26: where the 'question mark' shaped vessel swallowed them up.  I don't know if they're alive or not.  P.S. - Fiona and the Hook-Handed Man got swallowed too."  Lol!  As terrible as that sounds
column27: the actual text in the book isn't much better than what I just wrote.  Not to spoil anything
column28: but the bit about Count Olaf's fate isn't much better either.  The pacing is all wrong: why spend chapters going on about the tedium of island life
column29: and then cram the important contents into a few scant sentences?  Judging by the response to this book
column30: it looks like old Lemony has really dug himself a hole.  The fans are mad
column31: and justly so.  Even if the series continues in spin-off books for years to come
column32: many fans have been turned of by "The End" and just don't care anymore.  The prevailing attitude is that readers would be better off stopping with Book 12; in many ways it is better to use your imagination and think of the millions of possible ways that the series could have ended
column33: rather than reading the thoroughly unfulfilling way that it did end.  All I can say is that if there are future books coming
column34: they had better be something 'really' special
column35: or "The End" may be the beginning of the end

column1: It's always discouraging when self-professed Christians lie
column2: and Dembski purposefully perpetuates a lie in order to further his ID claims.  The lie is that evolution by natural selection is "random."  Most famous is the analogy of a hurricane sweeping through a junkyard and creating a jumbo jet.  That's so ridiculously impossible that evolution must be impossible
column3: too.  Right?  But only the genetic mutations underlying evolution are random.  And being random
column4: most of them are in fact terrible failures
column5: frequently causing the fetus carrying them to spontaneously abort.    Only those mutations that do not harm the carrier can be passed on to future generations.  That is a non-random selection process.  In general
column6: only those mutations that actively benefit the carrier are likely to spread throughout the population.  That is a non-random selection process
column7: too. (That's a bit simplified
column8: but the general point holds--even harmful mutations that spread do so non-randomly.)  Dembski's claim that all non-randomness is evidence of design fails the simplest test of logic.  So his goal of mathematically proving design by finding complexity is a red herring.  His implicit claim that evolution by natural selection is randomness in action is a flat-out lie.    Don't be fooled by the ID claims of scientific oppression.  Dembski's work is unscientific not because he believes in God (many scientists believe in God and get published)
column9: but because it tries to prove the unprovable.  Karl Popper pointed out decades ago that you can't prove a negative.  Evolutionary biologists don't claim they have proven the non-existence of God because they understand Popper's principle.  But Dembski believes he can prove that evolution didn't cause something--he never actually tries to prove God
column10: he only tries to prove something else didn't happen
column11: then sticks God in place as the only explanation.  That is bad logic
column12: bad science
column13: and even bad theology

There are two contentions that I would like to address from this book: Haliburton is not profiting from their contracts in Iraq, and 2) Iraq really did have WMD's.  If Halliburton is barely making ends meet with its open-ended, no-bid contract, then don't they owe it to their shareholders to pull out of Iraq toward more profit-making ventures? Shouldn't their board of directors be thrown out? Has anyone bothered to check Halliburton's northward stock march since 2003? A look at Ameritrade from Aug 06 to July 06 shows that the company has almost doubled it's price share!  It's hard to imagine a company cannot make money after being forgiven a $60 million dollar penalty for overcharging the government for things like $45 for a case of coca-cola, or $100 for a bag of laundry, or underfeeding our troops at Halliburton-run messhalls? Haven't they been charging the government for feeding the regiment three squares a day, seven days a week? So, whose running this company into the ground anyway, and leaving it awash in red ink?   Now, for the author's proof that there were WMD's in Iraq:  If we really did discover weapons of mass destruction, as Miniter claims, wouldn't this administration have trumpeted this information worldwide? How come even they are admitting that WMD's don't exist, and never did? Even the US Army Chemical Corps stated the chemicals they found, which Miniter proclaims as proof, were just chemicals and not chemical weapons. The sarin was so degraded from age, it would have been wholly ineffective. The low grade uranium was already bagged and tagged by the U.N. years earlier. Incidentally a lot of countries have that amount of uranium. Does that mean they are making WMD's, and are we going to invade them too?  It was tough reading this when I suspected that Miniter was clutching anecdotal straws to reinforce his preconceived beliefs. His work and sources will not withstand serious scrutiny. He had made numerous factual gaffes, an indication of careless editing and miniscule research. And he uses inductive reasoning to draw his conclusions.  Judging by some of his five star reviews, it's obvious that his conclusions matched his readers' expectations. It's unlikely however, a reader will challenge what he or she already wants to believe.  Mr. Miniter, just because lemons are yellow, and your car may be yellow, doesn't prove that your car is a lemon. It only proves that your car has yellow paint

column1: To lead off
column2: the author of the book was long-time Cleveland
column3: OH
column4: print media sports reporter/columnist Russell Schneider. When Schneider retired from his post at The Plain Dealer - still a major daily at the time - he wrote a weekly column for a minor weekly newspaper chain and turned his attention to a variety of book projects
column5: including Covering All The Bases.  Boudreau was a legend in Cleveland as an all-star shortstop and player/manager - taking the helm at age 24. The 1948 team - one of the greatest in MLB history - went from world champions to the big screen
column6: starring in a typical sports film at the time
column7: The Kid From Cleveland.  The Hall-of-Famer was also known by millions of Cubs fans for his nearly three decades of work on radio broadcasts on WGN. Boudreau also had a brief stint playing pro basketball in the National Basketball League
column8: the forerunner to the National Basketball Association.  With nearly a lifetime of professional baseball to reflect upon
column9: it is surprising that Schneider focuses so much on Boudreau's statistics rather than drawing out anecdotes to highlight the achievements. Schneider does a good job having Boudreau comment on his controversial loss of collegiate eligibility at the University of Illinois for signing a letter of intent to play for Cleveland upon graduating
column10: but there are really no journalistic high points afterwards.  A series of book signings in northeast Ohio were greatly scaled back due to Boudreau's worsening health problems. Though even more than a decade after the publication
column11: there are still new autographed books available for readers who like to comb through bookstores in northeast Ohio.  For baseball fans who enjoy statistics over ruminations
column12: Covering All The Bases is a hit. But Schneider could have done so much more to make Boudreau's career come to life.

This book is a great example of the passive exploitation of the college textbook market. Publishers have perfected the art of having an expert slap together material that is not elaborated upon enough for advanced students
column2: or which repackages information that can be obtained cheaply (or freely) elsewhere. Then the publisher can charge a grossly inflated price for the book
column3: encourage professors to require it for students
column4: then keep the price high by forcing scarcity in the marketplace for those same students who are forced to buy a copy at any cost. This particular book will only ever be purchased by college students in communications law
column5: most of whom can get 99.9% of the knowledge herein for FREE. Here's the rub - this book is almost entirely made up of reprints of court case documents
column6: which record the rulings and reasonings of judges. But if you are a college student - that is
column7: a member of the only possible market demographic for this book - then your college probably offers free or inexpensive access to database services (such as LexisNexis or WestLaw) that compile this information for scholars.   In this book
column8: the "author" Zelezny has supplied a brief introduction that is so brief as to be useless. Then each chapter has an introductory page that features a paragraph on the overall topic
column9: followed by a list of one-sentence descriptions of why each of the selected cases is of interest. Then the court documents for each of the cases are simply reproduced (with some omissions that enhance brevity but damage full learning)
column10: and only a handful of those cases are supported by any explanatory introductions or conclusions from Zelezny. In short
column11: Zelezny just barely tells you why he's reprinting information that is free elsewhere. Instead of buying this completely extraneous book
column12: the student would be better served by simply learning which cases are considered classics in communications law
column13: then reading the cases (plus their supporting documents to boot) on the computer network offered by the campus that holds the class that requires this book. Guess which one costs less. [~doomsdayer520~]

column1: First things first.  The most important thing to recognize about this book is that the majority of it (about 2/3) was not actually written by Jesse Livermore.  It was written by Richard Smitten
column2: a man who tries (and fails miserably) to create a sort of monologue of Livermore
column3: complete with phony quotation marks
column4: in which the great trader outlines his system.  Having said that
column5: Livermore's actual writings are very interesting.  The first few chapters of the book is a word for word transcript of Livermore's original text
column6: and contains much in the way of useful insight and helpful tips and information.  The Livermore Market Key at the end of the book is also Livermore's creation
column7: and it
column8: too
column9: is useful in its own way. 	 The rest of the book is cobbled together by Richard Smitten
column10: a man who seems to have made it his life's work to piggyback on Livermore's success in order to make a name for himself.  Smitten took letters and interview transcripts and pieced together a phony Livermore monologue.  It is unconvincing and a complete waste of time.  The writing is abysmal
column11: and Livermore's concise points and techniques (from the first part of the book
column12: the part Livermore actually wrote) are repeated over and over and befuddled to the point that you have to remember that it is not actually Livermore speaking.  Smitten's attempt to adopt Livermore's style of conversation fails miserably
column13: and the whole of his work is tedious to the power of ten.  I couldn't even get through it-I had to skip to the Livermore Market Key at the back.    The book also contains some shameless self-promotion in which Smitten attempts to peddle his biography of Livermore onto the reader and also his trading system
column14: which he shamelessly claims will help you trade like the great legend.  Smitten's writing is so awful I would never even consider anything else written by him-his seeming inability to create a concise sentence without a run on and his ineptitude at using question marks when necessary waxes tiresome in a hurry.  The best book about Livermore's trading style is Reminiscences of a Stock Operator
column15: and that book will get you closer to understanding the real Jesse Livermore than this drivel ever will.  Aside from Livermore's own words (the only redeeming factor here)
column16: this book is utterly useless

column1: Ray Johnson is a virtually unknown figure of the Pop Art scene and his story is filled with interesting figures from New York at the time. Additionally his suicide puts a tragic spin on his biography. I was disappointed though once I saw that 'How to Draw a Bunny' was not going to let the viewer at the information so easily. What you do get is interesting enough but it comes with an soundtrack consisting of drum riffs that is engineered at the same level as the interviews which proved to be very distracting. About 30 minutes into the film I realized that I had yet to see any of Johnson's work in the film. When it does appear it is quickly cut
column2: cropped
column3: or shown in bits.   'HTDAB' does not suffer from lack of information. After a while
column4: I got the feeling that the filmmaker had almost too much information and interviews often stray off unrelated to each other. I was left to wonder why some anecdotes went on for five minutes while other more interesting ones were cut off to quickly.  At times too much of a 'personal touch' interferes with the film. Why for instance do we need to see a re-creation of a valentine xerox work of Johnson? Was the filmmaker concerned that it might serve to undermine the actual work? Its not too much of a shame...you get the point of the film -and Johnson's collage and xerox work- rather quickly but the details that are supposed to be the meat of any documentary are downplayed by the garnish.

column1: This book provides a good overview of reflections of the late Terence McKenna
column2: a celebrated icon of the contemporary psychedelic scene and discussion
column3: comparable perhaps with Timothy Leary in the 1960's.  For the curious reader
column4: "Food of the Gods" offers a rich insight into his thought and its appeal. But that appeal turns out to be rather narrow and limited
column5: unfortunately. Like Leary
column6: McKenna commanded considerable attention
column7: reaching a wide audience and achieving some degree of celebrity. But as reflected in the pages of this book
column8: his analysis and views turn out to be surprisingly (I would even say disappointingly) weak
column9: and fatally biased
column10: with no solid substance.    I am sure McKenna must have been a very nice man from what people say
column11: and I don't necessarily suspect he was a dishonest person.  Nor is he a bad writer.  But for a subject as interesting as the human impact of hallucinogenic fungi
column12: the discussion McKenna offers here leaves a lot to be desired.  He tends to jump precipitously to his conclusions
column13: and tries to support his arguments by speculation
column14: often idle in nature
column15: and rarely qualified with any semblance of scholarly rigor. This is surprising (and again
column16: disappointing) because he is apparently well educated.    For example
column17: the glare of Lamarcke's error is blinding in McKenna's speculations that psilocybin mushrooms may have catalyzed the very evolution of our species from its hominid ancestry. This is a good example of the kind of thought that seems to have excited so many readers of McKenna's works.  But if you have a minimally sound understanding of the idea of natural selection
column18: its actually a little bit insulting to your intelligence (not that I think he meant it to be).  McKenna's thesis of the extraterrestrial origin of Stropharia cubensis gleefully throws any and all pretense of informed reason to the wind
column19: and I'm sure that's a lot of fun--but only in a cartoony
column20: conceptually childish way.   Readers seeking a more balanced understanding about psilocybin mushrooms will scratch their heads at how oblivious McKenna seems to findings from science.  To me his writings recall "scientific creationists" and their style of argument.  In fact
column21: along these lines
column22: one of the worst flaws in this book is its stifling
column23: overbearing
column24: disaffecting ideological rigidity.  It is almost like what one sometimes sees in "creationism" but of opposite
column25: left-wing rather than right-wing
column26: character.  The more different
column27: the more the same? This is hokey
column28: corny stuff
column29: and actually not interesting
column30: unless you are really into
column31: well
column32: overt propaganda really
column33: about the "partnership" society of prehistory
column34: and the "dominator" culture
column35: and ... it just goes off into this sort of hambone rhetorical bait for anyone who will snap at it.  Here
column36: a lot of fashionable
column37: widely circulating fairy tales about prehistory and pre-industrialized culture are installed at the foundation
column38: where only a better informed theoretical perspective could serve.  Its Rousseau's "noble savage" all over again
column39: with PC retooling.  (From my perspective
column40: notions that other peoples are better or worse than we are
column41: especially if they are really really different from us
column42: probably tend to distort our image
column43: and capacity for humane understanding
column44: of both them and ourselves
column45: sooner or later).  One seeks in vain for a connection of any significance in this book to the prior works of pioneers such as Huxley
column46: Alan Watts
column47: Huston Smith
column48: and R. Gordon Wasson
column49: whose comments about the personal power and impact of their experiences with psilocybin mushrooms and/or similar agents are so insightful.  McKenna actually challenges Wasson's thesis about Soma
column50: suggesting it was not Amanita muscaria but ... you guessed it ... Stropharia cubensis.  And true to form
column51: he offers nothing amounting to evidence
column52: only a chain of poorly reasoned supposition and speculations--a far cry from the exhaustive research and painstaking studies upon which Wasson based his theory.   McKenna argues his ideas with all the passion he can muster
column53: and perhaps this explains part of his appeal for some readers
column54: especially if they share in his brand of polarized politics (note the unbridled enthusiasm on parade in many of the reviews posted here). So if firing your imagination with a lot of wild and wooly psychedelic surmises is your cup of tea
column55: you will perhaps find this book entertaining.  Its really a dalliance in mental self-stimulation for anyone whose tastes it appeals to.  If a sound
column56: well-informed perspective about a subject as important and interesting as ethnobotany is what you seek
column57: well
column58: this book is still good in that you can get a clear
column59: detailed picture of the Terence McKenna phenomenon
column60: and what it represents as a body of ideas or thought
column61: what it is all about
column62: the better for you to be able to evaluate its relative merits.    Apart from that
column63: this is essentially an uninteresting book on a fascinating subject.  I would prefer to bear happier tidings
column64: but "Food of the Gods" really fails to deliver a discussion worthy of the visionary promise of personal experiences with psilocybin mushrooms
column65: compelling and glittering as that promise is.    But don't take my word for it
column66: read the book and see for yourself what you think.  The good news is

column1: Crump was featured in the book BABIES FOR SALE: the Tennessee Children's Home Adoption Scandal by Linda Tollett Austin.  If you want to know about Crump that is the book to read.    Edward Crump was a typical city boss who sold favors out of public office.  This made the rights of citizens dependent on what they could afford to buy.  Crump enforced the poll taxes that charged people money for the 'right' to vote.  Crump was big in bootlegging and prostitution.  He was the architech of the Memphis 'baby selling' scandal brought to light by Senator Estes Kefauver in 1950.  Crump appointed both women in the scandal.  Georgia Tann or Camile Kelley were Crump's employees.  These women took the heat for Crump's crimes.   This book is PR for a criminal.

column1: Dr. Steven Greer is a well-known figure on the fringe of UFOlogy
column2: and he claims to have "briefed" senior government figures on the UFO issue
column3: but five minutes with this book reveals why few take the issue seriously.  It's an amateurish
column4: sometimes incoherent clip job of unedited
column5: free-flowing interviews with dozens of scientists
column6: pilots and former government/military figures
column7: most of whom say they experienced a highly strange UFO episode (though some of the "testimony" is second-hand).   The firsthand stories can be very interesting and provocative
column8: especially when they purport to cover the government's secrecy
column9: suppression and disinformation techniques. But any impact the content might have is pretty much overshadowed by the hard fact that "Disclosure" is a disorganized
column10: misspelled
column11: contradictory
column12: somrtimes unintelligible
column13: incoherent mess. It's not even "written" in the strict sense -- it appears to be a bunch of interview transcripts hurriedly set in type
column14: not subjected to so much as a simple spell-checker. Names and geographic locations are mangled
column15: punctuation is absent
column16: and the speakers' weird allusions are left hanging. It's hundreds of pages long
column17: but it feels like the world's biggest high school social studies project.   The one consistent stylistic point is that Dr. Greer's name or initials appear over and over and over again -- nobody ever accused him of missing self-promotion opportunities -- but the amateurish nature of the production is a net negative mark against him. It's a mess.  In a foreword Greer says the material was/is so urgent
column18: because it deals with the future of the entire human race
column19: etc.
column20: that it had to be rushed into publication. I would like to think the definitive word on the future of the entire human race will be spelled right and look like it came from grown-ups.  Tragically disorganized efforts like "Disclosure" warm the hearts of the disinformation masters
column21: I'm sure
column22: because the UFO movement hangs itself with this kind of stuff -- or at least consigns itself to eternal fringe status. It's a serious subject and it deserves serious coverage
column23: but "Disclosure
column24:
for all the nuggets of interest it contains, helps guarantee that the subject won't be taken seriously for the foreseeable future.

column1: "A Facsimile of the original edition" ? My mother has an original copy (7th edition) which was handed down to her & it is now held together with tape & love. Borrowing that book from my mom made me a bit nervous so I wanted to get one for myself. I did a lot of reading of reviews & finally decided on this one. Yes it does have all recipes that the original had but without ANY cooking temperature (electric
column2: gas or internal temps). Even the time tables on page 32 & 33 with cooking times didn't have the temperatures that they needed to be cooked at. My mother's does except the charts are in a different area of her book. I am sorry but I am not going to sit down with a brand new cook book & take my mother's book & write down what temperature every single recipe needs to be cooked at. There was one recipe that state "cook for 20 mins. at a very high temp" & my mothers book said " cook for 20 mins. at 450 F". It almost looks like the temperatures were purposely left out because everything else appeared to be the same. Copyrights problems?  I am returning this book because it didn't meet my expectations & felt it was misrepresented

column1: Prof. Gardner's book is disappointing. He tries to be all things to all people saying both that he believes in basic competencies but wants to put inquiry first. Also
column2: his language is inflated
column3: and lacking in philosopical specificity. For example
column4: he believes in building up the inner world of "mental representations" [unexplained term] yet insists on "performances of understanding" [another unexplained term].   Also
column5: he has respect for the individual learner and individual differences
column6: yet he is concerned about the "position" or "situation" or social class dynamics in which the learning takes place. Thus
column7: he fails to do justice either to the individual or to class
column8: race
column9: or gender.  The role of leadership in learning is wholly ignored; and responsibility is not explored.  In short
column10: it is extremely difficult to pin down Prof. Gardner. It would be kind to say he is eclectic. I hope it's just not fuzzy thinking.  However
column11: we can discern that he has a romantic obsession with beauty
column12: truth
column13: and goodness. Imagine -- the Holocaust is reduced to being an illustration of what goodness is or is not! His treatment of these ideas is superficial and banal. I don't like to be so judgmental
column14: but his writing about them does not deserve a detailed analysis.  When attacking E.D. Hirsch whom he calls the main speaker for "cultural literacy
column15: he sets up a straw man. He says that Hirsch's school of thought has an underlying belief in the Lockeian tabula rasa." Yet
column16: I find nothing in Hirsch's writings to indicate that he believes in a tabula rasa.   Further
column17: is Prof. Gardner really less elitist than Hirsch as some have claimed? I have found that the Harvard elite spend their entire lives trying to achieve and learn everything
column18: and be on top. Their lives are marked by ambition to the Nth degree; yet
column19: he debunks time-honored and experience-honored content areas that traditionally have defined literacy at its best. Thus
column20: I find a certain inherent dishonesty in Gardner's presentation.    Believe me
column21: friends
column22: I have taught students who have many ideals
column23: Greek ideals and other ideals
column24: but know very little
column25: nor do they aspire to learn. If they have those ideals
column26: and if they are facile and glib
column27: will they be the leaders of tomorrow who are embraced by Prof. Gardner?  I find a tendency on Prof. Gardner's part to oversimplify certain issues like the Holocaust
column28: and to overcomplicate certain others like the nature of intelligence.   The world is not waiting for the concept of intelligence to be re-written.  Am I oversimplifying when I think that there is something very awkward about saying that there is no fundamental difference in intelligence between Einstein and the custodian of my school? Is this awkwardness because I am an elitist putting down the custodian?  Is it because of lack of intelligence that I am still in the grip of a univocal definition of intelligence? I don't think so. Rather
column29: we all know we are dependent on each other
column30: and that everybody has some unique aptitudes or gifts they can express and be respected for
column31: but trying to elevate this understanding to a higher level of truth or intellectual significance seems to me to be illegitimate.   Lastly
column32: his writing style is a bit too fond of adjectives
column33: and the book reads as a whole like It Takes A Village by Mrs. Clinton. The Disciplined Mind has a mellifluous style that presents itself as being highly sophisticated and
column34: at the same time
column35: as down-to-earth
column36: with balanced common sense. Yet
column37: ultimately
column38: the book is boring.  As one Amazon reviewer states
column39: Prof. Gardner is full of himself.    In this book
column40: there is no straightforward discussion or emphasis placed on knowledge
column41: justice
column42: Judeo-Christian values
column43: persistence
column44: responsibility
column45: or character development...words which I find essential for a true philosophy of education.

column1: There are a lot of books out there written purely for entertainment and then are the more scholarly
column2: "artsy" books like "The Stone Diaries" that unless they get Oprah's endorsement usually aren't read in the mainstream.  These latter category of books have more freedom to experiment with different styles and techniques.  This can make for an interesting story or it can make for a dull
column3: albeit somewhat thought-provoking read.  Again the latter categroy best describes "The Stone Diaries."  I hate to say a book is boring because I sound like a five-year-old trying to squirm his through an opera
column4: but this book is BORING.  The problem lies with Daisy herself.  She isn't interesting.  She does nothing interesting.  Almost nothing interesting happens to her.  Her first husband for all of two weeks gets drunk and falls out a window; that's the most interesting thing that happens to her.  That and her birth in the kitchen of her father's Manitoba home when her mother was either too stupid or too lazy to find out she was pregnant.  Everything else is as common and ordinary and unexciting as the lint in your dryer.  She grows up
column5: moves with her father to Indiana
column6: goes to college
column7: gets married and widowed
column8: visits Ottawa
column9: gets married again to the much-older man who helped raise her after her mother died
column10: has three kids
column11: gets widowed again
column12: becomes a garden columnist
column13: gets fired
column14: gets depressed
column15: gets old
column16: gets sick
column17: dies.  The end.  It almost sounds more interesting describing it that way than it reads in the book.  The most agonizing part for me is it takes the book so long to even get to Daisy.  The first 90 pages of the novel go by without knowing more than basic information about her.  We read nothing about her childhood except her getting sick and developing an allergy.  We read nothing about her teenage years in Indiana or her time in college.  We go through a good third of the book without knowing ANYTHING important about the main character of the story.  We're told plenty of background about the people around her--including the life story of her dead mother--but very little about her until she's already widowed the first time and on her way to becoming the Canadian June Cleaver.  The only way to appreciate this book
column18: especially near the end
column19: is to think
column20: "Daisy is like me" or someone you know.  But then it's pretty depressing to think most of us are this bland and ordinary.  We'd like to think we're special but if we see ourselves in Daisy then we are anything but special.  The narration for this book was confusing as well.  It refers to Daisy in the 3rd person most of the time
column21: but then throws in first-person references as well.  There's also a paragraph or two halfway through saying how unreliable Daisy is as a narrator.  Upon reading that
column22: what am I the reader supposed to believe?  All of this as well as the frequent time shifts
column23: cuts to letters
column24: "theories"
column25: recipes
column26: notes
column27: and so forth left me dazed
column28: confused
column29: and feeling empty.  Of course you can say
column30: "This won a Pulitzer
column31: so what do you know?"  I've read many of the Pulitzer winners over the last 15 years or so and there aren't many I'd recommend reading unless you're a literary snob.  I'd theorize it's because most of these winners aren't written with the intent of entertaining readers.  All in all I think there might have been a way to make this uninteresting topic interesting
column32: but Shields doesn't do enough to make that happen.  You're better served contemplating your own dull
column33: empty life than reading someone else's.  To close
column34: I'd like to point you to John Updike's Rabbit Angstrom books
column35: starting with "Rabbit
column36: Run" that chronicle a relatively ordinary person in a much more fascinating
column37: entertaining way.  The last two books in the series even won Pulitzers.  There's a literary experiment that succeeded brilliantly

column1: `The Anglo-American Establishment" is a book by Carroll Quigley
column2: a man whom former president Clinton called his "favorite professor."    Quigley documents the work of a secret Group of influential conspirators
column3: alleging that the Group was one of the most important historical facts of the 20th century
column4: due to its influence on British foreign policy. The book covers the period from 1919-1945.   The author nearly bores us to death
column5: and presents a lot of information that is contradicted by other sources.  There is some worthwhile information here
column6: but it will be hard to find if your eyes glaze over.  Cecil Rhodes of South African fame formed this unnamed Group and perpetuated it after his death
column7: by way of a trust fund.     Many who were associated with the Group imagined that they were endeavoring to extend British rule throughout the world
column8: along with the great moral ideals of "freedom and democracy."    This Group was self-deluded.  They imagined that they were moral
column9: civilized
column10: and even Christian
column11: but they were the antithesis of all that.  Their methods were those of tyrants
column12: despots
column13: warmongers
column14: and conspirators.  Quigley makes a fundamental error in supposing that this Group was at the apex of power. More likely
column15: this Group was manipulated to further the interests of international finance
column16: without the idealists in the ranks having any suspicion of being used.      The name Robert Henry Brand (Baron Brand
column17: Lord Brand) is repeatedly mentioned as a supremely influential member.  He was a partner and managing director of Lazard Brothers Bank.  "In all of his activities Brand has remained one of the most central figures in the core of the Group."     The Group was responsible for an unbroken series of British policy disasters.  Like they say
column18: the big money is made in wars and depressions.     The Group's idea of expanding the British Empire mutated into the idea of placing the Commonwealth within a League of Nations
column19: which is just another name for world government

column1: Having recently built a digital picture frame from scratch
column2: I was excited when someone gave us this frame for xmas
column3: to see what a commercial frame would be like. After using it for a few weeks
column4: I have to say that if it wasn't a present I would return it and get one that was built by people who had some sense of innovation.  The Good:  * Screen is bright
column5: images look great * Resolution is only 640x480 but it will play images up to 10 megapixel and they look pretty good to me. Doesn't seem like you need much higher resolution than that on such a small screen.  * Computer connection worked great - I plugged it into my xp box
column6: all drivers installed automatically without the need for a cd and then 4 new removable drives showed up. It would be nice if only the drives with a card in them showed up but this is a minor issue.  The bad:  My main complaint about this picture frame is that the people who made it obviously had no interest in making the sort of product that you enjoy using because it is clear that the inventor appreciated why such a product would be fun to have or what makes it an improvement over what was there before. If I bought this frame in 1999 or if it cost $50
column7: I could have forgiven it for the poor design
column8: but in 2007
column9: for $180
column10: it is completely unacceptable.  We live in the future here people
column11: get with the program!    I have not used other frames on the market
column12: but given that you can buy an old tablet pc with a 12" screen on ebay for $70
column13: strap it into a cheap frame and make your own
column14: pc-based screen that works 100 times better than this frame
column15: just by running a screen saver for under $150
column16: I'd say this frame is not worth the money at all. This screen just doesn't deliver the goods for the price.  Some details: * Menu system is insanely poorly designed - for instance
column17: you have to be in a specific menu to adjust the system settings - pushing the "setup" button at any other time does nothing despite the fact the the setting are global * Remote control only works when you are standing about a foot from the computer and pointing it directly at the tiny IR hole in the front of the screen. * Screen only works as a horizontal frame - there is no way set it up as a vertical frame (i.e. as a 480x640 frame) because the frame automatically rotates vertical images and there is no way to turn this "feature" off. * The slowest slideshow speed setting is 1 minute between images. Your only other option is to have it just be on 1 image that doesn't change. * No way to connect remotely to the computer or to easily  get images onto the frame without having to take the frame to where your computer is or go through a tedious process with a memory card an the crappy menu system. * Good viewings angles are limited but this is a general problem with lcd screens

column1: This book has all the right things to make it a good novel. So why does The Raven only give it a measly two stars? Three words: Excessive language use. A character like John Constantine can be expected to use colorful language. Not a problem. In the real world

column3: not conversation
column4: I begin to wonder about the author's imagination. Isn't there a better way to say that without resorting to "gutter language?" The Raven thinks so. It is unrealistic to think that characters should not give way to full expression
column5: it makes the character more human; you think: "Yeah
column6: I know a bloke like that! Sounds just like him!" But in the context of the writing
column7: it becomes: "Can't he think of another word? I'm tired of reading the f-word all the time!" Quoth the Raven....

 I got into AFI with the release of Art of Drowning, which is a fantastic album.  My girlfriend at the time had Black Sails in the Sunset and even though I didn't really get into it then, I now think it rivals AOD.  AFI has always been a band to look towards the future and embrace a sense of progress (this is highly commendable).  These two albums, which formed my introduction to AFI, now stand as the mid-part of their career.   The band has always refused to simply fall into the groove of what's cool.  They've always been unique.  Their first two albums came out of their intense interest in the 80's and early 90's hardcore punk scene.  Davey Havoc may have summarized the roots of the albums best when he says, Ever since I can remember I wanted to be in a hardcore band
column3: at the beginning of the He Who Laughs Last" video.  These albums are full of the intensity of the early hardcore scene.  When the band emerged into this middle era the music was totally fresh and delightfully dark (it was there in the early days
column4: though
column5: in songs like Brownie Bottom Sundae).  These middle albums (haloween ep and self-titled included) also had an intensity and an energy that blew away their old sound.  Moreover
column6: I've yet to hear a band in the world of punk (past and present) who's music rivals this intensity.  I appreciate the two newer albums on an artistic level; they continue to break the mold (the goth glam influence is pretty cool).  Besides
column7: who can say they didn't see them foreshadowed in certain moments on Black Sails and AOD.  But
column8: personally
column9: it's pretty difficult to listen to Decemberunderground.  AFI deserves all the respect in the world but I don't feel much of the fire of the old days.
