column1: One reviewer below cries that 99.9% of the names on the VietNam War Memorical Wall are of men. Typical of people who like Farrell's style of 'research' he neglects to mention one key fact: women were kept out of combat roles and indeed out of the military just about entirely during that era.  Who did this to women? Powerful men who substituted chivalry for justice.  Farrell and his readers blame women for this.  Why shouldn't they? If htey blamed those powerful men it require that they surrender power
column2: too
column3: and they're not willing to do that
column4: even while they claim victim status for the gender that occupies some positions Farrell doesn't want to cite:  98% of Fortune 500 CEOS
column5: 90% of all violent criminals
column6: 85% of police officers and military
column7: and so forth. All of that is power.  Farrell would have you believe that this is ephemeral power that doesn't really exist on the street level for the ordinary guy. Tell that to any rape victim.    Farrell's section about Laurie Dann ought to give pause to his fans
column8: but it doesn't. Like other backlashers
column9: he makes wild charges and yet doesn't get close to the facts. Not hte least of his errors is this: Dann did not have a son.  Dann did not accuse an eight-year-old boy of rape. And so forth. Let nothing
column10: however
column11: get in the way of the male quest for victim status.     Farrell's been dining out on his status as a former male member of NOW for ages
column12: but he neglects to mention that  his alleged feminism ended when his wife divorced him.  Farrell's been treating feminism since then the way a scorned lover treats the ex's photo: as something to be bitterly defaced. He got rejected and he's never recovered.    I wonder if readers approaching this 'poor me' catalogue of badly-researched drivel are aware of two important items in Farrell's past that he tries to hide:  *His infamous 1987 Penthouse magazine interview in which he talked about positive father/daughter incest---approvingly;  and *His statement that "Before we called it date rape
column13: we called it a good time."  Farrell likes to say he was a feminist but he was sunshine feminist when 'feminist' meant 'free love.' Once it became clear there were no more freebies for 'what's-in-it-for-me-male-feminists' he turned his back and got downright hostile. He's been writing badly-researched drivel ever since.      He relies on biased sources
column14: cherrypicked quotes
column15: and dubious logic to support his thesis
column16: that men are really powerless instead of women.  In a way
column17: it's awe-inspiring
column18: how he manages to turn examples of literal power into powerlessness
column19: but looking at it from another s ide
column20: it's frightening
column21: too.  His beliefs and his writing justify a lot of hostility and outright hatred against women
column22: and for that he deserves notice.       People who want to read a sincere exploration of the trials and tribulations of modern masculinity would do better to pick up Susan Faludi's "Stiffed." It features better research
column23: better logic--not that that's saying much---and genuine compassion.

column1: Steven Pinker lost me as a buyer of his thesis with the very second sentence of his book:   "For you and I belong to a species with a remarkable ability: we can shape events in other's brains with exquisite precision".  It you take that for granted
column2: Pinker's book will seem compelling and not especially controversial. Steven Pinker clearly takes it for granted
column3: perhaps because he can't conceive of how we could possibly communicate effectively and coherently if it were not true.   Consider the following
column4: which I think perfectly encapsulates the world view Pinker can't conceive of
column5: by Ogden Nash:  Caught in a mesh of living veins
column6: In cell of padded bone
column7: He loneliest is when he pretends That he is not alone.  We'd free the incarcerate race of man That such a doom endures Could only you unlock my skull
column8: Or I creep into yours.  To my way of thinking
column9: it is the very fact that we *can't* "shape events in other's brains with exquisite precision" - or with any reliable certainty at all
column10: that describes the human condition. The frisson created by precisely that ambiguity underpins all communication; it is the source of irony
column11: tragedy
column12: comedy
column13: invention and imagination. Any theory of language which denies that fundamental contingency of human communication (as this one does) is going to have to prove it
column14: and displacing that onus is a heavy task indeed.  Pinker's psycho-linguistics makes precisely that denial
column15: by holding that all human communication - every language - shares an inate
column16: evolutionary programmed Universal Grammar
column17: precisely because Pinker can't conceive how else human communication could be possible.  I'm no academic
column18: and certainly I have no background in linguistics. Given that this theory - which is from the same tradition as Noam Chomsky's - has been the ascendancy amongst academic linguistics for the best part of the last thirty years
column19: Steven Pinker being one of the leading "normal scientists" within the paradigm (if I should be so bold as to use that word)
column20: and that The Language Instinct is considered fairly widely to be his magnum opus
column21: I was expecting to have my naive relativistic assumptions carefully and systematically dissected
column22: then annihilated
column23: one by one.  So imagine my surprise to find that in the place of carefully drawn arguments and compelling statistical data
column24: one finds a tissue of anecdotal arguments carefully selected to fit the theory
column25: arguments from authority ("Chomsky is one of the ten most cited writers in all of the humanities")
column26: dubious suppositions in place of statistical data (the "it is difficult to imagine the following grammatical construction being used" sort of thing)
column27: begged questions
column28: non sequiturs
column29: and Roger Penrose-style irrelevant scientific waffle - especially as regards evolution - and a decided absence of any consideration of competing theories of linguistics - and straw men versions of those which do rate a mentioned.   In short
column30: Steven Pinker employs just about every illegitimate arguing technique in the book. His theory completely fails to account for metaphor (metaphor is barely mentioned in the book)
column31: nor the incremental development of language
column32: the evolution of different languages with different grammars and vocabularies. At times Pinker is forced to argue that the grammar of our language is sometimes different from the words we actually speak and write
column33: containing unspoken "inaudible symbols" representing a word or phrase which has been moved elsewhere in the sentence
column34: so the sentence "The car was put in the garage"
column35: according to Pinker's Universal Grammar should technically be rendered as: "was put the car in the garage"
column36: and the construction we use can only be explained by movement of "The car" and the insertion in its place of an inaudible "trace":  "[The car] was put [trace] in the garage".  Now
column37: again I am no technical linguist
column38: but this has all the hallmarks of pure bull manure to me.  Finally
column39: Pinker is at pains to point out that Universal Grammar is only ever applicable to oral language: written language didn't arise for centuries after oral grammar "evolved" as a phenotype.  But this hardly helps Pinker
column40: since (as he himself points out
column41: with reference to a transcript of the Watergate Tapes) when people talk in ordinary conversation they almost *never* use complete grammatical sentences: they interrupt themselves
column42: they rely on physical gestures
column43: they break off in mid stream and start a new thought
column44: they don't punctuate (there's no unequivocal punctuation in spoken English)
column45: all the time.   As is fashionable amongst the "reductivist" and "evolutionary" set these days (a set I would otherwise
column46: in general terms
column47: consider myself in agreement with)
column48: relativist arguments are scorned. But Pinker's paradigm implies that
column49: provided we are competent in constructing our own sentences
column50: we should all understand each other perfectly
column51: all the time: there should be no ambiguity; no room for miscontrual; no possibility for evolution in ideas or language. It is difficult to see how anyone could believe such a thing. But neither the structure of language and grammar nor its practical use needs to be perfect for effective communication *at some level* to be possible
column52: and surely that is all that is needed. The beauty of the contingent view of language
column53: which Pinker seems unable to appreciate
column54: is how it can account for the missed margin of communication which might explain the everyday cultural and interpretative problems we all face
column55: and the figurative and metaphorical power we all find at our disposal. Ogden Nash's dilemma is our dilemma
column56: however much Steven Pinker might wish it were otherwise.  An earlier reviewer has mentioned Geoffrey Sampson's "the Language Instinct Debate" as a compelling antidote to Pinker's world view. Having recently read it (on the strength of that recommendation)
column57: I would firmly agree. In perhaps an ill-advisedly grumpy tone
column58: Sampson - whose position at the University of Sussex inevitably means his academic profile is lower than Pinker's or Chomsky's - systematically and convincingly annihilates many of the arguments (such as they are) in Pinker's work.  Olly Buxton

column1: I really wanted to like this gadget
column2: but I've ultimately been disappointed.  The idea is COOL
column3: being able to see your family and carry on a FREE Internet phone conversation with them
column4: and the price is much less than other videophone solutions out there.  Alas
column5: there are a few problems still to be worked out with this device.  Here's the saga of trying to just get the device to work with my network setup.  I tried calling Dlink (the i2eye manufacturer)
column6: Linksys (for my router setup)
column7: Comcast (broadband connection) and SunRocket (VOIP) for support on this issue.  I eventually got the device to work connecting to my parents' wireless version of the i2eye (which I setup through a USR wireless broadband router by opening the required ports) by connecting my i2eye (the wired ethernet version) directly to my cable modem (without my Linksys broadband router or SunRocket VOIP box in the equation).  I then tested various configurations until I was able to determine that the Linksys router (model WRTGS) was not forwarding ports correctly (I HAD properly configured port forwarding).  Linksys tech support tried but failed to help me out.  I swapped routers with my girlfriend who had a Dlink router and the problem went away (after also configuring port forwarding).  Would have been nice if Dlink could have told me when I called them for support that my router wasn't compatible with their device (though it's possible that my Linksys router has a "broken" port forwarding feature).  I also had to forward ports through my VOIP box which the SunRocket tech support people quickly told me how to do.  So I eventually got the damn thing working after a month and a half of trying.  Of course that is two weeks after the standard return policy of ANTonline expires (who I bought the device from through Amazon).    Now to performance.  Even when the i2eye is connected directly to my broadband cable modem my framerate never rises above 5 frames per second.  That's both for the transmitted and received data stream.  (On my parents' end I have to connect wirelessly through their wireless router as their TV is too far from their cable modem.)  I've tried tweaking the "speed" settings on the i2eye to adjust the amount of data the device is configured to send and receive
column8: but I never got an improvement.  Dlink advertises that you can get up to 30 frames per second using a high quality broadband connection (like mine and my parents').  I haven't tested my broadband connection's total upload and download speed because I simply don't know how (probably need some third party utility program).  Regardless I SHOULD be getting at least 500kbps upload speed and at least 1Mbps download speed (at both mine and my parent's end) as that is typical of cable broadband connections.  Also the image quality from the i2eye's "lens" and CCD is horrendous.  The brightness
column9: contrast and general overall "sharpness" of the image is lousy.  That's simply not acceptable.  You can get better framerates (along with much better image quality) from a good webcam using one of the "messenger" applications out there.  Which is what I'm going to explore doing next.  I'm going to attempt to return the devices now (both mine and my parents' i2eye) through ANTonline and Amazon with the argument that the i2eye devices don't perform as advertised and that I'm "late" returning them because of the difficulty in testing the devices (you have to coordinate with the people at the other end of the connection to determine if your own configuration is working).  I'll try to post an update to this review with the results of that attempt.  Unless they can improve framerate throughput through some kind of data compression technology upgrade
column10: I can't recommend this device to anyone.  Less critical improvements would be a better quality camera (and microphone) onboard and better support for setting up the devices (a dedicated i2eye server you can connect to test your i2eye configuration settings) including a list of supported and non-supported routers.    Hope this helps someone else avoid the headaches and hassles I've been subjected to by this device.  Andre

column1: Mr. Carroll has written a book chock full of his arm chair theorizing on a wide variety of topics
column2: that
column3: according to him
column4: he has spend years of researching and thinking about.    What bothers me the most about this book is that Mr. Carroll is so absolute in his belief to non believe that you wonder how he wrote another book on critical thinking.  I find no critical thinking whatsoever here; just a mess of one man's opinions.  It would of been better if Mr. Carroll created a scholarly/scientific work that myth busts but offers more heft with analysis. Me thinks that Mr. Carroll does not have enough "gravitas" to critically examine what he deems to be silly and inane.  Not on a point by point basis
column5: mind you
column6: but as a whole.  And while I do agree with Mr. Carroll that there are charletans and bogus claims made by many delusional people
column7: he makes the big mistake in discounting all in order to fit his black and white philosphy of the hardened skeptic.  Mr. Carroll strikes me as many I have met who are into/studied philosphy (he is a philosphy professor) that deem themselves quite clever and believe that every answer has a rational explanation. In my travels I have found that those who purport to have all the answers actually have very few.  My suggestion to Mr. Carroll is that he pour himself a beverage and spend another twenty years thinking about what he is thinking about.  Maybe then he will get it right.

column15: and this book is not the answer. Save your money
column16: and beg your instructor not to use this text.

column2: I did not exactly 'read' this biography. Instead I purchased the CD version which I distilled via my car sound system every morning on my way to work (I have enjoyed countless biographies of great american figures this way

column5: Richard Carwardine
column6: or Doris Goodwin. I do not seek a beautiful story in a biography
column7: but rather a reliable source of facts that I can use to form my own opinion of a character. In this context
column8: I find Mr McCullough's use of superlatives or long emotionally charged sentences to be a distraction from the subject matter of John Adams and his contribution to America. I also enjoy direct quotes from letters
column9: speaches
column10: autobiographies
column11: as they help me refine my impressions of the context (the period
column12: the relationships to contemporary characters
column13: ...) surounding a promonent figure. Usage of the English language in politics has dramatically evolved since Mr Adams' time
column14: and I missed 'hearing' the voice of John Adams. Instead
column15: this biography felt like reading a translation where the personality of the translator overshadows the personality of the original author. Finally
column16: having read other biographies of the founding fathers
column17: I was disapointed to find so little about the complex relationship between Adams and Franklin.  All in all
column18: my lasting impression is that Mr McCullough did a great job at bringing John Adams and the early American Revolution to the masses through a very appealling product that may however leave readers asking for more historical details and less emotional opinions. Had I known that
column19: I might have passed on this biography and instead explore Mr McCullough's fictional work

column1: Please note that this may have been a great book when it was written in 1999
column2: but how any review in 2005 can recommend this book with four stars is beyond me.  A very serious genetic disorder in Cavaliers has become TOO common and is found in all bloodlines.  This disease
column3: which did not become widely identified in Cavaliers until 2003
column4: should be thoroughly researched by anyone interested in acquiring a Cavalier.  It is not in this book.  Go into this with your eyes wide open.  We love our Cavalier and would not trade him for anything.  But he has had major brain surgery at a prestigious university vet hospital
column5: pre- and post-surgical MRI's
column6: and is on expensive medication 3 times daily.  He cannot be walked on a leash because of pain
column7: even with the medication.  If you want "cutesy" information
column8: buy a book.  If you want real information
column9: go on-line.    Added from Cavalier Health on 9/13/2006:  "Researchers conservatively estimate that at least 50% of CKCSs have occipital hypoplasia (or caudal occipital malformation syndrome -- COMS)
column10: the skull bone malformation believed to cause syringomyelia.

column5: design

column7: procedures

column1: While this is a brisk read
column2: as a good popular history should be
column3: I am concerned by errors in the text.  One example suffices.  In Chapter 2
column4: Kelly describes the infamous Fourth Crusade thusly: "Venetian authorities offered a group of French Crusaders free passage to the Holy Land
column5: then rerouted the Crusaders east to capture Constantinople."  Wrong on virtually every count.  Then as now
column6: Venetians gave nothing away free.  The Doge and the leaders of the Crusade agreed on a (healthy) price for transport by sea to Egypt (not Palestine).  When the troops arrived at the port
column7: however
column8: the Crusaders proved to be short of funds
column9: and were unable to raise the balance.  Only then were they diverted to the sack of Zara and then of Constantinople as a means of paying their debt to Venice.  See Norwich
column10: "A History of Venice" for the details.  Now
column11: if Kelly can get an episode as well-known and well-documented as the Fourth Crusade so wrong
column12: how can one trust his judgment on other issues?  Especially on such issues as epidemiology
column13: which few readers (myself included) are likely to know much about?  I also note that the author apparently personally responded to one of the negative reviews posted here.  I would rather that he respond to the one that accuses him of plagiarism.  I do hope it's unfounded.

column1: How exactly this film is billed as a comedy is beyond me. I can't remember laughing at this movie. I guess it's a comedy-of manners

column4: and "Double Indemnity" have actually made  this movie! A very weak and unfunny screenplay by I.A.L Diamond and Wilder  himself. If it weren't for the fact that there are two star performances by  Lemmon and Matthau

column6: I might consider giving this one star. The story goes something like  this
column7: Harry Hinkle (Lemmon) is a camera man who just happens to be in the  wrong place at the wrong time
column8: see he collides with football star Luther  "Boom Boom" Jackson (Rich). Hinkle's brother-in-law
column9: Willie  Gingrich (Matthau) seeks the perfect opportunity to try and pull off a  insurance scam. Hinkle of course at first is totally against the whole  idea. But when he's ex-wife calls
column10: Sandy (West)
column11: to check if her ex is ok
column12: Harry starts to think
column13: maybe he could win his wife back. All of this seems  like a pretty good idea. You would think that perhaps some laughs could  come out of this. But Wilder and Diamond have something else up their  sleeve. They both completely avoided the comedy and seemed to try to give  the movie more "heart". It seems like they wanted to make a drama  more than a comedy. Which is fine with me. Only I was expecting a comedy.  The story really seems to drag
column14: why Wilder felt the movie had to be a  little over two hours long I'll never understand. He could of made the same  bad movie in 90 minutes. The movie was nominated for 4 Oscars

column16: which went to Matthau
column17: for best supporting  actor. One of Wilder's weeker films
column18: and one everyone should stay away  from. ** 1\2 out of ****

column1: I found the book repetitive and boring.  We were told many things over and over again.  And the set up for the romance with the Reverand is nothing if not ridiculous.  Not interested in reading any more of these for sure.
As Hemingway the Zen master said
column2: "Some are hunters
column3: some are not." Several Hemingway scholars have treid to explain EH's lifelong affinity for blood sports (notably Bredahl and Drake's 1990 exegesis of Green Hills Of Africa) -- this "package of Papa" is content to just push whole chunks and raw excerpts of Hemingway onto a marketing skewer without any comment.  Using "hunting" as a marketing criterion forces together the most flaccid posthumous Hemingway and some of his purest fiction and livliest reportage. It's obvious Hemingway wrote about hunting (and fishing) in the same sense the Homer wrote about Mediterranean tourism. Lazy readers may like the way this editor rearranged Hemingway's cabin furniture
column4: but most of the writing actually seem the duller for being re-packaged to a less spontaneous purpose. Sad to see a great prose turned as a license for 'designer books
column5: ' and by his own kin. Some are artists
column6: others are not

column1: Im not really writing this review to sway anyone's opinion of it.  Tastes are different from person to person.  Some may love this book
column2: others may hate it
column3: and a few will think its okay
column4: that is just the way things are.  I only wanted to share my opinion about it
column5: because oddly enough it stirs up strong emotions within me whenever I think about it. The first time i read this book I hated it.  I have read it again since then and upon finshing it twice I still don't like this book at all.  Yet
column6: during both times that I read it I could not put the book down.  This is the bizarre duplicitous nature of The Relic.  I do not like the story or the characters
column7: but still I have been drawn in.  As much as I hate to admit it I consider this book to be a real page-turner.    I don't think i need to go into the plot so I will list the offenses this book commits (once again this is just my opinion).  Predictability - I dont think I was surprised even once while reading this book.  It gives you the kind of cut and pasted characters that are far to overused these days.  From the first time a character is introduced you can pretty much tell whether they are in it for the long haul
column8: or merely here to serve as entree's for the monster.  The outcome of most of the situations presented are easily deciphered if given any thought at all.  Not to spoil any surprises but I'll give you one guess what happens when we are informed that the museum the beast haunts has a security system with solid metal doors that fall into place to cut off a supposed thief's escape route.  Throw in the fact that we are informed of this right before a gala premier of the museums' new attraction in which hundreds of guests will be attending and...well I think you allready know where this is going.  Poor Characters -  All your cliche's are here.  From the overworked
column9: underappreciated heroine
column10: who puts all the pieces together
column11: to the museums management staff who refuse to shut down the museums' premier even after numerous
column12: grisly murders.  Why? do you ask.  Because of revenues of course. I wonder if the museums' head director wears the same suits as the mayor from the movie Jaws.  If the characters arent fulfilling the role as a needed cliche' then they are doing the exact opposite that any sane person would do.  If I heard strange noises in a closed section of the museum I was gaurding
column13: especially after the fact that at least two horrific murders were commited in the vicinity
column14: I would call for backup before I investigated.  Of course I am sane
column15: so reverse what I would have done and you get the basic course of action most of the people in this book take.  UNBELIEVABILITY -  There were many times while reading this book when I had to stop and say
column16: "Give me a break."  I also used the expressions
column17: "Oh
column18: please"
column19: and "That is so STUPID!".  Many times we are expected to deny common sense
column20: and reason so that the story can progress.  Of course if you had a monster that could be killed like any other animal on this planet
column21: then this book would probably only be 100 pages long.  So in an effort to stretch it out to 400 or so pages you need a creature that can be described as nothing short of the animal equivalent of a sherman tank.  Im not kidding
column22: this monkey-lizard is shot no less than 5 times and probably a great deal more with no ill effects.  I don't want to give anything more away
column23: but there will be many times when you will find something hard to believe in this book.  Many "What a rip-off" moments - To often while reading this book I found myself comparing it to some other book or movie that had come before it. column1: This book is way too short for such an interesting topic. Another problem is that it depicts women as main victims of weird medical practices in 19th and early 20th century
column2: which is not entirely true. At those times (and may be true today in some cases also) one would be far better off if one stayed away from medical profession. Also
column3: there are some really hillarious things about treating hysteria which authors didnot bother to mention. For the hystory of vibrators as legitimate medical treatment for hysteria
column4: Rachel Maines has done very good job in dealing with this topic. What is also a pity is that authors didn't pursue various medical superstitions about females and different treatment of females which are present in modern times. For example
column5: nobody questions the articles published in peer reviewed medical journal which state that patient's absolute refusal is "relative contraindication" for performing episiotomy. Is there any other surgical procedure which can be inflicted on a patient against patient's explicitly stated wishes? Or for example the fact that many health insurances cover Viagra but don't cover contraceptives. There are many topics well worth investigation which belog to the topic "Complaints and Disorders : The Sexual Politics of Sickness" which authors have chosen not to address in this pamphlet (can't even call it a book)

column1: What a waste of time this book is! I wouldn't recommend it to anyone for any reason. Save your money
This book is important for the historian who wishes to get a glimpse into the workings of the mind of an important figure in American Revolutionary history
column2: but it doesn't stand on its own. It is written almost entirely as a response to Edmund Burke's "Reflections on the Revolution in France"
column3: so I would not recommend reading this one until and unless one has read that one. Otherwise
column4: it is impossible to judge the fairness of the rebuttals of Burke's points
column5: as one only sees them through Paine's perspective
column6: and Paine is far from a fair and impartial debater; he misses no opportunity to belittle his opponent's arguments
column7: and even his opponent himself. I would not be at all surprised to discover that he gives an inaccurate picture of what Burke had to say
column8: particularly given that history speaks rather better of Burke's misgivings than of Paine's panegyrics. Both books were written before the Reign of Terror that resulted from the revolution in 1793; the second part of this book came out in early 1792. Also
column9: history shows us just how silly some of Paine's claims for a Republican
column10: representative government are: 200+ years of representative government in the US have hardly banished wars
column11: or the high taxes associated with them
column12: even though the world as a whole is far more democratic than it was at his time. He makes some good points
column13: and certainly it is hard to stand up against him in favor of hereditary monarchy
column14: but it is apparent that he failed to see that not ALL "democratic" movements were necessarily benificent
column15: even if it would be hard to have much sympathy for the autocratic regime that they overthrow

column1: It was Mark Twain who popularized the aphorism of Benjamin Disraeli that there are three kinds of lies: lies
column2: damned lies
column3: and statistics.  I kept hearing all these marvelous things about FREAKONOMICS
column4: a book by Steven Levitt and Stephen Dubner
column5: so when I ran across it at 25% off
column6: I did a stupid freakin' thing and bought it.  I thought
column7: What the freak
column8: I've got a pretty inquisitive mind and I'm open to seeing things differently
column9: to discovering new viewpoints.  The doubt started early when I got the book home and I first noticed the glowing comments on the dust jacket from the likes of Time
column10: The New York Times
column11: The Washington Post
column12: and The Los Angeles Times.  When all of the liberal news agencies are lining up to tell me how wondrous a certain publication is
column13: I'm immediately going to be freakin' suspicious.  Author Malcolm Gladwell tells us on the cover
column14: "Prepare to be dazzled."  Well
column15: evidently Ol' Malcolm is dazzled a whole lot easier than I am.  (I won't even mention the smug mug of Stephen Dubner that taunted me from the book's dust jacket because I don't want you to get the idea that I judge a book by its cover.  Or in this case
column16: a writer by his physiognomy.  So I won't mention that.)  If you're the kind of person who is amazed to learn that 70% of auto accidents occur within 10 miles of a driver's home
column17: then you just MIGHT be dazzled by FREAKONOMICS.  If I tell you that the company that issues its 5-day-a-week employees only 3 uniform shirts
column18: thinking that it is cutting costs
column19: is probably increasing its overhead
column20: and this fact astounds you  - if you must ask "But how?" - then yes
column21: buy FREAKONOMICS and be dazzled.  Mostly what FREAKONOMICS offers (when its conclusions can be trusted) is just what we used to call "common sense."  But since America has been reduced to a bunch of corpulent
column22: brain-dead zombies staring vacuously at that box of SURVIVORS
column23: and AMERICAN IDOLS
column24: and LOST knuckleheads
column25: good old-fashioned common sense now appears to dazzle the dead (when you can sever them from that box and put a real book in their hands
column26: that is).  I dove into FREAKONOMICS hoping to find my purchase worthwhile.  I got no further than page 13 when my fears were realized: everything would require second-guessing and verifying.  On that page
column27: Smug Mug tells us (based on a single report by the Institute Of Medicine) that "drinking eight glasses of water a day has never actually been shown to do a thing for your health."  Fortunately
column28: I read YOUR BODY'S MANY CRIES FOR WATER by Doctor F. Batmanghelidj over a decade ago so I already knew what a bunch of bunk that was.  In chapter 4
column29: Smug Mug "proves" that legalizing abortion in 1973 with the Roe v. Wade decision was responsible for a national drop in the crime rate.  This represents the centerpiece of his book
column30: both literally and ideologically.  The first thing the reader must accept is that there really has been a significant drop in crime since the early 1990s.  On page 92
column31: the author acknowledges that the police in Atlanta were discovered to be underreporting crime in the early `90s in hopes of landing the 1996 Olympics.  Well
column32: would police forces nationally have an incentive to underreport crime generally if it has actually dramatically increased since the `90s as predicted?  True
column33: being honest might be means to an increased budget
column34: but it sure would make your department appear inept and unable to maintain control.  And surely the Chamber Of Commerce and the big business interests would frown on that public perception.  Let me ask
column35: do YOU actually feel you're less likely to be the victim of a crime now than you did in the early 1990s?  That's funny
column36: me neither.  There's so much crime now that some of what was once reported to the police agencies goes unreported
column37: and recently
column38: an ex-police officer friend told me that cops can no longer engage in some of the micro-policing they were able to do in the `80s and `90s because crime is so out-of-control now.  In dismissing other possible factors responsible for the huge drop in crime (if this claim is a verity)
column39: Dubner states that increased police personnel accounts for only 10% of the drop.  Having a bit more insight into the nature of police work than does the average civilian
column40: it's funny that I find myself even contending with the stats Smug Mug uses that actually WORK AGAINST his theory: I believe the wide-scale hiring of police officers since the early `90s could have impacted the crime rate only minimally - less than the 10% - while actually increasing the municipal coffers via traffic citations significantly.  And Dubner concludes that right-to-carry firearm laws "simply don't bring down crime."  (Be sure to read the utterly fascinating book
column41: GUNFIGHTERS
column42: HIGHWAYMEN & VIGILANTES by Roger D. McGrath
column43: for a decidedly different and scholarly viewpoint!)  In dismissing all explanations for the unexpected drop in crime except legalized abortion
column44: I didn't notice any mention of the tremendous increase in homeschooling and the proliferation of private schools since the early `90s
column45: and I wonder if that might have some statistical bearing.  Ya think?   Yes
column46: I think Smug Mug is selective.  He calls some abortions a "crude and drastic sort of insurance policy."  Not "immoral."  Not "sinful."  But then I didn't expect Smug Mug to call a sin a sin.    And even if Levitt and Dubner's hypothesis is correct
column47: that abortions have lowered crime
column48: the fact remains that not every aborted child would have eventually murdered an innocent person
column49: but every aborted child was an innocent person murdered.  So why are we even discussing this?  I'll tell you why: because the pro-choice folks can feel a slightly shifting consensus
column50: and now they're pulling out all the stops
column51: trying to "statistically" convince the masses that they're safer with all those unborn potential criminals missing.  I find this repulsive!  (And there are studies indicating that those missing people have
column52: and will continue to have
column53: a negative economic impact on society.)  I won't even go into chapter 5
column54: What Makes A Perfect Parent?  Suffice to say that as usual (surprise! surprise!) all the statistics Dubner employs nearly always seem to confirm the rightness of the liberal dogma on each issue.  Funny how those crunched numbers always crunch conservative beliefs.  Just know that if you're a working mother
column55: you haven't cheated your child in the least
column56: but if you're a dad who thinks that an occasional spanking is in order
column57: you are "unenlightened."  If your kid is watching lots of TV
column58: it isn't turning the "child's brain to mush."  (No word on whether or not it's turning his/her morals to mush though.)  And the studies (that we are called to pay attention to) show "that a child's character wasn't much affected whether or not he was sent to day care
column59: whether he had one parent or two
column60: whether his mother worked or didn't
column61: whether he had two mommies or two daddies or one of each."  (I've often wondered what might have happened to me if my Mom
column62: who was home most of the time
column63: hadn't been there to hammer the dangers of drugs into my head day after day
column64: year after year
column65: while I was growing up in the `60s and `70s.)  I've given FREAKONOMICS two stars because I did find the section on the naming of children very interesting
column66: as well as the story of Stetson Kennedy's fight against the "three Ks."  But if you're smarter than I am

 I myself is a Proform treadmill customer and tortured by their customer services. I also found some reviews on the internet mentioning their machines broke down in several months after purchase. (Mine in three months.) The strategy of the customer service is basically make wild guesses of what went wrong and send you the parts asking you to replace it by yourself. (In one occasion, they even asked me to take off the motor and find a local garage to test the motor to see if it's good.)These back-and-forth guessing games normally drag on for months, and eventually they claim the warranty expired and they can no longer serve you, even though it's still within one year. I believe you are looking for a treadmill for exercise, not to practice your debate skill over the phone with some customer service keep saying: this is our policy.

column5: chemical composition

column8: salt-free

column23: with no ill effects.  Lastly
column24: the tone of the book is to white-knuckle
column25: grit-your-teeth and stick it out until you are off pred.  Unfortunately
column26: for many of us

column29: there ARE  many realistic strategies for minimizing each of the side effects;  none of which are discussed in this book because Ms. Zukerman didn't face long-term treatment with the drug.   My recommendation is
column30: go to webmd and look up the medical side effects

column1: As "rush to judgment" is the mantra chanted by defenders of the "presumption of innocence" and skeptics of law enforcement
column2: so could "rush to publish" be a criticism leveled at authors who have penned premature books on the Laci Peterson case.  Fleeman's
column3: "Laci - Inside the Laci Peterson Murder
column4: a pulp paperback mass produced by St. Martin's Press in December of 2003, is an accounting of the case from the disappearance" Christmas Eve of 2002 to the burial of Laci and Conner in August 2003
column5: two months before the preliminary hearing where many clarifying
column6: enlightening and alarming facts would be presented. Fleeman
column7: currently on the staff of People magazine and formerly with the Associated Press
column8: attempts to portray a fairly balanced treatise
column9: based heavily on articles from The Modesto Bee and press conferences
column10: along with selected quotes and opinions from the Peterson family which have not
column11: to my knowledge
column12: appeared in print before.   From this observation
column13: I conclude that the Peterson family was consulted during the research of this book and were compensated for it. Notably absent are statements from the Rocha side that were not derived from previously broadcast or printed media. Whether because of inaccurate sources
column14: ignorance
column15: careless editing
column16: or deliberate spin
column17: the book contains an extraordinary amount of errors.    I am surprised that a professional such as Fleeman would allow this book to go to press without having someone with an informed background in this case proof read it first. To Mr. Fleeman's credit
column18: interspersed as a sort of bucolic relief between recounting the chronology of the grim investigation
column19: a few of his anecdotes about the history of Modesto are amusing. However
column20: Mr. Fleeman's somewhat bland narrative is eclipsed by quotes from the major players in the story
column21: and what few laughs and tears I experienced reading this book were all elicited by Laci or her family
column22: who remain the heart and soul of this tragedy.  Fleeman's main source of information was obviously local news reports generated daily throughout the case by the Modesto Bee
column23: some of which we now know were incorrect in many of the details
column24: based on the flurry of activity and originally accepting much of Scott Peterson's explanations for events as fact. Various recurring descriptions of Peterson "crying
column25: blubbering
column26: incomprehensible
column27: and focused on the search for his wife
column28: were no doubt contributed by his family, as any overt demonstrations of grief, credible emotional displays, or participation in active searches were nonexistent to the rest of the world. Fleeman relies on Peterson's timeline and other unreliable references for his activities of the 24th, the weather, the number and times of his phone calls, McKenzie's behavior, and Laci's plans that morning.   In his efforts to present Peterson's side of the story, Fleeman traps the defendant in numerous areas of disbelief.   Similar to the articles in People Magazine about the Petersons, Fleeman blatantly misrepresents the clan as another blended family. Both his parents had three children from previous marriages and
column29: like the Brady Bunch
column30: this brood somehow formed a family when Lee and Jacqueline Peterson got married...He [Scott] was the baby of the family and the joke among the seven Peterson children - five boys
column31: two girls - was that Scott never had to walk anywhere until he was at least age two..." Apparently Mr. Fleeman isn't privy to the fact that Jacqueline's first two children
column32: Don and Anne
column33: were given up for adoption and never met Scott until they were adults; and that Jacqueline
column34: by all accounts was never married prior to Lee.  Other important (or incriminating) details that were omitted in the book include reports of Scott golfing during the searches
column35: visiting the Berkeley area in rented cars only to stare out at the water for a few minutes and leave; and the revelation that a neighbor
column36: Kim McGregor
column37: was responsible for the burglary of Peterson's house while he was in L.A
column38: which were all common knowledge before the preliminary hearing. Curiously
column39: the 8-page photo archive in the center of the book includes no pictures of Laci
column40: not even the ubiquitous "missing" poster. Any biographical information about Laci is derived from her family and friend's interviews with the press and television personalities. If I were writing a book about a murder
column41: using the victim's name as the title
column42: I would make a concerted effort to flesh out her life and history to portray her as a multi-dimensional person
column43: and not merely rely on what has already been written about her.   The philandering and fraudulent Scott
column44: on the other hand
column45: warranted much more illustration
column46: including several references to a golf scholarship to Arizona State that has yet to be confirmed as anything but Peterson family legend.  Regardless of the attempts to swing the anti-Scott pendulum more toward the center
column47: Fleeman's cozying up to the Petersons is glaringly evident in the amount of ink he devotes to their point of view. Besides his propensity to revisit already trampled territory
column48: the author fails to penetrate any source in the investigation on either side
column49: which may be attributed to the fact that most insiders were strictly adhering to the gag order (despite what the defense and Peterson supporters allege)
column50: or just didn't trust Mr. Fleeman. After seeing how Fleeman misrepresented some of the salient details that were shared with him by people peripherally involved in the investigation
column51: I'd be surprised if he gets any more opportunities for future interviews with key players (other than the Petersons) when the results of the trial are known and he wants to write another book. Perhaps he should title his next one "Scott.

column1: This book claims that Plato wasn't an anti-democrat. Or was he? Actually
column2: the author tries to have it both ways. On the one hand
column3: Sara Monoson admits that Plato had strong anti-democratic and elitist tendencies (you might say that again). On the other hand
column4: she nevertheless wants to "unsettle the orthodoxy" and claim Plato for democracy. It's not working. The method of this book is fundamentally flawed. Monoson points out that Plato shared many of the cultural conceptions of Athens. But that is hardly surprising. Plato was an Athenian
column5: not a Spartan or Cretan. It doesn't prove that he was democratic. Monoson also claims
column6: that Plato's rethoric often derived from various democratic practices. But
column7: once again
column8: this proves very little. Even fascist rethoric is partially derived from democratic ideology
column9: for instance the populist appeals to the people or the nation. This doesn't prove that Hitler was a democrat. (Incidentally
column10: I'm not claiming that Plato was like Hitler. I'm simply trying to make a methodological point.) What makes Plato Plato
column11: what makes Plato tick
column12: is precisely his controversial ideas
column13: including his sometimes disturbing criticism of democracy. We cannot domesticate Plato. We have to wrestle with him as he really was. Friend or foe alike
column14: we're doing Plato a disservice by turning him into a harmless icon.

 Christopher Byron's sensibility indicates that he is a small-minded, pathologically envious little weasle of a man, who tries to puff up his empty meaningless life by attempting to denigrate a great woman who has brought great beauty and grace to our culture.  Unless you're one of those nasty-spirited people who find glee in joining the pack of hyenas who hate powerful, brilliant, talented women because the light from great women's souls is too bright and reveals too vividly your pathetic life, avoid this book. Byron is simply a mean little vampire, trying to suck money and notoriety from the life blood of Martha.  Shame on John Wiley & Sons for publishing this book 
 Many reviewers on this site read TLGPE in the 70's, when we were young and impressionable. (I happened to be 13 when I read it.) If one could be sued for intellectual forgery, Lindsey would certainly be found at fault.  Most of us, thankfully, have gotten past our fears that plagued our teenage years. After all, when we read TLGPE, we were young. We were searching and seeking. We didn't have all of the facts. There were wolves who knew this, and they preyed upon us. Many people who were older, yet still intellectually undeveloped, read this book and were moved to 'believing'.  For most of us, our minds matured. We began to see the vast chinks in Lindsey's pompous Christian armor. We began to realize that fear is a weapon brandished by madmen, by people who use a subtle, gentle cloth of manipulation to control others.  This is beyond dangerous. It is beyond extreme, as most of us have now found out.  I love a good horror novel. I love a good 'true crime' thriller. But the fact that people read Lindsey's books and take them at face value is, perhaps, one of the scariest notions I have ever imagined.  That, dear reader, is beyond horrific . . . and far more terrifying than anything you'll find in the bible or any of Lindeys 'books'. The only thing scarier is that Mr. Lindsey is still receiving royalties from an outdated, silly, contradictory and completely barbaric book penned over thirty years ago. Please don't be the next sucker. Please don't add this one to your cart.

column1: There was a time when I would buy anything with Jeph Loeb's name on it.  At the time this book was being written
column2: Jeph Loeb had already worked with Tim Sale to produce "A Superman for All Seasons" (the inspiration for Smallville)
column3: and "Batman:  The Long Halloween."  Jeph Loeb had established that he KNEW these characters.  He seemed born to write them.  But all was not well when wrote Batman: Hush
column4: the story leading into this one.  He still had a wonderful handle on the character
column5: but his great mystery (Who is Hush?) was formulaic and predicatable.  At best.  It was cluttered with too many characters and was painfully episodic.  At this time he was following up the terrific first two season's of Smallville with the somewhat lack luster Season 3 of Smallville.  Then came Batman/Superman and Smallville Season 4.  One has to ask
column6: did Jeph Loeb have a blood clot form in his brain?  Batman and Superman work to take down President Luthor after Luthor declares them outlaws because a giant kryptonite meteor was headed to Earth.  ...  Wait ...  Superman
column7: the most significant figure in human history since Jesus ... is a bad man because a piece of a homeworld he never saw is going to hit the Earth?  And isntead of rallying all the Superheroes on Earth to stop it... you send them after Batman and Superman?  Hard as it is to imagine
column8: it goes down hill from here.  Luthor is the perfect villain for Superman.  He is evil
column9: and equally powerful
column10: but fragile.  He is the epitome of the Superman conflict.  Superman has all the power of a God
column11: and sometimes he just can't stop evil.  He can't save everyone with his powers.  One of the major themes of Superman is that some problems can't be punched.  Some problems must be faced as a man rather than a Superman.  Loeb appeared to understand this
column12: and was the very man who made Luthor President.  The American chose the man who respresented everything Superman found evil and wrong to control the country he loved.  Superman felt betrayed.  The paralells to Bush are striking
column13: but as Luthor's rise to President was written well before the Novembor 2000 election
column14: pure coincidence.  SO here we are
column15: Batman/Superman.  Several DC story arcs were leading up to Clark Kent doing what Superman couldn't.  Using truth and the media to take down a man that Superman couldn't touch.  THIS is a theme that DC comics needs to embrace.  If they want to reach a more mature audience
column16: a greater focus needs to be put on Clark.  Superman gets the people in capes
column17: Clark gets the people in suits.  And as the story arcs build up to what could be the best Superman story written in a decade-- Jeph Loeb decides to have Luthor just GIVE UP EVERYTHING and inject himself with LIQUID KRYPTONITE and get in a giant robot and go fight Superman in front of national television.  Paging Mr. Loeb
column18: we've discovered that you are a hack.  This of course ignores many of the other terrible aspects of this story.  This review is getting long.  - The homoerotic tension could be cut with a spoon.  I have no problem with gay super heroes.  Superman and Batman are tow of my favorite heroes and I lvoe their interactions.  But this isn't two budies facing certain death.  It's two gay lovers taking down the entirity of the DCU in issue after issue of uninspired dialogue and terrible story. - the world is ultimatly saved by a giant half batman half superman anime robot flown by Captain Atom.  We are meant to feel bad because he is going to die.  Only he can't.  It's impossible.  eVery time his suit gets ripped open he just gets thrown into the future.  And that happened again of course.  So why should the reader care? - Being shot with a kryptonite bullet apparently does nothing more to Superman than make him a bit quesy.  It's amazing how one can across comic books and Smallville track how the shining star of comic book authors went from a man who could reach his readers on a profoundly emotional level to a man who appears to be writing for little more than a paycheck

column1: I am black American and have combination hair...nappy
column2: wavy and straight.  I've been using drug store relaxers for over 30 years (Crème of Nature
column3: TCB
column4: Dark & Lovely
column5: Revlon Realistic) whatever is "on sale" with satisfying results.   These products leave my hair evenly straight and shiny but hard and stiff immediately after the process.  I usually wash my hair after a few days (I like to give it a rest after relaxing) and use a good conditioner to soften and detangle.  From there I am able to go about 12 weeks before having to retouch.  In general my hair is healthy and responds well to straightners.  My biggest expense is with conditioning products to maintain my hair.  I'll try anything and spend any amount if it works well on my hair.  I have great success with Frederic Fekkai products and love Phytodefrisant Botanical Hair Relaxing Balm...this stuff is amazing if you like to wash and go (air dry) and it works wonders with blow drying/flat ironing too.  (Bumble and Bumble Styling Spray is another amazing product for great flat ironing results.)  I forked out $60 to try Phtyo2 after reading all the rave reviews.  I am satisfied with the outcome but not blown away.  Yes

 If anyone would visit Dallas, Texas and the location where JFK was shot, you realize just how much disinformation has been written on this subject, especially this screen play. I found the entire screen play just a fatasy  of paranoid exploitation by a profiteer claiming to sell the truth! For  example, the grassy knoll is less than 30 feet from the road way, with an  easy 10 second slow jog, up a knoll about 3 feet high from the road way, to  the fence on the Grassy Knoll. If shots came from there it was easy for any  policeman to run to that area, let alone see anyone tryimg to shoot from  such an open area. Even a quick getaway is not as easy as this screen play  makes it out to be, since you can preview the entire parking lot for over  100 yards. Also, the distance from the sixth floor to the road is far  closer by observation that anyone can imagine, except for Oliver Stone.  These easy observable locations makes the Warren Report much more accurate  than this screen play. Also, the people who benefited by JFK's death was  the Democratic Party and its leadership not any right wing Republican  radicals? Johnson won overwhelmingly and the Democrats took even a stronger  positions in the House and Senate. Moreover, to support such a screen play  based upon the past reliability of the author in biographies that are  suppose to be real stories about real people is another reason to doubt its  integrity. Again, another example I can cite here is On The Fourth Of  July" where Ron Kovic was beaten and thrown out of the 1968 Democratic  Convention
column4: not the Republican Convention. What few know is that Oliver  Stone was a delegate to the Democratic Convention but this fact permits him  to change facts in this film based on poetic license. So be it
column5: but such  behavior cannot be construed for the truth by a truth teller. The same for  this screen play
column6: it is a great work of intentioanl fiction meant to poison  the minds of the reader to reasonable

column1: The Inflammation Cure by Meggs and Svec
column2: and The Inflammation Syndrome by Challem
column3: both appeared in 2003 and both discuss the role of inflammation in the major diseases of our time
column4: and the things that one can do to limit the risk of diseases related to inflammation.  Both books are easy to read.  Which to choose?  According to the prestigious Library Journal
column5: "While Jack Challem's The Inflammation Syndrome covers similar ground [to the Inflammation Cure]
column6: his approach leans toward the faddish and sensationalist
column7: while Meggs takes a more levelheaded approach
column8: weaving the latest research on various diseases into a broad picture."  The thing I most prefer about Meggs' book is that it takes a comprehensive approach (including diet) to the things that affect inflammation
column9: rather than spending the whole book just discussing the role of diet as is done in Challem's book.  Challem is a health reporter who writes and publishes The Nutrition Reporter newsletter; it is natural that he would stress diet and its consequences.  But diseases are caused and controlled by much more than our diet.  Meggs is a practicing physician who has a great deal of clinical experience with all aspects of inflammation
column10: and who has woven many real-life cases into the book as illustrations.  So
column11: which book should you buy?  I have little doubt that you will find The Inflammation Cure by Meggs and Svec more informative and much more useful as a reference on your shelf

column1: I have read this book (and its companion volume) a couple of times
column2: and to be honest I am not a fan.  Many of Jan Fennell's suggestions are useful
column3: but none are original.   Ms Fennell's method is based on the idea of using the non-violent language of the wolf pack to put your dog in his rightful subordinate place
column4: and therefore gain his understanding and cooperation.  Alpha wolves eat first - so Ms Fennell has the dog owner eat dinner before his dog.  Alpha wolves take the pack out hunting - so we are bid to walk our dogs daily.  Alpha wolves aren't demonstrative - so we are told to ignore our dogs for five minutes each time we arrive home from work.  These suggestions are sensible
column5: but they are hardly revolutionary.  Maintaining dominant status by behaving like an "alpha" wolf is a technique that has been championed by many other authors - the only difference is that Ms Fennell gives this process the cutesy name of "Amichien bonding".  The technique is a good one for restoring a relationship with a dog that has been spoiled or confused in the past by weak or misinformed owners. Its success lies not only in the owner mimicking canine behaviour
column6: but also in the institution of house rules and a predictable daily routine for the dog.    So what is wrong with this book?  The first fatal flaw is the unrealistic simplicity of the method.  Ms Fennell seems to believe that all canine behavioural problems are caused by the dog wishing to be alpha.  It is certainly true that a dog with a misplaced sense of his own importance will probably become a problem dog.  However
column7: dogs can also behave badly for a plethora of other reasons - poor training
column8: learned fear
column9: boredom
column10: health issues
column11: confusion and inherent high prey drive
column12: to name just a few.  Ms Fennell's insistence that all canine problems are dominance problems that can be cured by "Amichien bonding" is unfortunately just not realistic.       For a professional dog trainer
column13: Ms Fennel also displays a rather disturbing lack of knowledge about several dog breeds.  At one point she states that it may be impossible to fully train Bull Terriers "and dogs of this type" due to their inherent "savage natures"!  One gets the impression that she has been unable to train this type of dog herself and holds a grudge about it.  Whatever the reason
column14: I find it somewhat disingenuous of her to ignore the fact that other trainers have managed to train these breeds to very high standards
column15: and blame her own failure to do so on the dogs instead of on her own methods.  In short?  If you know very little about dog behaviour and have a mildly pushy dog
column16: then this book isn't a bad buy.  Certainly
column17: applying the "Amichien bonding" advice won't hurt.  It is the same type of programme as recommended by dog behaviourists the world over (you can get much of the same information for free on the internet
column18: from Shirley Chong's website for example).    However
column19: Ms Fennell's book is not a comprehensive guide to solving every dog's problems.  If your dog has moderate to serious behavioural problems
column20: save your money and book a consultation with a professional behaviourist.  Your dog will thank you for it.

The thigh cushioning made it slightly difficult to slide into the seat because it effectively raises the level of the seat (my car doesn't have fancy seat controls) and I had to wedge myself into the seat. column1: This book is well-written and contains fascinating information
column2: especially in the early sections dealing with Berlin's pre-Germanic
column3: Slavic history. Later on
column4: the bloody  Soviet assault on the city in 1945 against ferocious resistance is depicted magnificiently
column5: while Richie's account of atrocities committed by Soviet troops is truly horrifying.       Where Faust's Metropolis runs into trouble is in the author's tendency to slip into factual errors and in her more  pronounced tendency to present her reactionary political  interpretations as indisputable depictions of reality.                                                              Some of the factual errors are relatively minor; an example would be her assertion that during World War I the expensive German battleships were never used. Actually
column6: they were used - against the British at Jutland
column7: one of the most spectacular naval battles ever fought. In addition
column8: she actually believes
column9: or claims to believe
column10: that Britain entered World War I to protect the neutrality rights of Belgium. Anyone with even a cursory knowledge of the War knows that the British themselves initially planned to invade neutral Holland in order to strike at Germany; the plan was abandoned out of military considerations
column11: not legal or ethical ones.                                                                 More serious are the errors brought on by the author's hatred of Marxism. One need not be an admirer of Stalin in order to realize that her claim that he spurned Britain and France in order to sign a pact with Hitler is pure nonsense. Stalin signed the pact only after the Western allies refused to sign an alliance with him
column12: hoping that the Germans would attack the U.S.S.R. rather than Poland and France. Another area in which she substitutes fantasy for history is in her treatment of Generals Montgomery and Patton and their conflicts with Eisenhower. Both are presented as heroic in their eagerness to provoke a confrontation with the Soviets; Patton
column13: she tells us
column14: was fired "because the Americans would not allow anyone to sour relations with Stalin." Actually
column15: Eisenhower removed Patton from his command after he disobeyed direct orders to stop associating with Nazis and openly planning for World War III. Montgomery
column16: another head case
column17: is lauded for his plan to dash accross Germany and seize Berlin just as it was in the grasp of the Soviets. Somehow he emerges as the hero of the Battle of the Bulge; Richie contends that Eisenhower "hid in his headquarters" during the battle because he feared that the Germans would try to assassinate him.                                                                   Richie's treatment of the G.D.R. after the War reads like one of those pamphlets I was given to read in grade school - the ones written by J.Edgar Hoover or Cardinal Spellman. She finds nothing good about East Germany
column18: not even free
column19: guaranteed medical care or daycare for children
column20: which are described as "rigid social benefits." What are non-rigid social benefits? The kind you get in the form of a trust account or monthly checks from an affluent mommy and daddy? Sometimes her denunciations take on a hysterical tone
column21: as when she declares that the Evangelical Church of the G.D.R. (which made a point of attacking racism and human inequality) was "was very much the successor of Hitler's 'National Church.'" Ravings like this pass beyond the borders of muddled thinking and sloppy scholarlship and enter that of ideological fanaticism.                                                            Richie sides with every cold war hardliner she comes accross
column22: from Richard Pipes to James Baker. Detente was a big mistake
column23: we are assured
column24: because it gave the Soviets military superiority in Europe; why they didn't use it to evict the West is not explained. Willy Brandt's opening to the East was also a no-no; he should have followed the Christian Democrats in blindly following the U.S. Ronald Reagan is a big hero; his absurd Star Wars plan
column25: Richie thinks
column26: is what led to the fall of the Soviet Union and the G.D.R. One has to wonder about the judgement of an author who believes that Reagan
column27: whose government financed the Guatemalan and Salvadoran death squads
column28: stood for international freedom and justice.                                                              In a lengthy and sanctimonious afterward the author's right-wing agenda becomes even more explicit.  she lectures West Berliners that "the road away from the United  States is the road to disaster" and insults Willy Brandt's widow as "pathetic" for begging to differ. She also lumps the Greens ("dreamy environmentalists") and Berlin's new leftists in with vicious neo-Nazis as opponents of U.S. leadership.                                                           At some points in this book Richie seems to reject the concept of collective guilt for the Holocaust
column29: at other points she wants the Communists
column30: who themselves were murdered
column31: jailed or forced into exile by the Nazis
column32: to assume responsibility for it. In the afterward  she encourages "all Berliners ... to try to be worthy of forgiveness." This will probably happen around the same time that British Tories accept responsibility for Britain's leading role in the slave trade and for the genocical witholding of food during the Irish Potato Famine.                                                               One last point. For someone who throws around so many phrases about freedom and democracy
column33: Richie seems to have a rather odd idea of how this works out in practice. As a sign of "hope and optimism" she notes that "hard-line East German teachers were barred from schools" after reunification. In other words
column34: Marxist teachers were fired
column35: as they were in the U.S. in the McCarthy Era. The old Tory interpretation of individual rights - Of course you have freedom of speech. All we ask is that you don't try to exercise it

I did not buy this from Amazon but sought it out here so I could vent about this outrageous product (that's 'outrageous' in its traditional meaning
column2: that it outrages me).  This is two packets of colored dust
column3: approximately the consistency of unmixed plaster.  Empty the plastic bags and the colored dust flies everywhere
column4: mold it in your hand and it retains its shape for a few seconds before blurring and falling apart.  My wife and I repeatedly checked the packaging to see if we should add water or do something else to make this usable but apparently not.  The claim on the package is that it "Molds like Dough
column5:
obviously intended to remind us of Play-doh, but Play-doh is a clay-like material that retains its shape and can, in fact, be molded.  This material -- again attempting to compare itself to Play-doh -- states that it won't dry out.  Of course not!  It's dust!  It can't dry out, there's nothing drier than dust.  In case you're wondering I have no connection to Play-doh or its makers (I don't even know who does make it), I'm simply the father of a 3-year old who uses Play-doh often and hoped this product might be a workable addition to our playtime.  Wrong 
 Sorry, but I really hated this pretentious, boring, and useless exercise in academic masturbation. It's all just an excuse for the writer to drone on and on about her favorite books. A lackluster lesson in literary snobbery, this lifeless thesis paper includes iffy interpretations of dry excerpts, unhelpful writing hints, and zero sense of humor or drama. If you don't love the same books, stories, and writers that Francine Prose loves, you're pretty much screwed. As a published writer myself, I often check out writing books for inspiration. This is one of the worst. I prefer something lighter, more engaging and motivational to light a fire under me. I like Ray Bradbury's book, with its infectious boyish enthusiasm, and the terrific book about publishing, The Forrest for the Trees" (the first half is inspiring
column6: but the second half a little depressing.) Either way
column7: skip this yawn-fest

column1: The Burden of Bad Ideas is an exploration of the shortcomings of urban public policy
column2: examining issues such as welfare
column3: teachers' education
column4: foster care
column5: homelessness
column6: and multicultural curriculum in our nation's school system. The author investigates the ideology of the "nation's elite orthodoxy" and its impact on modern American society.   	Heather Mac Donald holds a John M. Olin fellowship at the Manhattan Institute. She works as a contributing editor for the City Journal
column7: covering issues such as education
column8: homelessness
column9: racial profiling
column10: and the New York court system. Mac Donald earned a J.D. from Stanford University Law School and is a non-practicing lawyer.  	The author's methodology stems largely from her personal experiences in the field of journalism. Mac Donald visited teachers' education classes
column11: homeless shelters
column12: and sat in on public hearings. The author conducted extensive interviewing with people on both the policy-maker side and the recipient side of issues
column13: claiming
column14: "If you want to know how well social policies are working
column15: I learned
column16: ask the poor - when their advocates aren't around."  While the interviewing certainly creates an entertaining read
column17: a lack of concrete sources or citations to support her "facts" has a negative impact upon the integrity of the author's work.   	Mac Donald's book is arranged into twelve chapters. Each chapter covers a different political issue. In "An F for Hip-Hop 101
column18: she examines a course offered at a Brooklyn public high school, studying what she terms ghetto culture
column19: including graffiti, deejaying, emceeing, and breakdancing. Why Johnny's Teacher Can't Teach" is a scathing criticism of education courses on the college level
column20: lambasting the teachers' education system as supporting "Anything But Knowledge."  In her chapter entitled "Law School Humbug
column21: the author discusses how the presence of racial and feminist theory harms serious scholarship in the college classroom. The book develops into a fairly predictable pattern, with Mac Donald's vitriol against the elites" and liberals ever-present
column22: the chapters merely providing different flavors of her disgust and frustration.  	The author
column23: in her introduction
column24: begins with admirable questions: Why aren't our children learning basic skills in public schools? Why aren't programs designed to help the poor really helping them? What will happen to our society if we continue to reject the notion of personal responsibility? Why is our media untruthful and how does this shape public opinion? The answer to all of these questions is more or less a blanket response: Liberal
column25: elitist ideology has caused the United States moral and intellectual bankruptcy. Mac Donald calls for a return to the traditional Western models of thought and education that she feels laid the foundation for the greatness of the United States.  	The problem inherent to this book is a touchy one. Mac Donald approaches many of the issues as an outsider
column26: and it shows. In "Law School Humbug
column27: she criticizes women of color for writing about the politicization of their hair. She claims this is part of a new genre of legal scholarship - first-person narrative." While the author's point that this sort of narrative deviates from the traditional conventions may hold merit
column28: she obfuscates her own point with a dismissive comment
column29: "Not since the Age of Aquarius has hair possessed such political significance." Mac Donald's flippancy only reinforces the impetus for these sorts of narrative
column30: that those belonging to the majority have discounted
column31: devalued
column32: and ignored the minority experience.   	The Burden of Bad Ideas without a doubt exposes many of the flaws in the upper-class liberal ideology. Mac Donald captures the patronization of the liberals to the have-nots
column33: and notes the many occasions where liberal guilt creates ridiculous loopholes in the public assistance system that may be exploited. She paints a vivid picture of the tendency within liberal academia to exoticize other cultures
column34: placing them upon pedestals so narrow they hold no room for honest critique. In the end
column35: the author's efforts fall short. Mac Donald's writing becomes merely one side in a shouting match that takes place between two sides of people who have very little in common with the folk whose fates they argue
column36: with one side wanting to indulgently pat the heads of the underprivileged and coo over their artistic and cultural achievements
column37: while the other side sneers at the relevance.   	Mac Donald's book provides raises many interesting questions and can be used to provoke thoughtful discussion in a classroom setting
column38: or as a springboard for more in-depth research.  Unfortunately
column39: the author's resort to name-calling and the lack of support and citation for her research undermines her credibility. The Burden of Bad Ideas ultimately succeeds in startling its audience
column40: rather than accomplishing any serious enlightenment

column1: Walpola Rahula's book is simply put
column2: Theravada dogma which pushes the belief that the Buddha taught natthatta
column3: namely
column4: there is no self.  Rahula makes a number of claims about what the Buddha taught which have no basis in original Buddhism.  For example
column5: Rahula gives a confusing account of the Five Aggregates (Pali
column6: khandhas).  He omits any serious discussion of why the Buddha does not identify his own self with the Five Aggregates or why the Buddha always deprecates the Five Aggregates declaring them
column7: for example
column8: to be the Buddhist devil
column9: Mara the Evil One.  It never seems to dawn on Rahula that the Buddha
column10: in his many discourses
column11: is deploying the via negativa (Grk. apophasis) with regard to the Five Aggregates.  The Buddha is really saying that our true self is other than these illusory Five Aggregates; and that we should have a revulsion towards them instead of the self!  This book deserves careful scrutiny.  And let the beginner beware
column12: this book draws a terribly nihilistic conclusion about Buddhism.  It is ironic to note that three months before the Buddha dies he said the following: "My life is fully ripe
column13: my life is at an end
column14: I shall depart from you
column15: I have made a refuge for the self.
