column1: I decided to read a book on the five-hour flight from MCO to LAX
column2: and then on the return flight of something less than five hours.  (Flying downwind eastbound
column3: of course.)  I purchased "The Aquataine Progression" by Robert Ludlum
column4: in paperback form.  (I must admit that I still can't get used to spending $7.95 for a paperback book!  But
column5: the horrors of inflation obviously continue to haunt us into the 21st century
column6: and beyond.  This promised to be worth the price inasmuch as it was touted as a "New York Times Bestseller.")  I got to Page 17 of the 658-page book before I gagged.  I managed to read only a few more pages before I set it aside disgustedly.  I quote from the book to explain why:  "Lieutenant Senior Grade Gordon Ramsey had been hit by a fluke rocket that had winged out of its trajectory over the coastline and in on Ramsey's fuselage; the explosion had filled the jet streams" - - (etc).  This almost stopped me in my tracks.  The reason for my hesitancy being the fact that there is no such grade or rank in the US Navy as "Lieutenant Senior Grade."  My inclination is to think that a noted author like Robert Ludlum (or the editor at Bantam Books) should know that while there is
column7: indeed
column8: a rank of "Lieutenant Junior Grade" in the US Navy
column9: there (conversely) is NO such rank as
column10: "Lieutenant Senior Grade."  (The ranks of "Ensign
column11: Lieutenant Junior Grade" and "Lieutenant" equate to "Second Lieutenant
column12: First Lieutenant" and "Captain" in all other branches of service except the US Coast Guard which echoes the rank structure of the Navy.  Most confusing
column13: of course
column14: is that the rank of "Captain" in the Navy is equivalent to "Colonel" in the other services. )  I swallowed my disapproval
column15: and continued to read.  But then
column16: the author goes on to tell us that the skipper of the aircraft carrier
column17: a Captain
column18: calls in our protagonist
column19: a Lieutenant Junior Grade
column20: to inform him that he is being promoted to squadron commander after "Lieutenant Senior Grade" Ramsey met his fate with the rocket as previously mentioned.  Here again
column21: I blanched.  A skipper of an aircraft carrier would hardly deal directly with a Lieutenant "Jay Gee" (JG
column22: for "Junior Grade") to inform him of such a thing.  There are
column23: of course
column24: officers of intervening rank and intervening commands and responsibilities below that of the skipper of the ship. You would have other Commanders
column25: Lieutenant Commanders
column26: and Lieutenants who would be in the chain of command between the skipper and the protagonist.  If there's one thing that's paramount in the military
column27: its delegation of authority!  It would certainly be somebody else who would inform the JG of his "promotion."  So
column28: I had to swallow hard
column29: again
column30: and go along with the absurd notion that a Lt. JG would report directly to a Captain
column31: let alone the skipper of the boat.  Then
column32: while these two are conferring
column33: a four-star general shows up unannounced via a tender to chew-out the Navy Captain.  Aw
column34: come on.  Between the four-star and the Captain are three-star generals
column35: two-star generals and one-star generals.  The chain of command would insert these people into the mix well before a four-star would come and deal directly with a four-striper
column36: let alone "chew him out."  After all
column37: one is ARMY
column38: and the other is NAVY.  The ticked-off general would vent his anger through not only his own chain of command
column39: but decidedly through the chain of command of the US Navy.  I swallowed hard
column40: again
column41: but kept reading.  Now

column1: I have been a design student for about two years and I purchased this book soley through word of mouth.  I approached this book as if I was a beginner

column7: but fails to explain how to find the midpoints of the sides
column8: and instead

column11: I always ended up with distorted images.  An example is when the author asks you to duplicate a cube in each direction.  Unless you are a machine
column12: your cube will not be perfect and your duplicated cubes would only come out distorted.  But that is why a cube is already provided for you in the book for you to work on.  However
column13: it seems that even professionals are imperfect
column14: for when you duplicate the cube which is provided in the book

Philip Slater puts forth with vehemence and passion his opinions on the trends of hyperconsumerism and overindependence that are driving rifts between the people of our nation and diverting much-needed resources from  instituations designed to create health and well-being. His observations  about how middle-class Americans are alienating themselves by placing far  too much emphasis on material possessions
column2: individualistic thought ("I  am different from all of you")
column3: and an economy that is powerfully  rooted in the need to simply consume and produce goods rather than increase  the quality of life are interesting
column4: though a bit dated
column5: and still hold  much relevance to the current situation today.    Still
column6: the phenomena he  rages against are nothing new to the conscientious among us
column7: and there are  many other views on the problems of loneliness and hyperconsumerism that  prey on us. Slater makes powerful points
column8: and he clearly has a deep desire  to see change and the end of the injustices that characterize our century
column9: but I found his writing style and thought process to be scattered and far  too extremist to inspire me. His book seemed less of an empirical analysis  of the problems facing our nation and what we can do to solve them and more  of an emotional rant about what he personally feels is wrong and where he  feels we all went wrong. Nothing bad about that
column10: it's just he seems so  angry and hurt about it all that he didn't come close to capturing me  (though the chapter about Vietnam and the last chapter were coming close).      It was a good book
column11: but there are far better books written by far more  inspirational people. Carl Rogers ("On Becoming a Person") was a  psychologist who spoke beautifully and wisely for the healing of the  isolation and misunderstandings in our relationships with each other.  Barbara Marx Hubbard ("Conscious Evolution: Awakening the Power of Our  Social Potential") writes convincingly and with an uplifting sense of  hope about the problems we face as a people and a culture and what we can  do in the coming decades to move in the direction that Philip Slater longed  for. Both these authors
column12: and many others
column13: rationally describe problems we  all face
column14: then offer warm and well though-out advice about what we can all  do. Slater seems like something of a ranter
column15: and reading his book only  depressed me. But hey
column16: read the book
column17: then move on. Good luck

column1: I generally read about 100-150 books a year

column3: there are usually only two or three I don't finish. This is one of them. I picked this up intrigued by the Du Maurier name and the premise of a union between the United States and United Kingdom. Alas
column4: around halfway through this last of Du Maurier's seventeen novels
column5: I realized I was bored to distraction by the tepidness of the satire and generally lackluster prose. The story is set contemporarily (it was published in 1972)
column6: and like so many of her works
column7: in Cornwall. The idea is that a former stage actress of some repute and wealth has retired to a large mansion where she has taken in a series of orphan children
column8: allowing them a great deal of freedom to develop their imaginations. To a certain extent
column9: this character seems semi-autobiographical
column10: and the way the children are raised parallels her own relatively unrestrained upbringing. One day the household arises to discover American planes flying overhead
column11: marines landing on the shores near the house
column12: and an announcement of a political union between the U.S. and U.K. This is apparently in response to some kind of European Unionish fiasco that is left to the reader's imagination. The real point seems to be that Britons will never never never become slaves
column13: nor even the little brother to America's big brother. The household's first sighting of the Americans occurs when a nervous Marine shoots a neighbors beloved dog
column14: which sets the standard for the subtlety of satire. Soon
column15: the elderly lady is predictably leading a local revolt against the occupation
column16: American soldiers are brawling with locals over girls
column17: and so on. The problem is that the Du Maurier can't seem to decide if the story is supposed to be a satire
column18: a farce
column19: cautionary
column20: realistic
column21: or what. And since none of the characters were developed enough or interesting enough to care about
column22: I realized my time might be better spent reading something else.

column1: I might as well re-draft this review as only 0 of 2 people enjoyed the first draft.  That's wouldn't normally phase me
column2: but I can do better for you in this case.    I first saw a segment of ST-2 on cable and mistook it for an anemically budgeted direct-to-DVD release.  This ticked me off a bit because I'm a fan of Phil Tippett
column3: who got his major feature film directorial shot on this movie.    Having now got the DVD
column4: I have unreeled it from the beginning and I find it loads more ambitious
column5: intelligent and well rendered by director Tippett than I had given the producers credit for permitting.  Tippett has been an innovator in the CGI field -- stop-motion
column6: go-motion
column7: and transitional model-to-CGI models manipulated so as to provide dynamic effects for an impressive array of digital creatures. Among those milestones are the perfectly convincing insect creatures in the first STARSHIP TROOPERS movie. The multitudes of individually rendered creatures in STARSHIP TROOPERS are spotlessly realistic.    As a general rule
column8: if a studio greenlights a movie sequel as a direct-to-DVD release
column9: they intend to suffocate the production -- whether the franchise has been good
column10: bad or mediocre in the market -- by simply failing to provide a generous -- or even a minimal budget -- to sustain life support in any recognizable way.  Trust me -- starve any sequel of support and money and you become a key factor in ruining even the best of franchises.    STARSHIP TROOPERS (the first) was not a runaway commercial hit on first run
column11: apparently
column12: when compared to its $100 million cost.  But sci-fi buffs are a loyal film audience with eternal memories
column13: and it is certain that this ambitious sci-fi production will continue to attract countless repeated viewings -- and income -- for the rest of the studios' and the filmmakers' natural lives.  Nobody loses on this one.  A sequel is hardly a big gamble if one invests long-term.    Regardless of that
column14: director Phil Tippett has not only done an impressive job of directing his first major film
column15: he has also done a very smart job of producing a generous portion of images large in scope and convincing in power within his spare budget.    Looking at the bug war scenes in the first act
column16: you might easily not suspect there were any production restrictions at all.  Credit Mr. Tippett for that achievement.  In fact
column17: there are moments that benefit from lessons learned in the first movie
column18: which have added impact as a result.    Now for a few notes:  I would have liked to see the bug culture and biology expanded in new
column19: logical ways.  I would like to have seen bug life-cycle mechanics which did not rehash ground covered by other unrelated movies -- what has been done and re-done in sci-fi productions as far back as ALIEN.    The creative possibilities for an intelligent multiped
column20: exoskeleton
column21: hive-bred civilization are unlimited.  There is no need at all for the writers or FX techs to resort to the over-used and tired gimmick of an alien climbing from one human's mouth to another human mouth
column22: for example.    Nor do we need yet another script in which we revisit the old familiar premise of films from INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS to THE HIDDEN to THE THING that anyone can be inhabited by an alien and still appear normal.  It has been done to death.  Let's move on and discard that whole much copied process.    I could tell you things about the way a crawdad captures and eats a minnow from the tail forward that would make your hair stand on end. There is plenty of fresh
column23: untapped bug behavior to mine
column24: and there is far too much writing talent involved with the STARSHIP TROOPERS series to need to use anything rehashed from any previous motion picture.   Still in all
column25: Phil Tippett's feature debut as director is more than competent and particularly surprising for his facility with the actors.  I look forward to his future development as a director.

column1: Any resemblence between what is stated in this book and what's actually going on in the Middle East is purely coincidental.  What the reader gets instead is some amazing fascist propaganda that won't truly serve anyone.    Hirst writes for the Guardian
column2: a rather famous British newspaper that took decades to establish a fine reputation for its journalism.  It is staggering to realize just how much damage the Guardian has done to this reputation in just a short while by permitting such nonsense to invade its pages.  And I think we need to ask ourselves how and why this has happened.  The staff of the Guardian has to be professional.  One would think that they would hesitate to destroy their paper in such a manner.  After all
column3: it would cost the paper money.  It might ruin the paper entirely
column4: and put them out of jobs.  One might suppose it unlikely that they would want to violate any semblence of good journalistic practice just to hurt a few Jews or Israelis.  However
column5: the experience of reading this book and seeing some of the reviews has led me to a hypothesis of what has happened.  The destruction of the Guardian's reputation as a conduit of good journalism has not put it out of business at all.  Just as this book has brought money to its author
column6: the ghastly articles in the Guardian bring money to the newspaper
column7: if only by appearing sensational and controversial.    I think we readers have a duty to try to reverse this trend.  Just as dedicated people have made great progress in the campaign against cigarette smoking
column8: the same can be done in the campaign against bad journalism.  We can warn our friends about books such as this one.  And we ought to do just that

column7: headmistress of "The School
column8: possesses not a single good quality and is a criminal to boot. In not quite enough contrast, the heroine, the slim and glamorous art critic Helen Drager, is shallow, unsympathetic, and not above crassly manipulating her husband's position as a producer for the Cooking Channel for personal gain. Her doting husband Michael is such a complete pushover (except for once when he screws his courage to the sticking point and *gasp* withdraws one of his daughter's high school applications) that the reader wishes Helen would just consummate her affair with the wealthy and recently widowed art collector Philip, who talks like this: 'I find you incredibly attractive." His gaze held hers.' Instead
column9: the two neck on a sofa one afternoon.   Who is the audience for this dreck? Given that the novelist Judy Blume (authoress of "Tale of a Fourth-Grade Nothing" and "Frecklejuice") wrote the blurb
column10: one suspects it is the students portrayed here (or their younger siblings) rather than their parents. At least one hopes that there aren't enough adults who like this book to have taken it into paperback. I'm embarrassed that I finished reading it

column1: I was disappointed in the latest Lincoln Rhyme mystery. The book had more twists than a Chubby Checker song and in the end they strained credibility.  Rhyme and Sachs are called in to solve a string of murders by a serial killer calling himself the Watchmaker. Rhyme has met his match with the Watchmaker
column2: a meticulous killer who leaves nothing to chance and leaves few clues for Rhyme to follow.  Running parallel to the story of the Watchmaker
column3: Sachs is also lead detective on her first case - a case that appears to involve police corruption. Sachs is juggling a heavy case load as well as rumours that her own father may have been corrupt. Ron Pulaski steps up to help with crime scenes and proves himself to be a smart and resourceful officer but ultimately it is up to Rhyme and Sachs to solve the case.   The book introduces Kathryn Dance
column4: a visiting Californian expert in Kinesics
column5: the study of body language. Dance helps interview suspects and witnesses and plays a role in solving the case. There is also a hint of romance with officer Sellitto which is ultimately left hanging. The information about Kinesics is interesting and Dance is a character that could have used more development.   The title of the book comes from a season in the lunar calendar
column6: which is also a time of death. The book also contains a lot of information about clocks and time courtesy of the Watchmaker. There was some fascinating information
column7: but at times the book was bogged down in historical details about clocks.  The book lurches from one plot twist to the next. At first it was exciting
column8: but after a while it became tedious. NOTHING was what it seemed. Further I found Rhyme less likeable in this book - grumpy
column9: bossy
column10: pedantic and sarcastic. The only hint of humanity was in his fear that he may lose Sachs.  At times I found the writing clumsy. Deaver uses cliched adjectives in his sentences to describes his characters
column11: such as
column12: "the handsome
column13: sardonic and impatient criminalist" I found it trite to describe Rhyme that way.   This book is not as good as earlier Rhyme mysteries.

On the whole it's not a disaster

column1: I brought this book after reading the reviews of the many people it has clearly helped.  I have suffered from chronic neck pain for many years now.  I wondered if the chronic nature of my pain could be due to emotional or other reasons.   Unfortunately
column2: the book did not help.  It appears that either this is not the cause or I am in the small group of people that Dr Sarno believes need counseling.    One thing I did find frustrating was the abruptness with which the book ended.  Dr Sarno concludes that some people will need counseling to achieve relief.  However he provides no guidance about the type of counseling or what sort of issues may need to be addressed.  I got to the end of the book with no where else to go.  I couldn't envision going to a psychologist and saying "I have neck pain
column3: help me discover what is causing it".    I have since decided that this is not the cause of my problem.  It appears to be an intermittent physical problem.  So far my I've found that yoga and remedial massage have been the most successful in controlling my problem.  Regular yoga in particular often provides weeks and weeks of relief.  This book didn't help me
column4: but from the many glowing reviews it has obviously helped many other people.  Mostly
column5: I wrote this review so that people would be aware that it doesn't work in all cases.

column1: Verbose
column2: annoyingly pedantic
column3: and rarely to the point
column4: this text is a disaster from start to finish. For students who have little to no research experience it will be overwhelming in detail (unless you find reading formal style manuals to be a joy). On the contrary
column5: for the more seasoned researcher certain sections will likely appear dubious or downright wrong
column6: insofar as the text has a strong bias towards a certain social scientific approach (which is subject to learned academic debate
column7: a point students should be made aware of). It essentially presents the research process as take it or leave it
column8: encouraging a investigative framework that leads to inevitably trite conclusions. Additionally
column9: it reads like a car manual with many sections repeated verbatim when the need arises for them to be referenced a second time. Finally
column10: it uses examples of students work that are of questionable quality as positive examples
column11: rather than well written
column12: notable published pieces.   In conclusion
column13: this would never be an appropriate guide for a students at elite research universities
column14: nor would it be an efficient approach for students at less vaunted programs.

column1: Three problems with this film:  1. PACING - The film's pacing doesn't vary.  It's very boring.  As a matter of fact
column2: this wouldn't be a problem if the film were much more tense (e.g.
column3: "Speed")
column4: however this film lacks the high-action intensity to pull off such a slow expository speed.    2. EFFECTS - Too many sequences of this film rely on color and light superimpositions
column5: and there is an overabundance of high-speed imaging.  The scene changes that employ erratic barrages of images desensitize the viewer from the thrilling "horror" scenes.  Furthermore
column6: they fail to make enough sequential sense of the film's plot to really mean much to the film as a greater whole.  The upshot: the film relies too heavily on the art of editing
column7: to the point where plot twists are no longer interesting.    3. TRIVIALITY - The plot's conclusion quails in the face of the "so what?" question.  The viewer is left with a sense of
column8: "I sat through the film for THAT?"  In light of points (1) and (2)
column9: this obnoxious bit is the icing on the cake.    Don't waste your life.  ALon

column1: Books have been written
column2: and will continue to be written
column3: to try and disprove Christianity and Jesus as the Son of God. What is almost comical is that one has to print lies and errors to try and convince people. That's because you can't disprove the TRUTH. And what are some of the errors
column4: you ask? I will give you a few: Dan Brown tries to use Gnostic gospels (gospels written in the 2nd century and beyond by people who were not eyewitnesses) to try and prove his theory and omitting New Testament Scripture. To say that Jesus and Mary Magdalene were married by using the Gospel of Phillip (written after 250 A.D.) where there are missing words: And the companion of the [...] Mary Magdalene. [...] more than [...] the disciples
column5: [...] kiss her [...] on her [...]. Clearly
column6: there is some problems with this text with the missing words and the fact that it was written over 200 years after Jesus died. This does not prove anything. Also
column7: he says that the word "companion" means spouse in Aramaic
column8: which is great
column9: except that the Gospel of Philip was written in "Coptic
column10: where companion" does not mean "spouse!" Second
column11: Dan Brown says that it wasn't until 325 AD at the Council of Nicea did people start to believe Jesus was a Deity and that it was a close vote. New Testament disproves that because it shows that Jesus was Deity where Paul writes in 1 Corinthians 15:3-5: "For I delivered to you first of all that which I also received: that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures
column12: and that He was buried
column13: and that He rose again the third day according to the Scriptures
column14: and that He was seen by Cephas
column15: then by the twelve." Also
column16: The Council of Nicea met only to sort out some differences among church leaders
column17: all of whom believed that Jesus was divine. The main question was whether Jesus was begotten or made. Jesus' divinity
column18: death and resurrection were not in question. Only two of 318 clerics at the Council did not sign the Nicene Creed. So there was not a close vote unless you think 318 to 2 is close! Third
column19: his main argument is that it Mary Magdalene in the Last Supper painting by Leo. If that were true
column20: then where is John
column21: the youngest and most beloved apostle? John was often portrayed in a feminine manner to convey youth
column22: as is seen in many stained glass portraits in European cathedrals. And also
column23: Leo was just a painter who was not around when Jesus was
column24: so it didn't matter if he tried to put Mary in a painting or not! Fourth
column25: Brown says that The Gnostic gospels and the Dead Sea Scrolls are "the earliest Christian records." While the New Testament obviously came before the Gnostic gospels
column26: The Dead Sea Scrolls refer to a collection of about 900 documents
column27: many of which are fragmentary scrolls written in Hebrew
column28: Greek and Aramaic
column29: that were discovered in a cave and do not contain even a single mention of Jesus or of any other person mentioned in the New Testament as they are Jewish documents! He also says they were discovered in the 1950's when they were discovered in 1947. Oops! Fifth
column30: Dan Brown says that Christianity borrowed its beliefs from the pagan religion of Mithraism. He says that Mithraism worshipped the pre-Christian God Mithras
column31: called the Son of God and Light of the World
column32: who was born on December 25th
column33: died
column34: was buried in a rock tomb
column35: and then resurrected in three days. Scholars of Mithraism would strongly disagree with Brown on all of these points. Nowhere is Mithras given the title Son of God and the Light of the World. Brown apparently made this up because it sounded good. Mithras was born on December 25th
column36: however this proves nothing. The New Testament never associated December 25th with the birth of Christ. The early Christians chose to celebrate the birth of Christ on this day intentionally to oppose the pagan mid-winter festival of Saturnalia. They never claimed Jesus was actually born on that date. The claim that Mithras died and was buried in a rock tomb is just not true. Scholars will tell you that in Mithraism there is no death of Mithras at all. So
column37: there was no rock tomb and no resurrection. So once again
column38: he is nowhere near correct. Lastly
column39: Brown says that the four canonical gospels were chosen from over 80 gospels. First
column40: there were only less than half that many books written about Jesus life. The two Gnostic gospels Brown relies on most heavily weren't written until the second century A.D.
column41: long after the New Testament gospels were written. It makes sense that the Gnostic gospels came about in the late second century
column42: as this is when Gnostic thought was most prevalent. However
column43: the New Testament was complete before the end of the 1st Century. Also
column44: the Gospel of Thomas
column45: which Dan Brown lies heavily on
column46: claims women must become men in order to receive salvation. That makes no sense. There are many other errors in this novel
column47: but I think I have showed there are enough lies in this book not to be taken seriously. This is pure (or rather "poor") fiction
column48: without a shred of evidence that Jesus was anything other than the Christ
column49: the Son of the living God! Thank you
column50: Dan Brown
column51: for making my faith stronger

column1: "LACE AND WHISKEY"  REVIEW:  This has to be Alice's most inconsistent album. The albums only real standout tracks are "It's Hot Tonight
column2: You And Me
column3: the funny King of the Silver Screen" and the gut-wrenchingly sad "I Never Wrote Those Songs". But this album may be home to the worst Alice Cooper song and that's the Chas Underwood-penned track
column4: "Ubangi Stomp". Both "(No More) Love At Your Convienence" and "My God" aren't very good either while "Lace And Whiskey
column5: Road Rats
column6: and Damned If You Do" are nothing more than just decent.   THE PLAYERS:  Dick Wagner - Guitars
column7: Vocals  Bob Ezrin - Keyboards
column8: Vocals  Steve Hunter - Guitars  Babbitt - Bass  Tony Levin - Bass ("Lace And Whiskey
column9: Damned If You Do
column10: and Ubangi Stomp")  John Prakash - Bass ("Road Rats")  Allan Schwartzberg - Drums  Jim Gordon - Drums ("Road Rats
column11: Damned If You Do
column12: and You And Me") Jim Maelen - percussion
column13: vocals  Jozef Chirowski - keyboards  Al Macmillan - Piano ("Damned If You Do")  Al Kooper - piano ("Damned If You Do")  Ernie Watts - tenor sax and clarinet  Venetta Fields
column14: Julia Tillman
column15: Lorna Willard - Vocals ("Road Rats")  Douglas Neslund and the California Boys' Choir - vocals   INTERESTING FACTS:  1. Released in April of 1977
column16: "Lace And Whiskey" peaked at #42 on the Billboard Top 200. Despite having a Top 10 hit single ("You And Me") this has yet to be certified by the R.I.A.A for sales in excess of 500
column17: 000 copies sold.  2. "You And Me" would later be covered by the late Frank Sinatra at the Hollywood bowl.  3. "Lace And Whiskey" was Alice's highest chart placing album in Australia at #3.  PACKAGING:  The front and back cover are cool concepts while the booklet does feature the album's lyrics.  APPROX. RUNNING TIME:  40 min. and 16 sec.  FINAL ANALYSIS:  This was Alice's worst album up until this point but it is intriguing to listen to if nothing more than to wonder "what the hell were they thinking?". This is - however - the worst Alice Cooper album that Bob Ezrin has produced. **1/2 out of 5.

column1: I was extremely disappointed with this camera.  It's a shame there is no option for zero stars
column2: because it doesn't even deserve one.  I bought two of them for a vacation to Belize because we were planning to do a lot of activities in and around the water
column3: and we were hoping to capture those memories without risk to our digital camera.  Now I really regret not putting a little more money into a waterproof case for our digital camera rather than wasting money on this camera and developing pictures that were only worthy of the garbage can.   All of the pictures from both cameras were very grainy - terrible
column4: terrible quality.  The camera that we took pictures with while diving was slightly better than the one we never even submerged in the water.  Those pictures were so grainy that we couldn't even tell what the pictures were supposed to be of.  Extremely disappointing for a camera that wasn't even submerged in water.  Not to mention both cameras said that there were more pictures left on the roll when there were none
column5: so we took shots that we thought were going to be really amazing only to find that they weren't even on the negatives.  I was so disappointed in this camera that I wrote to Kodak and they offered to send me two new disposable cameras.  Unfortunately our trip to Belize was a once in a lifetime trip
column6: so I have absolutely no need for replacements - the damage is done.  And I have no desire to ever use one of these cameras again. If you are planning on using a disposable waterproof camera for capturing valuable memories
column7: DO NOT waste your money on this one.  The only thing you will receive from the photo lab is disappointment.  I wish I had done more research before purchasing this one - please don't even bother with it

column1: Heinlein's first attempt at a novel stayed locked away
column2: unpublished
column3: in a drawer until after his death for a reason.  As a story
column4: the plot does not flow and the characters
column5: although very smart
column6: lack any real depth.  This was Heinlein's extended diatribe on how he thought the world should be.  Heinlein is probably lucky that this book was not picked up by a publisher.  In the fifties
column7: he would have went to jail for writing such ideas. This book is great as a comparison read to see how much Heinlein changed from his idealistic youth until his libertarian death.  Some of the predictions are true
column8: but
column9: at this time
column10: Heinlein really underestimated how much technological development would come in the near future.    I recommend this book to Heinlein fans as a comparison or beginnings work.  I would also recommend this book to economics students as they would be the only ones to truly grasp the economic scenario laid out towards the end.  It could have been more.  I think Heinlein recycled what he thought he could use in other stories.  If you want to read some Heinlein
column11: there are other better selections to choose from.

column1: If you're going to read one of the great classics of literature-and you should-don't pick up this edition.  It is a reprint of a version that dates back to the 1870s and was exposed more than 40 years ago for cutting nearly one-quarter of Verne's story and mistranslating much of the remainder.  Its reappearance in this edition is all the more amazing considering Tor's status as a leading science fiction publisher
column2: and the company's willingness to perpetrate this fraud on is many readers is truly stunning.  If you want to truly get to know Verne's novel
column3: pick up the elegant Naval Institute Press edition
column4: in a modern
column5: complete
column6: updated translation
column7: with commentary by the leading American Verne expert today
column8: Walter James Miller.  That book also comes with many of the artistic engravings that illustrated the original French first edition (no illustrations are to be found in the B&N Mercier reprint).  Less attractive but more academic is the Oxford Classics version of Twenty Thousand Leagues.  This review is posted on behalf of the North American Jules Verne Society by Jean-Michel Margot
column9: president NAJVS

column1: This book has a touchy-feely self-absorbed New Age feel to it. I see that most reviews for this book are positive but this one is not. If you lean even a little toward the evangelical and/or fundamental
column2: please consider the following:  Walsch claims God could be a woman (or without gender). He refers to God as "She" and "Her" in spots.   There are too many references to all of us being One. We are not "one"; we are individuals
column3: created by God to be individuals with different gifts to use in His service. It is He who equips us
column4: not we who fit God into a "friendship" relationship -- this is simply not scriptural. In John 15:14
column5: Jesus says
column6: "You are My friends if you do whatever I command you." This denotes a higher-to-lower hierarchy
column7: one which is repeated throughout the Bible. Jesus (God) clearly states He is in charge and in a superior position. But Walsch's writing does not convey this. It conveys an equality
column8: implicitly
column9: that he and God are on equal footing. This is offensive.   In his hubris
column10: Walsch writes
column11: "It has been two thousand years since the birth of Christ
column12: twenty-five hundred since the time of the Buddha
column13: and more since we first heard the words of Confucius
column14: or the widsom of the Tao
column15: and we still haven't gotten the Main Questions figured out." [We haven't?] "Will there ever be a way to turn the answers we have already received into something workable
column16: something that can function in our day-today lives?" [Many of us have done so by following the Bible.] "I think there is. And I feel pretty certain about it
column17: because I've discussed it a lot in my conversations with God."  [I see.]  Walsch calls himself a Christian but places other religious figures on equal footing with Christ. Jesus never left open the option of truth claims to ANY but His own. Christ never offered a one-from-column-A
column18: one-from-column-B faith. In the guise of thinking outside the box
column19: Walsh reveals his own religious pluralism.   In Scripture
column20: God tells us to fear Him (not a craven fear
column21: a Godly fear). God tells us to worship Him
column22: obey Him and come before Him in humility and in supplication. I see none of this reflected in the pages of Walsch's book. God is my Creator
column23: my Saviour
column24: the Love of my life Who loves me. But He is not my friend; He is God
column25: far above friendship. On this earth a father can be a friend. In God's realm
column26: God is God and not on equal footing with anyone. From Walsch's writing
column27: I got a creepy feeling he was lecturing and explaining to God things God may not have known.   The last straw was the following paragraph where Walsch is justifying the large profits he makes on his books (not that profit is a bad thing): "Is Ted Turner less valuable than Mother Teresa? Is George Soros less of a good person than Che Rivera? Are the politics of Jesse Jackson
column28: who appears to have plenty of the good things in life
column29: less worthy than the politics of Vaclav Havel
column30: who may have less? Should the Pope
column31: whose very garments cost more than it would take to feed a poor child for a year
column32: have his words called blasphemy because he lives like a king as the head of a church which owns billions? Ted Turner and George Soros have given away millions of dollars. They've empowered the dreams of humanity with the rewards of their own dreams
column33: lived."  Turner
column34: Soros and Jesse Jackson are not role models for most people I know. Walsch seems to set them up as such.  Walsch writes the following self-absorbed
column35: misguided statement: "It's as if we somehow know that if we can learn more about one another
column36: we can learn more about ourselves. And the yearning to know more about ourselves -- about Who We Really Are  -- is the depest yearning of all." No
column37: Mr. Walsch; the deepest yearning of all is not to know more about ourselves: It should be to know more about GOD. It is He Who will teach us what we need to know about ourselves
column38: if anything. Americans are already too self-absorbed. We don't need more of it.  Perhaps it is just me but I found this New Age claptrap just a bit over the top
column39: not biblical and certainly not the kind of Christianity I'd like to see spread around.

column9: because you can't compress all that into such a short time span.   Then

column17: presenting all the back story
column18: but I was surprised later on when I needed it and remembered it so well. Okay
column19: yep
column20: Tolkien's got game. Given his popularity
column21: one would sincerely hope so.   You absolutely have to love the look of Middle Earth. How are they able to adjust everybody's heights? Most of the special effects are impressive.   Most importantly
column22: somehow I feel sure the filmmaker stayed true to Tolkien's vision. In fact
column23: I read somewhere that he did.   I never found elves quite so annoying in my Dungeons & Dragons days as I do now. I bet they never sweat
column24: do they? They talk in riddles and glow too much
column25: but I guess that happens when you live too long.   The various species are quite distinguishable
column26: aren't they? So are different members of the same species. This is masterful. It's a skill far too few modern authors possess. Either everybody in the book seems like the same person
column27: or else each character seems to belong to a stereotype of some sort. Tolkien avoids both pitfalls while simultaneously acknowledging that
column28: yes
column29: sometimes it's reassuring to a person/character to have a stereotype to fall back upon for a sense of identity when circumstances require.   Once our fellowship finally goes into battle
column30: we get some great sequences. Among many fine performances
column31: those of Frodo and Gandalf stand out in my mind. Oh
column32: and "never toss a dwarf
column33: which I KNOW Tolkien didn't write. Anxiously awaiting part two.   THE TWO TOWERS   What's more boring than real world politics? Fictional politics! I don't believe Tolkien spent this much time on the war aspect. Well, I hope he didn't. Saruman makes a bunch of uber-Orcs and sics 'em on humanity. Fine. We don't need a cast of thousands to spend hours in mock battles. Nor do we need the lamest excuse for a love story" in cinematic history.   But once we FINALLY get past all that
column34: I believe we get back to the Tolkien vision. Here's hoping we stay there for part three.   (Two hours
column35: two paragraphs. What's wrong with this picture?)   THE RETURN OF THE KING   A balanced attack. That's what THE TWO TOWERS lacks but THE RETURN OF THE KING has. By this
column36: I mean that long sustained fight sequences are boring. That's not your "action
column37: unless your name's Jackie Chan. Give us just enough fight to let us move from plot point to plot point, then switch over to the real conflict before we get bored and leave the theater.   {No hate mail from Jackie Chan fans, please. I love SHANGHAI NOON.}   The real drama comes in the interpersonal, and in Frodo versus that @#$%^* ring. Gollum is one freaky deaky, ain't he? Liv Tyler is still unwatchable, but fortunately her screen time was minimal.   We get very close to the end of this film before Hollywood excess creeps into the war scenes. Those very cool elephants, for example, seem unstoppable. I was quite impressed with Orlando Bloom's quietly effective performances, but I'll never believe his computer simulated double took down one of those big bad muthas. Those elephants are doomsday machines, and the heroes' strongholds were Hiroshima and Nagasaki.   Meanwhile back at the ranch, perhaps we had one too many dramatic rescues that stretched credibility. Sam the Hobbit versus HOW MANY orcs? Um, lest we forget, he's only a freakin hobbit!   I don't know if it was the screenwriters who wrote themselves into a corner or perhaps Tolkien himself. But, well, somebody damn sure did. Let's floor the gas over those speedbumps and see what's on the other side.   Unlike some critics, I appreciated that this film didn't end at the climax." We needed some more time to just hang out in Middle Earth

column1: The idea for this book is an excellent one
column2: but the results are very disappointing. Each participant makes such a weak case for their respective positions that the debate itself becomes superfluous. It's like watching the 3rd card in a boxing match. Who cares? For example
column3: Gary Habermas tries to make the affirmative case by citing what he calls 12 "known historical facts" that are indisputable. Here are some of his known facts along with the disputations he apparently was unaware of...  p. 19 "Jesus died due to the rigors of crucifixion" - Very many scholars doubt that the 3 to 6 hours that Jesus was on the cross were sufficient to be a cause of death. Many people lasted for 3 or 4 days. Even Pilot himself was surprised to learn that Jesus died so quickly. Indeed
column4: there are many scholars who believe that the resurrection was actually a "resusitation". This may or may not be true
column5: but it is NOT true that Jesus' death by crucifixion is an uncontested historical fact.  p. 19 "...was buried." The question as to whether or not Jesus was placed in a tomb or simply thrown into a ditch and later buried in a pauper's grave is a debated topic. See
column6: for example
column7: Martin Hengel's informative book Crucifixion in the Ancient World and Haim Cohn's excellent book The Trial and Death of Jesus. Regardless of your belief
column8: it is incorrect to claim Jesus' placement in the tomb as uncontested historical fact. It is not fact at all. Finding Jesus' body in the tomb would establish the fact that he had been placed there. Reading about the placement in the Gospels does not make it fact!  p. 20. "James
column9: the brother of Jesus and a skeptic
column10: was converted to the faith when he also believed he saw the resurrected Jesus." - Nonsense. There is nothing in the New Testament about James' conversion. In fact
column11: there is a great deal of evidence that the Gospels were edited to remove evidence of the positive involvement of Jesus' family (see Butz' excellent book - The Brother of Jesus - for details). In any event
column12: most scholars believe that John 7:5 was a later insertion
column13: and it is John 7:5 which is the basis for Habermas's bold and encompassing assertion. James skepticism and conversion are not uncontested facts.  I could go on
column14: but you get the point. If the debater's case is weak
column15: the debate is weak.   The need for an informed debate on the resurrection is still there. This promising book does not meet that need.

column1: I'm not a perpetual dieter or diet book enthusiast. I occasionally have a few pounds to lose and I do it by cutting back on food. But recently I've found it more difficult than usual to discipline myself so I looked for a diet book that might make it easier. I was impressed by the promises made by the 3-Hour Diet: eat anything...no counting calories...no exercise...lose 2 pounds every week just by timing your meals. Well
column2: it ain't necessarily so. Eat anything? Yes
column3: as long as each meal consists of the proper balance of carbs
column4: protein
column5: fat
column6: and vegetables or fruit. And we're talking miniscule...not to mention undecipherable...amounts of each.  For the carbs--you want a Rubik's cube size portion. (Huh?)  Fats--make sure your portion size is equivalent to a water bottle cap! My favorite: you'll want to eat a portion of vegetables equivalent to 3 DVD cases. (I'm not kidding.)  No counting calories? That's just a flat-out lie since your meals are limited to 400 calories
column7: snacks are limited to 100 calories. What's more
column8: "meals" and "snacks" are alternated on this "eat every 3 hour" schedule
column9: so you're going 6 hours between your 400 calorie meals. Stop hunger? Yeah
column10: right.  No exercise? Well O.K. Yet exercise is recommended and there's a chapter devoted to suggested exercises. (Along with a suggestion that you get the author's exercise books!) But what bugged me the most about this book is the fact that the author is a Tony Robbins disciple and MOST of the book is devoted to "you can do it" motivation-speak. More than 100 solid pages are wasted with suggested "visualizations" and blank pages for the reader to record his/her day-by-day menus and thoughts.  Maybe "scam" is too strong a word but in no way does this book deliver what it promises.

column5: physicists and mathematicians alike have better alternatives

column7: with complementary qualities
column8: by Burke
column9: "Applied Differential Geometry"; by do Carmo
column10: "Riemannian Geometry"
column11: or by Spivak
column12: "A Comprehensive Introduction to Differential Geometry". This text's popularity in some areas of engineering must have played a role in the slow acceptance of Riemannian geometric methods.  Manuel Tenid

Since I have subscribed online directly through WD's website in Jan 2005
column4: I have received only a few issues. In the first few months for almost half a year
column5: I received no issues at all. It was only later then when I e-mailed them did they manage to get some issues through to me. The annoying thing is that even though I have e-mailed WD a few times on this problem
column6: they would reply apologetically saying that they will extend my subsription. How does this tackle the root of the problem? If they could not have assured its overseas subscribers a consistent service
column7: they should not have offered an 'overseas subscribers' option. Ironically
column8: I received their letter asking for a renewal of my subscription recently with my home address clearly printed on the front of the letter.  Logistic problems aside
column9: the magazine does have its plus points. In the issues
column10: there are useful tips for writers not simply on the craft of writing
column11: but also on the business and spiritual aspect of the writing process as well. Occasional issues also features insights into the lives of authors to give us an idea of how and where they work
column12: their opinions on life and the areas from which they derive their inspiration. All this from a range of authors from a range of genres. Essentially
column13: the business of writing is also not left out.  However
column14: the magazine is not one fraught without problems. The problem with WD is that the information presented to readers is too limited and scattered. Each article though containing valuable tips on writing
column15: does not have enough depth to really improve the work of authors if they are really implemented. In addition
column16: because of its range
column17: it also does not provide what some writers really want consistently
column18: which can be a waste of time for them to read if they are subscribers. Sometimes
column19: it does seem that the magazine is purposely limiting the information that they give to readers in order to encourage further buying of future issues. This for example
column20: can be seen in the amount of publishers' addresses that they offer. At most
column21: each specific article on a particular topic contains on average 7-10 addresses. There is nothing wrong with this
column22: but why would an author want to waste his time to have bits and pieces of such information when he can just purchase a Writer's market collection of publishers(and agencies) addresses collected into one? And ironically again
column23: the same company does publish a 'Writer's Market' collection which is of excellent quality annually.  That said
column24: the same problem - the lack of information and depth
column25: is also seen in the advice and tips it gives as well. To make matters worse
column26: every issue is usually cluttered with a plethora of advertisements that can be frustrating to readers at times. Writers want to organise their time and information
column27: not add on to it.   If you want are thinking of subscribing to WD
column28: do consider the alternatives that are currently available. Writing is a craft that requires more common sense and acumen than many would like to think. However
column29: if you are not particularly concerned with little information fed to you in slower dozes or are not too worried about a little more untidiness in your life
column30: than this magazine might be for you. But do your research first

column1: Presumably the label is trying to cater to mid-range fans who have a Prince album or two but don't want to buy them all and who want more than a single disc hits collection. The way this is laid out though is confusing at best: Disc 1 seems to be for the mid-range fan and it makes sense that they would choose the single edits though some of those chosen are questionable. ("My Name is Prince"? His take on "Nothing Compares 2 U" when Sinead O'Connor's is definitive?) Disc 2 compiles 12" mixes and remixes and similar rarities..i.e. for the diehard only who has to have every little bleat His Purpleness every records.  BOTTOM LINE: This is haphazardly thrown together. Middle range fans are better off with THE HITS/THE B-SIDES which compiles his biggest chart stuff with a pretty decent selection of interesting flip side material (some of which equals his singles)

column1: I wanted to like BROTHERHOOD
column2: for the simple reason that nearly every New Order fan this side of the galaxy has dismissed it
column3: usually with a faint whiff of snobbery (or at least apathy). Turns out they were right: BROTHERHOOD is half an album. Most of its nine songs feel unfinished
column4: as if the band wanted to cash in on the success of their 1985 smash LOW-LIFE and didn't care about the end result. BROTHERHOOD is a rush job
column5: plain and simple
column6: but there are still glimmers of hope within this bare-bones effort.   "As It Is When It Was" overcomes the album's overall muddy production by dint of being mostly acoustic
column7: and the melody is quite lovely. "All Day Long"
column8: the emotional centerpiece of the album by default
column9: is an intelligent (if half-hearted) protest against child abuse. While "Angel Dust" lacks a decent hook
column10: its subtly danceable beat and effective synth noodlings will at least briefly hold your interest. And the toss-off "Every Little Counts" has a charming sense of humor that is too often lacking in New Order's work.  The most popular song on BROTHERHOOD is
column11: of course
column12: "Bizarre Love Triangle". So good it seems to belong to a different album entirely
column13: "Bizarre Love Triangle" is truly New Order's masterpiece. The solid beat
column14: slick sequencer work
column15: and gorgeous melody showcase the band at their best: catchy
column16: danceable
column17: and downright euphoric. (Imagine how well it would have fit on LOW-LIFE.)  Sadly
column18: the rest of BROTHERHOOD is unremarkable. The album's production neatly mixes rock with electronic flourishes
column19: which has become New Order's signature sound
column20: but the songwriting doesn't measure up. Buy the album if you're a trainspotter
column21: but casual New Order fans would be better off picking up LOW-LIFE or 1983's POWER
column22: CORRUPTION AND LIES. This one is just a footnote.

column1: This is a really weak and uninspired translation - really a rewriting - of Brother Lawrence's classic little book.  The author/translator says that this is a "thought-for-thought" translation rather than a literal one
column2: and admits that this is a risky proposition.  He's right that it's risky
column3: especially when a writer is careless and takes unwarranted license with a text
column4: and unfortunately he's failed in his attempt.  It could and should have been otherwise.  The author goes overboard trying to make the book sound contemporary
column5: filling it with American colloquialisms and excessive informality to the point that it often sounds like a trivial conversation between teenagers ("let's bulldoze the dike that holds back God's flood
column6: let's cash in lost time
column7: if death is tailgating us
column8: we need to be ready
column9: life offers no `do-overs'
column10: don't look for the pleasure payoff, and on and on).  There are places where subject and verb don't agree and other grammatical or stylistic errors cause a lack of clarity.  When a writer allows himself great license
column11: he can't blame problems like these on the original text.  The author has been a news reporter and advertising copywriter
column12: and it shows.  This is too important a book to be treated with this much sloppiness and irreverence.  I'm surprised at NavPress for letting this one slip through

I doubt Anna spent more than a night in Rocky Mountain National Park.  Not only does she completely miss the unique character of the park but the park has no necessary link to the story.  The whole thing could have taken place in urban Chicago.  I have been picking up Nevada Barr books as fast as I could find them.  This book

column1: It starts off with a great premise for a novel - who wouldn't be drawn to the emotional and psychological complexities of a family torn apart by the loss of a child? But it's soon apparent that the book will be a letdown. First of all
column2: the main character
column3: Beth (mother of the lost child)
column4: is wholly unlikeable. Of course
column5: there's no rule that says that main characters have to be lovable
column6: but after several dozens of pages that deal with this woman wallowing in self-pity and shamefully neglecting her two surviving children
column7: this reader started wondering whether losing them as well wouldn't be in the kids' best interests. She is not only disagreeable - which is OK - but boring as well. The melodramatic general tone of the novel is also a big no-go - the word cheesy doesn't begin to describe it.   Apart from the annoyingly one-dimensional characters
column8: I found another big flaw in the several mistakes in the book
column9: to which other reviewers have referred (Kerry's age
column10: for example) and the numerous typos. These detracted from the book's credibility
column11: as did the contrived and artificial denouement of the story.  Lastly
column12: none of the other reviewers seems to have noticed three details I found completely unpleasant. One is the Italian grandfather Angelo's disparaging comments about the Japanese. These comments
column13: put in the mouth of a clearly sympathetic and likeable character
column14: seem strangely out of place
column15: and yet
column16: they don't seem intended to portray flaws in that person - they seem to be just what the author thinks it appropriate for that man to say. I thought it disgusting
column17: as I did restaurant-owner Augie's comment that "if people want to starve
column18: they can go to Ethiopia
column19: they don't need to come to my restaurant". What's that supposed to mean? Isn't it a really gruesome
column20: unfeeling
column21: nasty-rich-American comment? Can anyone explain in what way these gratuitous
column22: unsensitive phrases help the plot of the novel?  In the same vein
column23: I was also angered by lesbian Candy's comment regarding her wish to be a mother: "There's probably a lovely little girl out there in Chile waiting for me" (not a literal quote). Why a little girl in Chile? If I were Chilean
column24: I'd be offended - I'd like to know why Miss Mitchard thinks a Chilean kid would be better off in the hands of an American single woman who married a man against her sexual inclination and for the sole purpose of becoming pregnant (and left him when she didn't) than they would be with their natural families
column25: however poor or needy. I also wonder whether Miss Mitchard has ever considered the fact that there are probably as many abandoned and destitute children in the USA as there are in Chile
column26: if not more.  Maybe these unacceptable comments would have been less noticeable in a book that was more engaging and better written; as it is
column27: they stood out like pins in a cushion
column28: and made me dislike the novel even more

column1: It's rather amazing how many five star "reviewers" have so much of the same bad information to impart about John Kerry
column2: but so little to say about the substance of this book.   Rather than recycle chatroom effluvia
column3: I will actually review the book:   Poorly researched
column4: poorly written. Nasty
column5: vindictive
column6: and dishonest from start to finish.   For example
column7: in describing his 1971 debate with Kerry on the Dick Cavett show
column8: John O'Neill not only misrepresents what Kerry and Cavett said
column9: and the audience's response
column10: he actually misquotes HIMSELF. As the transcript (and video) of the debate is posted at O'Neill's own website
column11: how hard would it have been to check for basic accuracy?   And why tell such easily proven lies
column12: like claiming Kerry was booed during the debate
column13: when the video clearly shows that he wasn't?   If you watch
column14: you will also see O'Neill repeat a stunning lie about his own military service - his claim to have served "almost three years" in Vietnam. He made this claim several times in 1971
column15: both in speeches and in writing. But his records show that he served no more than a total of 15 MONTHS in Vietnam
column16: and that included his time offshore on a minesweeper. (You can see his military records yourself
column17: linked through his profile at Wikipedia.)   More examples of lies and misrepresentations in the book? How about the part where O'Neill claims that Kerry filmed interviews of himself while in Vietnam - four years before those cameras had sound capability.   In a more egregious example
column18: O'Neill posits
column19: in Chapter 5 of UFC
column20: that George Elliott wrote a Silver Star citation that did not reflect what happened that day. He is not honest enough to use the actual citation written by Elliott
column21: but instead uses a later
column22: edited version and then quotes things - like "numerically superior force" - that Elliott NEVER WROTE. The original citation written by Elliott PRECISELY reflects what happened that day - things he claims he was never told - as do the after action report and Zumwalt's monthly summary. (All of which can be found at SBVT's own archives.)   In this connection
column23: O'Neill claims that Elliott had no idea there were troops on the boats that day (even though he was division commander) and that they conducted the first sweep - although Elliott's citation
column24: the after action report
column25: and the monthly summary SPECIFICALLY state that there were troops on the boats and that the troops conducted the first sweep. He also claims that "[t]here is no indication that Kerry ever reported that the Viet Cong was wounded and fleeing when dispatched" - but Elliott 's citation and the after action report SPECIFICALLY state that Kerry shot a fleeing VC
column26: and the after action report says that the man was wounded.   In addition
column27: O'Neill claims that Hoffmann and Elliott had been told Kerry had "almost single-handedly" taken out a bunker of VC - except NOTHING OF THE SORT appears in the original citation
column28: the after action report
column29: the monthly summary
column30: or the news release for the incident. In fact
column31: the after action report specifically says that "other units saturated [the] area with fire and beached placing assault parties ashore" while Kerry chased the VC. column1: There is almost no science to back up the author's claims about the benefits of companion plants. Most of her book is based on folk tales
column2: myths and assumptions.   A gentleman named Craig Dremann actually studied the effects of companion plants and concluded that carrots detest tomatoes. Carrots do grow well with garlic and radishes but they grow very poorly with tomatoes. Carrots only grew to 6% of normal when interplanted with tomatoes. Tomatoes grew better with carrots so clearly the tomatoes were robbing nutrients from the carrots. Tomatoes also grow better with garlic but the garlic suffers
column3: only growing 35% of normal.  The Craig Dremann booklet with his findings is called "Companion Plants: Carrots Really Detest Tomaotes" and is available from Redwood City Seed Company in Redwood City
column4: CA

column1: While this book does cover several main grammar points
column2: it is difficult to use and poorly designed.  First of all
column3: rather than offer the beginning student examples of useful conversations it offers lectures.  So instead of learning how to have a conversation we start out learning about Maha and that her father works at the U.N.  ANY beginning language book should be based on daily conversation types of dialogue.  Secondly
column4: the type is rather 'fuzzy' and important short vowel and pronunciation symbols (written above and below the main script) are often either left off or completely illegible.  While it is true that in advance Arabic these symbols are often not shown
column5: for a beginner they are very important.  Another poor design charastic of the book is that the table of contents is listed almost exclusively in Arabic so if a beginner needs to make a quick reference to something they can spend hours trying to find where it is located in the book.  The accompanying DVDs are a great idea but not very well done.  The language is given too quickly - more at the rate of an intermediate or advanced level - and there is no accompanying written dialogue to help the student figure out what is being said.  The Vocabulary on the DVD often times has a huge
column6: long sentence to show how to use a single
column7: small word. BEginners learn more easily and much more quickly when they are given small
column8: bite size bits that they can easily digest and use in everyday conversations. (I created my own work around to this by having native Arabic speakers record the vocabulary words for me on an MP3 player)  While the grammar concepts tend to be well explained
column9: there are not enough exercises to practice the concepts after the explanation.  A really great idea would have been to have lots of exercises WITH answers so that the student could immediately check their work and see if they are on the right track or not.  Instead the student has to buy the answer key... and the answer key is very difficult to read!  Also
column10: the end of each chapter should have a brief synopsis of all grammar points gone over in the chapter so if the student wants a quick glance to refresh their memory
column11: they aren't leafing through countless pages of fuzzy
column12: black and white print.  This book seems to be the standard at the moment for a lot of colleges and universities offering Arabic language courses and I'm not sure why it is.  In a day of Adobe Illustrator and other text languages it would be fairly easy to create a nice text with color type to highlight important points and other key grammar issues.  In summary:  Lacks practical conversation practice. Has very poor type quality Offers no way for students to check their work Poor table of contents DVD soundfiles too much for beginner students.  On the plus side
column13: it does explain grammar points well.

column1: Even though this is a "popular" version of the theory
column2: with the considerable advantage of being by Einstein himself
column3: it is not so easy as the presentation may imply. Einstein says in his introduction that his reasoning will demand no more than a high-school knowledge. It might be true in his time
column4: but nowadays the book demands a longer study in Physics. I offer myself as an example: I'm a literature student in post-graduation level
column5: and simply couldn't grasp the meaning of many mathematical demonstrations he uses to make his points. His reasoning is also obscure in many passages (what are really those 'galilean coordinates'?). Perhaps these details seem self-evident for professional readers
column6: but they are not for the general public (the implied target of the book). In brief
column7: Einstein didn't succeed completely in his attempt at popularization.

column1: There are parts of this book which are utterly engrossing.  Rosemont constructs a fine narrative of events.  Perhaps I should say "events"
column2: as it is at times researched like a eighth-grade paper.  Lots of conjecture
column3: unsupported speculation
column4: hearsay and other aspects of irresponsible scholarship.  Mr. Rosemont freely admits that there is frustratingly little concrete evidence about much of Hill's life
column5: but he chooses to try and flesh out a lengthy book anyways.  This is exasperating at times as when one is forced to try and endure each and every tedious mentioning of the drawn or painted art of Joe Hill
column6: despite the lack of much actual material (surviving anyways).  However
column7: by doing this he touches on many peripheral aspects of Hill's life that have gone by and large unnoticed till now
column8: but which are much easier to verify than the sketchy details about Hill himself.  Several mentions of correspondence
column9: lives affected by Hill
column10: and reactions to Hill's art
column11: and many others tidbits of information are thrown out for more or less the first time in cohesive form.  Less cohesive
column12: and downright teasing at times
column13: are many starts and stops of several ideas that would be very interesting on their own.  The Wobbly influence on the beat poets
column14: the slighting of the IWW by other revolutionary and pseudorevolutionary groups (rarely written about from a fellow worker's perspective)
column15: and others seem like promising beginnings for reading but then are waded into only ankle-deep.  At one point when abandoning a topic Mr. Rosemont even suggests that it would be a good idea for further research
column16: by someone else.  All in all a fairly decent read but could have used prodigious editing and some fact-checking with standards higher than those of the NY Times

column6: whereas normally I am unable to put down Naipaul's books. Not one of his best works...in fact I don't recommend it to anyone aside from those hardcore fans who are determined to read everything this great novelist has ever written

column1: The problem with the Supreme Court is the same problem with virtually every U.S. institution
column2: it is being coopted by corporate interests.  The watershed decision that started this process was the 1886 case of Santa Clara Country vs. the Southern Pacific Railroad
column3: in which corporations were granted "personhood."  Since that time
column4: the Fourteenth Amendment
column5: among others
column6: has been perverted by corporate lawyers to extend additional rights to Big Business
column7: and we the people have been losing the legal structure to control these private tyrannies.  Founding fathers like Thomas Jefferson warned of this growing menace when he said
column8: "I hope we shall crush in its birth the aristocracy of our monied corporations which dare already to challenge our government to a trial of strength
column9: and bid defiance to the laws of our country."  And President Grover Cleveland warned in 1888 that
column10: "As we view the achievements of aggregated capital
column11: we discover the existence of trusts
column12: combinations
column13: and monopolies
column14: while the citizen is struggling far in the rear or is trampled to death beneath an iron heel.  Corporations
column15: which should be the carefully restrained creatures of the law and the servants of the people
column16: are fast becoming the people's masters." A much more interesting book on Constitutional matters is Thom Hartmann's "Unequal Protection: The Rise of Corporate Dominance and the Theft of Human Rights."  Hartmann also hosts a daily radio program that inspires the most thought provoking dialogue in radio.  I can't say the same for Levin's book or his show. In fact
column17: I think Levin is consciously avoiding the more profound issues that people like Hartmann raise.  These more pressing issues are also raised in the award-winning documentary "The Corporation" - which is available on Amazon in DVD format.

column1: Peter Lynch's book held me back about 10 years in my investing success.  I used to believe things I read in books because a good publisher like Simon and Schuster would publish it.  I counted cars in parking lots of companies with due dilligence and questioned managers on how things were selling.  I also avoided "reading tealeaves" like drawing trendlines on what I was actually concerned about THE PRICE of the stock!  Now I make a living "reading tealeaves" and leave the parking lot duty to those who think counting cars makes the price go up.      My suggestion is to learn basic technical analysis from a book like John murphys Technical Analysis of the financial markets.  Start there then go on to learn more advanced TA.  I also like Investor's Business Daily-BUT it is very specialized and takes reading several times and probably help from a more advanced user to understand IBD.  I also swingtrade - hold stocks for 2-5 days sometimes longer.

column1: As the American half of a Yank-Aussie binational relationship
column2: I am pleased to see another entry in the small but growing library of books on LGBT immigration (especially to Australia
column3: as my partner and I are pinning our entire future on Australia's just and humane approach to same-sex immigration).  Unfortunately
column4: one can learn more about the _right_ way to go about _legal_ immigration to Australia from the country's own immigration Web site and from the smattering of printed literature than from this book.  The author's personal experience is in no way useful
column5: and
column6: sadly
column7: contributes to the misinformed notion that lesbian and gay immigrants are just trying to take advantage of the system.  In my experience (and the author's experience in no way even remotely resembles my own)
column8: nothing could be further from the truth.  As the co-founder of a LGBT immigration-rights group
column9: I can attest that the vast majority of binational couples stay well within the letter (and spirit) of the law
column10: regardless of their respective countries.  Yes
column11: often the end result is a break-up -- but that is not a commentary on the nature of same-sex relationships; unless you have been forcibly separated from your life partner due to discriminatory and downright cruel immigration policy that strips you of the right to marry or sponsor your foreign-born partner -- while allowing any two drunken heterosexuals to hitch up in a Las Vegas chapel five minutes after meeting -- you cannot possibly comprehend the hellish strain on even the strongest relationship.  The author presents a skewed picture of same-sex binational couples -- both in practice and in diversity (excuse me
column12: but not all binational couples are male) -- and is giving the rest of us a bad name.  The upshot:  Don't buy this book.  If you want a true picture of same-sex immigration to Australia (or any of the other 15 countries that offer same-sex immigration)
column13: talk to other binational couples (we're all over the Web!)
column14: and get the real story from the Australian embassy Web site.  You owe it to yourself
column15: and your partner
column16: to do everything above-board.  Australia is NOT the United States; Oz is light-years beyond the U.S. in terms of fair
column17: sane
column18: and humane immigration policy.  If your relationship is genuine
column19: you do NOT have to resort to dirty tricks

column1: I wish I'd read the Amazon review before buying this book.  Some of the information is useful and I do agree with the bits about the uselessness of store bought junky plastic toys and stupid childrens' music but the following really stood out:  1) the authors just HAD to take the opportunity to drive the message home that bottle feeding babies and pain relief during childbirth is a bad bad thing.  If there is one thing I detest
column2: it is people that think it's their right to tell women how to feed their babies
column3: or not to use pain relief.  I'd like to see if the authors visit their dentist and not get some pain relief.  Absolutely backwards and outright offensive.  2) you can begin to toilet train at 12-15 months.  What a joke!  What the authors describe is oten referred to as "toilet timing".    It is widely advised by numerous child health experts that a child is not reading to be toilet trained until much later as they lack the mental ability to understand the whole toilet thing when they're that young.  And I had to laugh at the statistic of how many children were toilet trained at that young age many years ago
column4: what a joke!  3) the breastfeeding bits are a joke
column5: I'm sure breastfeeding consultants the world over would be horrified at the "advice" here.  4) the low bed.  I understand the theory behind it but get real!  They say that children in cots have fallen and sustained spinal and head injuries.  Gee
column6: and that doesn't happen with kids that fall against a wall or low wooden toyshelf or wooden toys?  What they suggest is extremely unsafe-- using bolsters or cushions around the bed: SIDS RISK #1.  Not tucking a blanket in: SIDS RISK #2.  Actually that second one is so bad it deserves more than one check point.  If you've been living under a rock recently you probably don't know that a loose blanket exponentially increases the risk of suffocation.  5) parts of the authors' philopsophies seem to completely contradict Montessori philosophy.  I will be very interested to know how Montessori teachers feel about this book.  6) Parents are baaaad if they choose to use disposable nappies.  I started off with cloth for my son who unfortunately was a really big wee-er.  I was constantly changing nappies
column7: constantly pailing nappies
column8: constantly washing nappies
column9: constantly flushing poo off liners
column10: constantly hanging out nappies
column11: constantly folding nappies.  Coupled with sleep deprivation and not getting any other work done
column12: as well as my enjoyment of motherhood being reduced
column13: I switched to disposables when I found out I could use a recycling service.  Result?  HOURS more free to spend with my son.  So much for the authors' rubbish about valuable interaction time with your baby being reduced because you're not changing a disposable as much.  I haven't read the bit about no fences around the school and dont know if I will bother reading anymore.  Point number 1 up there made me want to stop altogether.  I wouldn't recommend this book.  I wish I could get my money back.  As lots of other reviewers have said
column14: it's a jumbled mess
